excerpts: Good strong Ethiopian coffee rounded out the meal.
There are only 5 tables and the kitchen is fun to watch while you eat!
Friendly speedy service made this a great choice before theater.
ethiopian coffee.author: Laura A.
ethiopian coffee.review: Tiny delicious place close to UN Plaza. The injera is deliciously spongy and lightly sour. We had a salad of spicy tomatoes and torn injera on a bed of romaine, and a traditional collard green dish served with tiny spiced lentils, and other garnishes. Good strong Ethiopian coffee rounded out the meal. There are only 5 tables and the kitchen is fun to watch while you eat! Friendly speedy service made this a great choice before theater.

excerpts: We also had Ethiopian coffee which was extremely strong, like a slow drip black americano.
ethiopian coffee.author: Megan K.
ethiopian coffee.review:
Mmmm! Hearty spicy Ethiopian made with love :) 
S
Light lunch turned into a feast. I only ordered 3 items for the two of us. 

Lamb tibs: spicy sautéed lamb and lamb ribs with bellpeppers onions and jalapeños that came with a lentil sauce, cabbage/ carrot turmeric sauce, of course about a pound of injera and this delightful herbed micro ricotta (ayub) and berbere 13.95$, 

veggie medley with bellpeppers, onions and mushrooms 9.95$ spicy and complemented the protein

ground beef sambussas 4$ for 3, similar to a wonton or jamaican meat patty with meat; with a side of delicious spicy sauce that had Turmeric and I think harissa. Definitely ordering again! 

Delish! 
We also had Ethiopian coffee which was extremely strong, like a slow drip black americano. Crack!

And the kelba, (cant wait to try at home to incorporate into smoothies) a rich yet refreshing slightly sweet blend of flaxseeds and honey.

Service was extremely friendly and warm and I believe the owner was our server. They know how to run a business. Bravo!

excerpts: We also tried the Ethiopian coffee and it was so good!
The staff were really nice.
We had a very satisfying meal.
ethiopian coffee.author: Arthita G.
ethiopian coffee.review:
We went to Tadu for dinner after watching sunset from battery spencer park. We found valet parking in a nearby garage for about 15 bucks. Street parking is available too but it's a bit challenging to find a spot. Also the neighborhood looks a little unsafe. 

Tadu is a small place and there's around 6-8 tables. We were lucky to find a spot as soon as we walked in. It's a little cramped in there but the we really enjoyed the food. We got 2 veggie combos and two sides of chicken tibs and one side of miser wot. We also tried the Ethiopian coffee and it was so good! The staff were really nice. We had a very satisfying meal.

excerpts: I started with the excellent Ethiopian coffee, to which I added ridiculously heavy-seeming cream.
ethiopian coffee.author: Lisa K.
ethiopian coffee.review:
This is a nice little oasis in the tenderloin. I started with the excellent Ethiopian coffee, to which I added ridiculously heavy-seeming cream. We had the vegetarian combo platter and the chicken tibs, which we asked to be brought out together on a big plate with injera underneath & a bountiful basket of rolled injera alongside. There was *so* much food and I thought it was pretty delicious & made for wonderful leftovers.

The biggest difference I found between Tadu & other Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've had is that it tasted a bit "fresher" and less slow-cooked/stewed. I'm not sure if this was a time issue or a stylistic one. Honestly I prefer the long-cooked method where the flavors meld together more and everything softens up, but this was good too. I found it especially noticeable in the gomen (greens) and kik alicha. Also, our alicha tikil gomen ended up being almost entirely cabbage.

excerpts: Inspired by the food, we also ordered Ethiopian coffee and spicy tea.
However, perhaps, that's where went overboard with experimenting and failed big time.
ethiopian coffee.author: Jay M.
ethiopian coffee.review:
This was our first encounter with Ethiopian cuisine and this place brings in amazing dishes which we felt in love with. 

Food:
We ordered vegetarian combo which included Alicha Tikil (potato, cabbage and carrots cooked with ginger, onions and turmeric), Misir Wot (red sipcy lentil), Gomen (collard greens) and Kik Alicha (spiced chickpeas). All this came with Injera which is East African sourdough risen flatbread. We loved almost everything. The vegetarian combo was brilliant in taste - each and every item. Injera was a bit more sour - a little less would have been better. 
Inspired by the food, we also ordered Ethiopian coffee and spicy tea. However, perhaps, that's where went overboard with experimenting and failed big time. I won't recommend the beverages but the food is amazing

Ambiance:
It's a small place, just enough to sit may be 10-12 people. Perhaps good for takeaways. Quite congested, so may be not good for large groups. However, you get to see the food made since the kitchen is right in front. Interiors are decorated with couple of pictures on African theme. 

Service: 
It was quite good and quite fast. Not sure why the owner doesn't smile (may be an off day for him when we went). 

Overall, it's a nice place. Definitely visit, in case you haven't tried Ethiopian cuisine

excerpts: I had a small cup of Ethiopian coffee which the owner gave me for free to try We also got a complementary Baklava and Spiced tea (they forgot to give us our Spice tea during our order) (a typical example of how customers are treated as a valued and appreciated "guest").
ethiopian coffee.author: Edwin L.
ethiopian coffee.review:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and fortunately it was very good.  If not, I would have been turned off to Ethiopian cuisine.  The restaurant was a bit in the shady area of San Francisco but well worth the trip. It was dotted with more of the homeless and indignant rather than gangs so I didn't feel unsafe when I went in the late afternoon daylight hours.

For the restaurant itself; small cafe style with about 6 small tables.  Clean, well kept, homey, and comfortable, nothing fancy.  It looked like about 60% of the business was take out.  Since this was my first experience with Ethiopian food, I didn't have a basis to compare the food with but I can tell you everything was fresh, flavorful, excellently prepared and unexpectedly well presented for a small cafe restaurant in the Tenderloin district. I would describe the food as tasty comfort food that you could easily develop a craving for.  Portions didn't look much when I first got it, me being a "healthy" eater but it was more than enough to fill me up.  I think the Injera bread has a lot to do with it.

A family run business and I really appreciate the friendly, caring atmosphere where customers are made to feel as a guest in their "home", a lost art with most business nowadays. 

My wife and I had the Sambussa.. Tasty with a mild spicy sauce on the side. Nicely packed, so you actually can taste the stuffing. Lamb Tibs.  Grilled tidbits with onions and spices.  This was really good having a nice seared flavor.   Vegetarian combination.  Great way to try all the different Ethiopian prepared veggies.  Each has it unique flavor, some mild, while others are a bit more spicy.  I like the spicy Misir Wot the best.  I had a small cup of Ethiopian coffee which the owner gave me for free to try We also got a complementary Baklava and Spiced tea (they forgot to give us our Spice tea during our order) (a typical example of how customers are treated as a valued and appreciated "guest").  Boy the Baklava was good too, being not overly sweet having a flaky pastry.

All and all, excellent experience and tasty food at a reasonable price.  I have now developed a comfort food craving for Ethiopian cuisine and for this establishment.  Thank you Tadu!!!

excerpts: You must try the Ethiopian coffee as well!
Injiras are soft and flavorful as well.
A total value for money!
ethiopian coffee.author: Shishir S.
ethiopian coffee.review:
One of my favorites, Tadu has never disappointed me. I have been there almost 20 times already and take anyone who visits San Francisco. Tucked away on a not so glamorous Tenderloin area, this is really a gem of a place. On some days you do have to wait as it's really a popular place and since the seating space is not much, there can be a bit of a wait, but it's always worth it.
The sambusa and the veggie combo are the best on the menu. The flavors are extremely well balanced. You must try the Ethiopian coffee as well! Injiras are soft and flavorful as well.
A total value for money!

excerpts: We finished with Ethiopian coffee.
ethiopian coffee.author: Dan D.
ethiopian coffee.review:
Wow this food is good!

My partner and I went there for a Sunday lunch. The restaurant wasn't busy at all, which was probably for the best since they only have like seven tables.

It's also located in a rough part of town. It's in the heart of the Tenderloin, so be prepared for all the sights (and smells) that entails. 

With that out of the way, the food definitely made it worth the trip! We started with beef sambussas, which were fantastic. The meat had a delightful combination of spices, and the dipping sauce they came with was also spicy and full of flavor.

For our main course, we had an order of lamb tibs and another of beef tibs, served with injera. This is essentially a platter of heavily spiced meat, served with vegetables and cheese. Injera is the Ethiopian version of a crepe. You get as much as you can eat, and you also pick up the meat with it, as there is no silverware. We both thought the lamb tasted better than the beef (each was cooked in different spices), but both were awesome. 

We finished with Ethiopian coffee. I'm not much of a coffee drinker, and I still thought it was quite good.

Overall, every single thing we ate was delicious. The prices were all super cheap, and we walked out of Tadu with our stomachs feeling thoroughly stuffed. I will definitely be back!

excerpts: I had the vegetarian combo, sambussa and some Ethiopian coffee.
ethiopian coffee.author: Debjani B.
ethiopian coffee.review:
I've never tasted Ethiopian food before so I thought I'd give it a try. This place does not disappoint!

I had the vegetarian combo, sambussa and some Ethiopian coffee. All highly recommended. 

The only word of advice I'd give is that this joint is located in the tenderloin region and is not the safest place in San Francisco. Still definitely give this place a go! Full stars on service, food and a cuisine you shouldn't miss!

excerpts: Really good Ethiopian coffee.
ethiopian coffee.author: Koalie W.
ethiopian coffee.review:
They roast their own coffee beans.  Really good Ethiopian coffee.

I enjoyed their Vege Platter.  Owner was also kind enough to allow us to split the Kitfo into a Special and Normal Kitfo.

Solid place.  I'll be back!

excerpts: They also carry Ethiopian coffee - highly recommended!
I may sound crazy
but I also highly appreciate them giving wet wipes post food, with all that finger licking chicken and spicy
ethiopian coffee.author: Nupur K.
ethiopian coffee.review:
Great food, warm staff, super cheap! 

We had Chicken tibs, Veggie combo with Injeras.. The chicken was sooo good! I can still taste it, a must must have! They also carry Ethiopian coffee - highly recommended! I may sound crazy but I also highly appreciate them giving wet wipes post food, with all that finger licking chicken and spicy lentil I needed that! 

Why 4/5 then? coz I've had better yellow lentil and cabbage.

excerpts: I suggest ordering the Ethiopian Coffee to go with your email.
ethiopian coffee.author: Jen L.
ethiopian coffee.review:
Great Ethiopian food!  

Had the ground beef with spices...and a lot of spice they have! It is pretty spicy...you might want to get some vegetarian options as well.  The vegetarian platter is a very good pick for that.  We ordered two meals and it fed 4 people.  So you can definitely eat for cheap here. 

I would suggest washing your hands before you eat, they don't do silverware.  Like classic Ethiopian food you eat with your hands by scooping up the food with the sour dough pancake stuff. 

The coffee is excellent as well.  I suggest ordering the Ethiopian Coffee to go with your email. 

Parking may be a pain....there isn't a parking lot so you may have to park out there in street possibly in the sketch area. So...plan accordingly.

excerpts: Don't forget to finish off with some Ethiopian coffee (seriously, the best coffee, and starting to be come my absolute favorite).
ethiopian coffee.author: Alyson S.
ethiopian coffee.review:
So freaaaaaaking delicious. I've only just started trying Ethiopian food, and let me just say, if you haven't tried it you're missing out. Had the chicken tibs with injera and the ritko sandwich. The ayub cheese will change your life. Don't forget to finish off with some Ethiopian coffee (seriously, the best coffee, and starting to be come my absolute favorite).

Great service and great food. Will be back again!

excerpts: Inspired by the food, we also ordered Ethiopian coffee and spicy tea.
However, perhaps, that's where went overboard with experimenting and failed big time.
spicy tea.author: Jay M.
spicy tea.review:
This was our first encounter with Ethiopian cuisine and this place brings in amazing dishes which we felt in love with. 

Food:
We ordered vegetarian combo which included Alicha Tikil (potato, cabbage and carrots cooked with ginger, onions and turmeric), Misir Wot (red sipcy lentil), Gomen (collard greens) and Kik Alicha (spiced chickpeas). All this came with Injera which is East African sourdough risen flatbread. We loved almost everything. The vegetarian combo was brilliant in taste - each and every item. Injera was a bit more sour - a little less would have been better. 
Inspired by the food, we also ordered Ethiopian coffee and spicy tea. However, perhaps, that's where went overboard with experimenting and failed big time. I won't recommend the beverages but the food is amazing

Ambiance:
It's a small place, just enough to sit may be 10-12 people. Perhaps good for takeaways. Quite congested, so may be not good for large groups. However, you get to see the food made since the kitchen is right in front. Interiors are decorated with couple of pictures on African theme. 

Service: 
It was quite good and quite fast. Not sure why the owner doesn't smile (may be an off day for him when we went). 

Overall, it's a nice place. Definitely visit, in case you haven't tried Ethiopian cuisine

excerpts: I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea.
Amazing food and very affordable.
spicy tea.author: Astrohfiziks A.
spicy tea.review:
Very very delicious. I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea. Amazing food and very affordable. My belly was very happy!

The only drawback was that my friend, when paying, didn't receive his card back. Understandable, as it was a crowded day. He realized it once we'd left the restaurant, and noted that when he went back to receive it, the staff did not apologize for the inconvenience it caused him. 

I agree with other reviewers that the service can be odd (we asked other diners who had ordered if we could have their menu after waiting for a bit and not receiving on) and that the neighborhood isn't the best. Despite these small things, I definitely plan to go back.

excerpts: Great Ethiopian food, ordered the chicken bits and the veggie combo which had 4 different types of veggie dishes and each one was awsome.also had the spicy tea which was good.
I have had Ethiopian food in various places this one is the best hands
Down..Highly recommended.
If you are walking to this place, avoid staying on Ellis road for long, its full of homeless people, walk down Leavenworth and hang a left on Ellis and its right there...
spicy tea.author: Yogesh A.
spicy tea.review: Great Ethiopian food, ordered the chicken bits and the veggie combo which had 4 different types of veggie dishes and each one was awsome.also had the spicy tea which was good.I have had Ethiopian food in various places this one is the best hands Down..Highly recommended. If you are walking to this place, avoid staying on Ellis road for long, its full of homeless people, walk down Leavenworth and hang a left on Ellis and its right there...

excerpts: Ordered the spicy tea.
I could swear I tasted honey in it.
Reminded me of the honey wine I had in another Ethiopian restaurant in Orlando.
spicy tea.author: Dushyant U.
spicy tea.review:
Would one call this mom and pop? I would call it fragrance and taste. Ordered the spicy tea. I could swear I tasted honey in it. Reminded me of the honey wine I had in another Ethiopian restaurant in Orlando. Took the vegetable platter with lamb tibs. Everything is family style and why not when everything is about family! Placed on injera with additional rolled injera to scoop everything in! The collard greens were soft and crispy. Yes, both! The lentils were mushed just right. The salad was dolloped with soft cheese. The cabbage with the potatoes and carrots had just the right dash of ginger and garlic. And wonder of wonders, the turmeric was just right! No, it did not enter into my nails! But enough! Lets go to the lamb tibs. Meat falling off the bone! The onions carmelized. A faint hint of jalapenos! The tomatoes blended in! A piece if advice to all my friends ....make sure you eat the injera the food is on... the seeping of the sauces adds to the taste! 
Major mistake..no space for desert!!

excerpts:
FOOD:
+ Sambussa ($4.00):
Stuffed with lentils or ground beef spiced with onions and peppers.
sambussa.author: Lillian Z.
sambussa.review:
If you're craving Ethiopian food, Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen is an excellent choice.

FOOD:
+ Sambussa ($4.00): Stuffed with lentils or ground beef spiced with onions and peppers. We tried the lentil sambussas (aka. samosas), and they were delicious. 

+ Tibs: Choice of beef, chicken, or lamb sautéed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, and berbere
+ Firfir: Choice of beef, lamb, or vegetarian. Small pieces of injera tossed in with the meat and Tadu's sauces

We ordered the tibs with beef and the firfir with lamb. If you've never had Ethiopian food before, you are in for a treat! There's a sink in the back where you can wash your hands, which you will want to do if you want to eat your food in a traditional Ethiopian way with your hands.

The tibs and firfir came served atop injera, a large piece of sourdough flatbread that is kind of spongy in consistency. The flavors of both were delicious. In addition to our two entrees, the injera was topped with a number of other smaller sides/dips/sauces. We were also given plenty of extra pieces of injera.

This is a pretty hefty meal, so be prepared to have leftovers! 

The ladies who work here are very sweet and helpful.

tl;dr: Yummy Ethiopian food with great service. Space is a little tight for seating, so don't go with a large group!

excerpts: Next time, I also want to order the Sambussa appetizer which everyone around us ordered and we eyed with envy.
I will say that the service was a bit odd.
We couldn't figure out if we were supposed to refill our waters or if someone would come by and refill them.
We never got any more water even though we asked.
This happens so whatever but just an odd note.
sambussa.author: Carrie W.
sambussa.review:
Tadu is absolutely worth the trek to the Tenderloin. A and I came on a random Monday night when we were craving something different and we hadn't had Ethiopian food in a while. Let's just get this out of the way now: Tadu is in a particular sketchy part of the Tenderloin. I would not be happy had we needed to wait or if it was dark out. Tadu is pretty small (5ish tables) so I can imagine that on the weekend during peak hours, you would need to wait somewhere outside of the restaurant. There aren't a lot of bars or cafes to wait in the direct vicinity so you would need to walk a bit. Luckily, we got in right away and it was still daylight but I don't see myself coming during a period where I may need to wait.

Anyways, A beat me there by a few minutes so he had some time with the menu. Once I arrived, we ordered quickly and decided to split the Vegetarian Combo ($11.95) and Special Kifto ($14.50) which we had rare at the suggestion of the employee. We had our food relatively quickly and proceeded to dig in. Everything was served on a HUGE piece of Injera with a basket of more Injera on the side. The flavoring on each of the dishes was very good and I was happy that none of the Veggie dishes were bland as I have sometimes found in my limited experience with Ethiopian food. The Special Kifto was GREAT and definitely both of our favorites. The rare ground beef kind of scared me a bit but it was delicious. The spiciness was great. We devoured our meal and were pleasantly stuffed.

The prices were definitely fair for what we got. Next time, I also want to order the Sambussa appetizer which everyone around us ordered and we eyed with envy. I will say that the service was a bit odd. We couldn't figure out if we were supposed to refill our waters or if someone would come by and refill them. We never got any more water even though we asked. This happens so whatever but just an odd note.

excerpts: We ordered Sambussa (deep-fried pastry stuffed with lentils) for our appetizer; Kitfo (ground beef sautéed with spices) and Gomen Besega (collard greens cooked with lamb).
sambussa.author: Michelle P.
sambussa.review:
Exploring the Tenderloin...post Color Purple at The Orpheum.  The spices wafting through the door convinced me and my son...we had picked a winner! 

We ordered Sambussa (deep-fried pastry stuffed with lentils) for our appetizer; Kitfo (ground beef sautéed with spices) and Gomen Besega (collard greens cooked with lamb). 

We ate family style and pinching our food with the Injera (bread similar to a crepe).  My only regret is that I didn't bring my other 2 sons so we could try more dishes.

excerpts: We split the vegetarian combo with sambussa appetizer, it was the perfect amount of food for 2 people and really reasonably priced.
sambussa.author: Kristin R.
sambussa.review: One of the best meals I've ever had! If you like Indian food you will love this place. We split the vegetarian combo with sambussa appetizer, it was the perfect amount of food for 2 people and really reasonably priced.

excerpts: Our favorite appetizer here is the Fitfit and close second is Beef sambussa.
sambussa.author: Sujeesha V.
sambussa.review:
My all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco!

This is a cute little hole-in-the-wall kinda place with colorful Ethiopian vibes. This place is located in super shady Tenderloin area of SF. So, uber. Uber. UBER (or Lyft, whatever). Crew is just Wonderful and they invite us in with a Big smile that is sooo contagious. They are very attentive and agnostic to your needs.

Our favorite appetizer here is the Fitfit and close second is Beef sambussa. Fitfit has this surprising tanginess to it that just wakes up your taste buds preparing your tongue for the awesomeness that is yet to be served in the name of main course.

Our go-to main course is the Vegetarian combination and lamb tibs. Veg combo comes with lentils, wat, collard greens and cabbage served on a big-ass injera. And more rolled up slices of injera are served in a basket to keep you going. 3 different kinds of wats are served which have a lil kick to it. I can eat just the lentils with injera all day long. Also try their Ethiopian tea with honey. Perfect compliment to the flavor profile going on in your mouth.

The spicy hot powder that is served as a side IS. THE. BOMB. Just sprinkle a lil bit on your injera before diving into the dips and you can thank me later!

Fun fact: just gotta check mark on the receipt to tip, which makes tipping a no-brainer. Ain't that awesome? :D

My Ethiopian friend vouches for this place and so do I. Try it out. You wont regret it.

excerpts: We started off with the Beef Sambussa appetizer which was perfectly crispy & very flavorful -- a must order!
If you're not quite sure what to order, the veggie combo platter is a good place to start & to that depending on how hungry you are, you can add some protein dishes.
sambussa.author: Ruby C.
sambussa.review:
I've had this spot bookmarked for the longest time since I love Ethiopian food -- glad I finally had a chance to try it!

Nice small family run restaurant with impeccable service. They checked on us multiple times to see how the food was & if we needed anything. Like all the Ethiopian restaurants I've been to (& it's honestly quite a few!), there's a sink outside the restroom since it's customary to eat with your hands. Look mom, no utensils! 

We started off with the Beef Sambussa appetizer which was perfectly crispy & very flavorful -- a must order! If you're not quite sure what to order, the veggie combo platter is a good place to start & to that depending on how hungry you are, you can add some protein dishes. For two people, a Veggie Combo Platter plus Lamb Tibs was more than enough. In fact we were stuffed silly but a good kind of full since the food was so delicious! The veggie platter came with yellow & red lentils as well as collard greens. My favorites were the lamb tibs & yellow lentils. I love the experience of eating Ethiopian food because it's very colorful & the spongy injera is the perfect way to scoop up bite sizes of deliciousness. They must've recognized my friend who is a regular since they gave us complimentary dessert.

Perfect for smaller parties. It's a small spot so if you come with a party larger than 4 you might have some difficulty finding a large enough table. They deliver via Eat24. 

Tadu, thanks for the wonderful food & great service. Looking forward to the next visit!

excerpts: We ordered the beef sambussa, veggie combo and lamb tibs.
Sambussa were flavorful and perfectly crisp.
The lamb tibs were cooked perfectly!
The njera here is really light:airy and not too sour.
sambussa.author: Semuteh F.
sambussa.review:
Excellent food and service! We had a great experience at Tadu from the moment we walked in. The space is small but we got a table for two immediately at 8:15 on a Saturday night. We ordered the beef sambussa, veggie combo and lamb tibs. Sambussa were flavorful and perfectly crisp. They also came with a really good dipping sauce (next time I'll ask them to keep that at the table for the meal--it's a great condiment).

Veggie combo and lamb were perfect. I liked the lentil wat and cabbage/potato the best. We weren't crazy about the salad in the middle. The lamb tibs were cooked perfectly! The njera here is really light:airy and not too sour. It was the perfect accompaniment!

For about $40 including tip, this is now one of our favorite places in the nabe.

excerpts: We got the vegetable combination plate, lentil sambussa, and chicken tibs
and they were all superb.
The chicken tibs was definitely a favorite of ours!
sambussa.author: Jacqui C.
sambussa.review:
I am absolutely excited to have found this place! The food is authentic with the usual traditional dishes, but they've also made some modern variations which I must come back to try.

The place itself is a small restaurant with an intimate setting of a family-run business. The staff are quick, friendly, and welcoming.

We got the vegetable combination plate, lentil sambussa, and chicken tibs and they were all superb. The chicken tibs was definitely a favorite of ours!

excerpts: We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs.
This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera.
My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs.
SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite.
Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.
sambussa.author: Crystal S.
sambussa.review: Went here for an early dinner on a Saturday prior to watching a movie. We figured this would be a perfect place as one of our group is a Vegetarian. We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs. This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera. My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs. SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite. Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.

excerpts: We had the Ground beef sambussa appetizer which was our favorite and we ended up getting a second order because we liked it so much
sambussa.author: Foodlover B.
sambussa.review:
A nice place in a shady neighborhood

We had the Ground beef sambussa appetizer which was our favorite and we ended up getting a second order because we liked it so much 

We had the tartare like ground beef and the veggie combo plate with endless amounts of the injera bread. We had to take leftovers home!

excerpts: I had the veggie combo with injera plus sambussa with lentils.
sambussa.author: Danielle H.
sambussa.review: My first time having Tadu. A bit on the spicy side for my taste pallet BUT flavorful and satisfying nonetheless. I would recommend! I had the veggie combo with injera plus sambussa with lentils.

excerpts: I ordered beef sambussa for an appetizer and the vegetable combo with lamb tibs for my entree, which could have served 2-3 people.
Wish I could have brought my leftovers back home with me
but unfortunately I had to head straight to the airport afterwards for a flight.
The beef sambussa came with a spicy sauce and was piping hot and delicious.
It was a bit on the greasy side, but extremely yummy.
The vegetable combo and lamb tibs was presented on an unfurled piece of injera, which is a spongey sort of flatbread.
The first thing I thought of when I looked at it was my slight case of "trypophobia
" (don't look it up on Google if you're uncomfortable with images of clustered, small holes)...but the subtle taste and texture was amazing.
There was also a side of extra rolled up injera for you to eat the wat (Ethiopian stew that has a similar consistency to hummus).
I personally LOVED the types of wat I got -
they were so flavorful and some of them definitely had a kick to them.
The lamb tibs were also quite yummy
sambussa.author: Katherine Z.
sambussa.review:
My first time trying Ethiopian food and Tadu did not disappoint! I ordered beef sambussa for an appetizer and the vegetable combo with lamb tibs for my entree, which could have served 2-3 people. Wish I could have brought my leftovers back home with me but unfortunately I had to head straight to the airport afterwards for a flight. The beef sambussa came with a spicy sauce and was piping hot and delicious. It was a bit on the greasy side, but extremely yummy. The vegetable combo and lamb tibs was presented on an unfurled piece of injera, which is a spongey sort of flatbread. The first thing I thought of when I looked at it was my slight case of "trypophobia" (don't look it up on Google if you're uncomfortable with images of clustered, small holes)...but the subtle taste and texture was amazing. There was also a side of extra rolled up injera for you to eat the wat (Ethiopian stew that has a similar consistency to hummus). I personally LOVED the types of wat I got - they were so flavorful and some of them definitely had a kick to them.  The lamb tibs were also quite yummy and I loved the smokiness to them. 

Ambience-wise, the place is quite colorful and cute. It's very small and probably only seats less than 20 people. The food comes out very quickly. One slight detraction to the restaurant is its location in Tenderloin, a neighborhood that slightly gives me the heebie-jeebies as a young woman by myself. As I did not feel comfortable walking in the area, I simply Ubered to and from the restaurant - no big deal. The food definitely makes this place worth it! And the service was awesome. Check it out!

excerpts: My wife and I had the Sambussa..
Tasty with a mild spicy sauce on the side.
Nicely packed, so you actually can taste the stuffing.
sambussa.author: Edwin L.
sambussa.review:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and fortunately it was very good.  If not, I would have been turned off to Ethiopian cuisine.  The restaurant was a bit in the shady area of San Francisco but well worth the trip. It was dotted with more of the homeless and indignant rather than gangs so I didn't feel unsafe when I went in the late afternoon daylight hours.

For the restaurant itself; small cafe style with about 6 small tables.  Clean, well kept, homey, and comfortable, nothing fancy.  It looked like about 60% of the business was take out.  Since this was my first experience with Ethiopian food, I didn't have a basis to compare the food with but I can tell you everything was fresh, flavorful, excellently prepared and unexpectedly well presented for a small cafe restaurant in the Tenderloin district. I would describe the food as tasty comfort food that you could easily develop a craving for.  Portions didn't look much when I first got it, me being a "healthy" eater but it was more than enough to fill me up.  I think the Injera bread has a lot to do with it.

A family run business and I really appreciate the friendly, caring atmosphere where customers are made to feel as a guest in their "home", a lost art with most business nowadays. 

My wife and I had the Sambussa.. Tasty with a mild spicy sauce on the side. Nicely packed, so you actually can taste the stuffing. Lamb Tibs.  Grilled tidbits with onions and spices.  This was really good having a nice seared flavor.   Vegetarian combination.  Great way to try all the different Ethiopian prepared veggies.  Each has it unique flavor, some mild, while others are a bit more spicy.  I like the spicy Misir Wot the best.  I had a small cup of Ethiopian coffee which the owner gave me for free to try We also got a complementary Baklava and Spiced tea (they forgot to give us our Spice tea during our order) (a typical example of how customers are treated as a valued and appreciated "guest").  Boy the Baklava was good too, being not overly sweet having a flaky pastry.

All and all, excellent experience and tasty food at a reasonable price.  I have now developed a comfort food craving for Ethiopian cuisine and for this establishment.  Thank you Tadu!!!

excerpts: I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea.
Amazing food and very affordable.
sambussa.author: Astrohfiziks A.
sambussa.review:
Very very delicious. I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea. Amazing food and very affordable. My belly was very happy!

The only drawback was that my friend, when paying, didn't receive his card back. Understandable, as it was a crowded day. He realized it once we'd left the restaurant, and noted that when he went back to receive it, the staff did not apologize for the inconvenience it caused him. 

I agree with other reviewers that the service can be odd (we asked other diners who had ordered if we could have their menu after waiting for a bit and not receiving on) and that the neighborhood isn't the best. Despite these small things, I definitely plan to go back.

excerpts:
SAMBUSSA ($4) - 5/5
Comes with 3.
Kind of like samosas,
but the dough is thinner, airier, flakier and crispier, and the inside is filled with ground beef or lentils.
We got the ground beef, which was amazing!
sambussa.author: Jessie L.
sambussa.review:
TLDR: flavorful Ethiopian food, large portions, very reasonable prices; definitely recommend for a different dining experience

I've seen Tadu listed as one of the "Best of Yelp" Restaurants for many weeks now (maybe since its opening?). I've yet to see a place maintain a 5-star rating for so long and with 100+ reviews, so of course it made my bookmarks list. Honestly, if fellow Yelper Ben K. hadn't suggested it for dinner, I don't know if I would've ever made it here since I don't like to frequent the TL.

The restaurant is a small hole-in-the wall with maybe 5-6 tables and probably has the capacity for only 15ish people. In contrast to the surrounding TL, the inside is pretty nice and clean. The place wasn't busy yet at around 6pm on a Friday, but it filled up pretty easily and there were people waiting by the time we left.

Anyone unfamiliar with Ethiopian food (like me) might be a little lost with the menu, not because there are too many options, but because everything sounds more or less the same. The menu has a few appetizers and several veggie and meat entrees, which all come with injera, a spongy sourdough crepe. I'd recommend the SAMBUSSAS as a starter and LAMB TIBS as an entree. And you can't go wrong with the VEGETARIAN COMBO, which will give you sampling of almost all the veggie entrees. The food overall was pretty tasty and I really enjoyed anything cooked with berbere (some sort of chili/spice).

For anyone who hasn't had Ethiopian food, there are no utensils (unless asked for). You basically break off pieces of injera and use it to pick up the meat/veggies or dip it in the more hummus-like veggie dishes.

Entrees range from $10-15 and portion sizes are big and filling, especially with the unlimited injera. One entree can easily feed you for 2 meals, so it's definitely worth the price. Being the fatass that I am sometimes though, I ended up eating much more than I should have..

Service is pretty good here. Our server (who I think may have been the owner) checked in on us a few times to ask how the food was and to see if we needed more injera or water.

===========

SAMBUSSA ($4) - 5/5
Comes with 3. Kind of like samosas, but the dough is thinner, airier, flakier and crispier, and the inside is filled with ground beef or lentils. We got the ground beef, which was amazing! A little bit of spice and so much flavor

LAMB TIBS ($14) - 4/5
[sautéed in spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, berbere]
Juicy and delicious! The jalapeños and berbere give it a good kick, but more heat would've been even better. The dish was on the greasy side for me but tasted so good that the greasiness couldn't stop me from eating more of it

VEGETARIAN COMBINATION ($12) - 4/5
We ordered the vegetarian banatu/firfir, but I'm pretty sure they gave us the veggie combo now that I'm looking back at my picture. The vegetarian firfir is supposed to be vegetables and pieces of injera in berbere but we definitely did not get that on our plate. The veggie combo didn't disappoint though and was a really good sampler of many of their veggie entrees

     -MISIR WOT - 4.5/5
     [split lentil sauce made w/ berbere, onions, ginger, garlic]
     Orange/red and similar in texture to a thick tomato sauce. A little bit spicy from the berbere, which I loved. Definitely one of my favorite veggie options
     
     -ALICHA TIKIL GOMEN - 4.5/5
     [cabbage, potatoes & carrots]
     Another favorite from the combo. Not as flavorful as the misir wot but I like that it actually has veggies in it

     -GOMEN - 3.5/5
     [collard greens]
     A little bitter but still pretty good

     -KIK ALICHA WOT - 3/5
     [chickpea cooked w/ spicy tumeric, ginger & garlic]
     Yellow and a little thicker than hummus in texture. Not bad but didn't impress me

     -BUTICHA - 3/5
     [ground chickpeas, peppers & onions]
     Reminded me of a potato salad in taste and mashed potatoes in texture. I actually liked the flavor but it felt pretty rich and heavy so I could only eat a few bites

     -AZIFA - 3/5
     [lentils sauteed w/ onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds & lemon]
     Served cold. Also kind of rich/heavy

VEGGIE MEDLEY ($10) - 4/5
[mushrooms stir fried w/ peppers, jalapeno & berbere]
Solid. Not super special and pretty greasy, but very flavorful

KITFO ($13.50) - 3.5/5
Flavorful lean ground beef, cooked to a nice medium rare. I liked it a lot at first but wasn't really a fan of the half raw ground texture after a bit

INJERA (complimentary)
The entrees are served on a giant piece of injera. I've only had Ethiopian once before and didn't like the injera much because of the acidity, but was pleased with the injera here. Theirs was soft, spongy and tasted like sourdough without being too acidic. I don't really like sourdough in general so I wouldn't eat the injera on its own, but it works well with the entrees and soaks up the juices of the lamb very well

excerpts: We also ordered the Beef Sambussa as an appetizer.
sambussa.author: Sherry L.
sambussa.review:
I love Ethiopian food but a good place is hard to find. My friend and I were seriously craving some the other afternoon, but the one in the Mission doesn't open until dinnertime. So we found Tadu in the TL, which has 5 stars. And it really lived up to its rating! There are only a few tables inside so when its busy, I can see why there would be a wait. There aren't that many items on the menu, but everything on it is delicious.

I highly recommend the lamb tibs. It's made fresh to order and is absolutely delicious. The onions are perfectly caramelized and the seasoning of spices and salt is perfect. So yummy!

We ordered the full size of the Alicha but they accidentally gave us the veggie combo, which is fine. The veggie combo was great. We loved the cabbage, lentils, and chickpeas. I also liked the salad a lot too. The collard greens were good too.

We also ordered the Beef Sambussa as an appetizer. There were only 3 but the filling was spicy and yummy.

Next time, I really want to try the eggplant (which they didn't have a half size of) and some of the other meat dishes. The pictures look awesome!

excerpts: We got the Sambussa starter which came with three pieces of fried flakey dough stuffed with ground beef and onions.
sambussa.author: Adrienne H.
sambussa.review:
I've only had Ethiopian in San Jose (Zeni), and Tadu wasn't quite at that level, but it still hit the spot. Bonus points for curing a terrible case of post crappy $40 hotel breakfast buffet hangry-ness.

We got the Sambussa starter which came with three pieces of fried flakey dough stuffed with ground beef and onions. Tadu's version is extra crispy, the filling is seasoned well, and the tomato dipping sauce was fantastic.

At the recommendation of our server, we chose the Lamb Tibs in addition to the Vegetarian Combo. The Lambs Tibs were juicy, but could have used some more seasoning. In the veg combo, I enjoyed the Misir Wot (red lentils with Berbere spice) the most. I also liked the buticha, which the server compared to hummus. It was made from chickpeas but much thicker than hummus, and reminded me of potato salad.

The Injera bread was not as sour or fluffy as I prefer, but that didn't stop me from eating an entire basket anyway. Injera is my weakness. There's something about the act of scooping up food with bread that I absolutely enjoy. Service was attentive and kind as well. Tadu is worth braving the sketch area for!

excerpts: In the meantime, who wouldn't want to start with an Ethiopian empanada called Sambussa, where you get three large, deep-fried turnover-like creations filled with lentil beans, onions and peppers?
A trio for $4 struck me as a good deal, and it was, especially with a huge ramekin of a light marinara-like tomato sauce for dipping (photo:
http://bit.ly/1EST1vN).
sambussa.author: Ed U.
sambussa.review:
Another treasure hunt led me to this compact Ethiopian spot deep in the 'Loin. Again a waft of positive Yelp reviews gave me the courage to gird my loins after dark and find my way to Ellis between Leavenworth and Jones where this cafe resides. Even though it was just past 8PM by the time I arrived, it was nearly full up with diners who didn't look like they were going anywhere soon. Luckily by the time I ordered at the counter, the front table opened up. I asked the woman at the register what she recommended since I was unfamiliar with everything on the menu except kitfo and injera (photo: http://bit.ly/1Dt2tGn). Kitfo is a bit like Hamburger Helper, Ethiopian style, which is not a bad thing but probably more meat-heavy than I had in mind for an entree.

In the meantime, who wouldn't want to start with an Ethiopian empanada called Sambussa, where you get three large, deep-fried turnover-like creations filled with lentil beans, onions and peppers? A trio for $4 struck me as a good deal, and it was, especially with a huge ramekin of a light marinara-like tomato sauce for dipping (photo: http://bit.ly/1EST1vN). For my entree, I decided on the $12.50 Gomen Besega, a house specialty that takes a huge round of injera, the spongy native bread of Ethiopia, and then covers it with cooked collard greens mixed with bits of minced lamb, garlic and onion. There was a thicker version of the tomato sauce on the side, which I think mixed in mashed lentil beans, as well as a fresh salad (photo: http://bit.ly/1ESSTfG).

On top of this generous portion came a basket of rolled injera which they served like bottomless mimosas (photo: http://bit.ly/1FwgaE4). By the time I depleted half of it, more injera came out as if it somehow multiplied in the kitchen. No matter since I happen to be a fan, and this one had a less vinegary taste than I've had at other Ethiopian spots. I was full by the time I was halfway through my entree, so I asked for a box which they happily provided. The owner came by to see if I enjoyed the food, and he shared with me his story about being a cabbie who dreamed of opening a place where he could serve his grandmother's recipes. Mission accomplished as the food has a very home-style flavor to it that tempers the exotic aspects of the cuisine. I plan to come back in the daytime when I can more freely walk there.

FOOD - 4 stars...home-style Ethiopian with the most flavorful injera in town (sorry Moya!)
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a bit tight in space but the interior is brightly lit and clean
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quite friendly and accommodating
TOTAL - 4 stars...if you're in the mood for Ethiopian, this is no Tenderloin trap

excerpts: We started with the sambussa - a flaky pastry filled with meat or veggies - which was delicious.
sambussa.author: Wendy L.
sambussa.review:
Tadu is an incredibly tiny restaurant with 5-6 small tables. We went on a weekday evening and it was relatively empty....but with the positive reviews, we weren't sure how long the wait would be so we called ahead for a reservation! They were confused but obliged!

We started with the sambussa - a flaky pastry filled with meat or veggies - which was delicious. As our entree, we shared the veggie platter with lamb tibs. I love tibs! And these lamb tibs are great, especially with the deliciously sour injera.

excerpts: I had the vegetarian combo, sambussa and some Ethiopian coffee.
sambussa.author: Debjani B.
sambussa.review:
I've never tasted Ethiopian food before so I thought I'd give it a try. This place does not disappoint!

I had the vegetarian combo, sambussa and some Ethiopian coffee. All highly recommended. 

The only word of advice I'd give is that this joint is located in the tenderloin region and is not the safest place in San Francisco. Still definitely give this place a go! Full stars on service, food and a cuisine you shouldn't miss!

excerpts: We ordered the Sambussa, and multiple veggie combos.
The Sambussa with lentils was ok.
I definitely wouldn't order it again.
The injeera was great, but the rest of the veggie platter was also just "ok".
There isn't a punch of flavor, and the seasoning wasn't well-balanced.
sambussa.author: Dimple B.
sambussa.review:
The restaurant is small, but nice. It's clean and not overcrowded, but is very busy. The service was great, except that one of the drinks came out after we'd finished the meal. But he apologized for it and explained that it took a bit longer to make. 

We ordered the Sambussa, and multiple veggie combos. The Sambussa with lentils was ok. I definitely wouldn't order it again. The injeera was great, but the rest of the veggie platter was also just "ok". There isn't a punch of flavor, and the seasoning wasn't well-balanced. There was far too much tumeric, not cooked properly, and a few of us walked away with yellow nails. 

It wasn't a bad dish, but we also made sure not to end the night on the taste from Tadu. Based on location, convenience, and food, my next craving for Ethiopian will be satisfied by Sheba.

excerpts: We got the veggie combo, LENTIL SAMBUSSA (SOO GOOD) and beef tibs for 2 people.
It was wayy plenty of food.
And for a great price :D if you call like 15 mins early, they can try to hold you a table which would probably be worth the effort
cuz its a verryy cozy place, only like 5 or 6 tables and no space to wait for a table to free up inside
so you might have to wait outside in the grimey TL streets which is known to rob you of your appetite.
sambussa.author: Sara C.
sambussa.review: The food is delicious, super friendly staff & great service, and the portions were such that I had a full lunch off the leftovers! We got the veggie combo, LENTIL SAMBUSSA (SOO GOOD) and beef tibs for 2 people. It was wayy plenty of food. And for a great price :D if you call like 15 mins early, they can try to hold you a table which would probably be worth the effort cuz its a verryy cozy place, only like 5 or 6 tables and no space to wait for a table to free up inside so you might have to wait outside in the grimey TL streets which is known to rob you of your appetite.

excerpts: The owner offered us for free the beef sambussa appetizer as we waited which was very nice of him and didn't hurt that it tasted great.
sambussa.author: Victor W.
sambussa.review:
Good Ethiopian food at good prices and good service - not much more to ask for (maybe nicer location?). It's cozy and clearly owner operated day to day with that small business charm.

We just missed getting an available table when we walked in and had to wait 20 or so minutes but it was worth it. The owner offered us for free the beef sambussa appetizer as we waited which was very nice of him and didn't hurt that it tasted great.

As its Ethiopian food, you order items that are placed on a communal thin sponge like bread that has a little sourdough tang to it. We got the lamb ribs and vegetarian combo. Both were great and more than enough to fill the two of us.

The Telba drink was also great. It's flaxseed and honey and ends up tasting like a sweet healthy breakfast.

excerpts: We initially ordered one Sambussa, but later ordered 4 more.
It's awesome.
I ordered one vegetarian combo.
It's good.
sambussa.author: Ashwin Kumar N.
sambussa.review:
Nice and healthy food. Have vegan/vegetarian options. We initially ordered one Sambussa, but later ordered 4 more. It's awesome. I ordered one vegetarian combo. It's good. My friends ordered one chicken and lamb tibs. There ordered it again for second time. It's great.

One note: all the food includes salad, so don't order salad separately.

excerpts: For starters, we got the Sambussa, which feels a bit like Ethiopian empanadas--meat filling inside a flaky pastry dough.
sambussa.author: Chrystal Z.
sambussa.review:
Can NOT stop raving about this place to everyone! Tadu was my first experience with Ethiopian food, and it was everything I had hoped it would be, and more. Robust and strong flavors, distinct and varied textures and ingredients, and such an experience. It sets the bar high for future chances I'll have to eat Ethiopian food.

For starters, we got the Sambussa, which feels a bit like Ethiopian empanadas--meat filling inside a flaky pastry dough. Delicious.

Mains included the veggie combo, the Kitfo (beef, medium rare), and the lamb tibs. Everything was amazing; the kitfo and the lamb tibs were my favorite, thought they taste completely different from one another. We ordered 3 things for three people and we were so stuffed at the end of our meal. Even though portions may not look formidable, you'll fill up pretty quickly. I suspect this is because you eat everything with a bit of their tasty injera bread.

The service is warm, friendly, and super attentive, as I've come to expect from authentic, family-run restaurants. Can't wait to make a return trip :)

excerpts: Sambussa was great.
Lamb tips and injera and the veggie combo was just made to perfection.
sambussa.author: Hussam S.
sambussa.review:
12/30/2015

This place gave me another appreciation and renewed love for Ethiopian food. 

Great ownership! Sambussa was great. Lamb tips and injera and the veggie combo was just made to perfection.

excerpts: And to start, we got the delicious ground beef sambussa.
Super fast oto!
sambussa.author: Al W.
sambussa.review: This place was awesome.  A tiny hole in the wall, with the friendliest servers.  The food was phenomenal.  We had the lamb tibs and vegetarian combo platter, perfect for 2 to share.  And to start, we got the delicious ground beef sambussa.  Super fast oto!

excerpts: I got Vegan Combo + Special Kitfo, Lamb and Beef Libs, and Sambussa.
This meal was enough for four to five people.
By the way, Injera has a little sour.
Overall, five stars food.
sambussa.author: Charles Z.
sambussa.review: A bit crowded restaurant but it's acceptable. Food is great. I got Vegan Combo + Special Kitfo, Lamb and Beef Libs, and Sambussa. This meal was enough for four to five people. By the way, Injera has a little sour. Overall, five stars food.

excerpts: I ordered the Sambussa with beef appetizer, Lamb Tibs with Injera as the entrée, and Telba as a drink.
The Sambussa is a crunchy, fried, meaty ball of deliciousness, kind of like a samosa (wait, is it a samosa?).
The Lamb tibs is very delicious, served over a layer of Injera, with vegetables and tomatoes that give it a nice acidic flavor to the umami lamb.
I recommend mixing everything together and use the Injera to grab the mixture, shove it in your mouth and lick your fingers.
DO NOT TOUCH YOUR EYES!!!
IT IS
VERY FUCKING
SPICY!!!
Luckily for you, their sink is right outside their bathroom, so you can quickly wash your hands, blow your nose, and get right back to eating.
sambussa.author: Alan L.
sambussa.review:
Amazing food, great customer service.
Their waiter/cashier, Caleb has a nice, warm friendly smile and personality.
The menu with photos and pricing is on their website.

I ordered the Sambussa with beef appetizer, Lamb Tibs with Injera as the entrée, and Telba as a drink. 

The Sambussa is a crunchy, fried, meaty ball of deliciousness, kind of like a samosa (wait, is it a samosa?). They give you 3 nice triangles with a nice sauce to go with it (I wish they'd give more sauce, because it was very flavorful, lots of spices). 

The Lamb tibs is very delicious, served over a layer of Injera, with vegetables and tomatoes that give it a nice acidic flavor to the umami lamb. I recommend mixing everything together and use the Injera to grab the mixture, shove it in your mouth and lick your fingers. DO NOT TOUCH YOUR EYES!!! IT IS VERY FUCKING SPICY!!! 
Luckily for you, their sink is right outside their bathroom, so you can quickly wash your hands, blow your nose, and get right back to eating. Umm, on that note, be wary bringing a first time date here. 

I highly highly recommend ordering Telba, if you are ordering anything else, Telba is always the perfect compliment! Caleb, the super nice, friendly Ethiopian dude gave me some small sample of Telba and it was like sucking on the tit of Goddess (cause it comes with a straw). It tastes rather creamy with the texture of a basil seed drink and the flavor of a grounded cereal mix. I highly highly recommend ordering it, because it will help cool you down by counteracting the incredibly spicy food.

A couple of warnings: the food is very spicy, so don't touch your face. There are no utensils unless you ask (but please, just use your hands), and there is no parking, take the bus. 

Peace and godspeed.

excerpts: We got the veggie combo and sambussa with lentil and it satisfied us both.
We order some food to go too.
Definitely will be back
sambussa.author: Sophia K.
sambussa.review: The food was excellent. We got the veggie combo and sambussa with lentil and it satisfied us both. We order some food to go too. Definitely will be back

excerpts:
We had the beef sambussa to start, and the lamb and beef tibs with injera as entrees. 
The sambussa was a dumpling-like appetizer, with juicy, slightly spicy ground beef wrapped in a perfectly crunchy and flaky shell of dough, and accompanied with a orange dipping sauce which added a ton of seasoning without overpowering the taste of the wrapping or the beef.
sambussa.author: Caleb W.
sambussa.review:
I came here on a Monday evening around 8pm with a few friends. While seating is rather sparse, especially for groups larger than two, plenty of seats were available when we walked in.

We had the beef sambussa to start, and the lamb and beef tibs with injera as entrees. 
The sambussa was a dumpling-like appetizer, with juicy, slightly spicy ground beef wrapped in a perfectly crunchy and flaky shell of dough, and accompanied with a orange dipping sauce which added a ton of seasoning without overpowering the taste of the wrapping or the beef. 

The injera was just as it should be, soft and spongy, without being overpowering or too sour. I absolutely recommend the lamb tibs -- tender lamb cubes sautéed with the most delicious caramelized onions, and seasoned heavily with black pepper and not much else. While not readily apparently after the first few bites, the lamb tibs are actually low-key spicy, and will definitely warm you up after a while. 

It's not the best Ethiopian food I've ever had, but it's definitely up there.

excerpts: The Sambussa appetizer with beef is also good.
sambussa.author: Marc P.
sambussa.review: This is very good Ethiopian food and the staff is very friendly and accommodating. The beef Tibs has great flavor and is a safe bet for anyone who has never eaten Ethiopian food before. The Sambussa appetizer with beef is also good.

excerpts: For an appetizer we had the lentil sambussa which was so moist and delicious.
sambussa.author: Brianna M.
sambussa.review: Best food Ethiopian food I have ever had. Went tonight with two of my friends. The waiter was extremely helpful and so very nice. For an appetizer we had the lentil sambussa which was so moist and delicious. For dinner I had the lamb tibs, one friend had the special kitfo and my other friend has the vegetarian combination. We all thought it was absolutely delicious. Then for dessert we had the baklava. Probably the best that I have ever had. Will definitely go back. Thank you Tadu!

excerpts: Had ground beef sambussa for appetizers.
sambussa.author: Hua T.
sambussa.review: Rainy Friday, decided to try other non typical food out there. Ethiopian food came to mind and found this new cosy place. Really liked the atmosphere here. Friendly staff and great service. It was a quiet night. They kept on coming to our table to check if we were happy with everything. Had ground beef sambussa for appetizers. Then we ordered lamp and beef tibs. For beginner you eat with your hands. No utensils if you wanna do it right. Love the flavors and spices they use, bring back memories of my travel to Africa. Interesting sponge bread made of teff flour (wheat) used to wrap the meat and veggies. The pepper powder is super spicy! Be careful a dash can set you on fire and make you go running for more water. I would definitely come back and try more dishes. The food is not something I eat everyday. I'm glad that I found this new gem for Ethiopian cuisine.

excerpts: Four of us shared the vegetarian combo, sambussa, and buticha salad and extra injera
it was so good!!!!
Lots of verity and helpful staff.
Good prices and lots of food!
Very clean facility including the bathroom
sambussa.author: Jessica S.
sambussa.review: Wonderful traditional Ethiopian food!!! Four of us shared the vegetarian combo, sambussa, and buticha salad and extra injera it was so good!!!! Lots of verity and helpful staff. Good prices and lots of food! Very clean facility including the bathroom

excerpts: Tried the lentil Sambussa appetizer and it was GREAT!
definitely get the veggie combo if you want a true mix of Ethiopian flavor.
Additionally, the Kitfo is fantastic!
The mix of spices and flavors are perfect.
sambussa.author: Danielle J.
sambussa.review: Tried the lentil Sambussa appetizer and it was GREAT! definitely get the veggie combo if you want a true mix of Ethiopian flavor. Additionally, the Kitfo is fantastic! The mix of spices and flavors are perfect.

excerpts: My Sambussa was delicious!!!
sambussa.author: Sharmi D.
sambussa.review: Very busy with very limited seating, therefore ordered to go. Food was delicious and spicy. Both cook and girl taking the order were very nice. Only thing I wish was they had photos of the food so I could have an idea what I was ordering. My Sambussa was delicious!!!

excerpts: I love Sambussa, Misir Wot and The Vegetable Melody.
sambussa.author: Iguanatte S.
sambussa.review:
All food are soooooo delicious and their service is great!!!
I love Sambussa, Misir Wot and The Vegetable Melody.

I come here two or three times a month:))

excerpts: The lentil sambussa were out of this world.
The vegetarian platter was fantastic.
The injera was so soft and so delicious.
Wait staff were super friendly.
And the prices were more than reasonable.
I wish I could take this restaurant home with me...
sambussa.author: Katy K.
sambussa.review: I love Ethiopian food and thought nothing could top what I'd gotten in Italy (which of course has a legacy of colonialism of Ethiopia), but this place is fantastic! I honestly didn't expect much since it's a small restaurant with a small menu in a sketchyish area of town, but hooooly. The lentil sambussa were out of this world. The vegetarian platter was fantastic. The injera was so soft and so delicious. Wait staff were super friendly. And the prices were more than reasonable. I wish I could take this restaurant home with me...

excerpts: We ordered the veggie combination, sambussa and a side of Shero.
More than enough food for three.
Nice variety of flavor as and spices.
The staff was super friendly and proudly described the ingredients and how the food was prepared.
Probably the best value in San Francisco we've encountered.
We will be back!
sambussa.author: C S.
sambussa.review: Our first experience with Ethiopian cuisine and it was a hit!  Tasty variety of vegetarian dishes. We ordered the veggie combination, sambussa and a side of Shero. More than enough food for three. Nice variety of flavor as and spices. The staff was super friendly and proudly described the ingredients and how the food was prepared. Probably the best value in San Francisco we've encountered. We will be back!

excerpts: I got the veggie combo and sambussa.
The two workers were so nice and willing to explain and make sure i got what i wanted.
I will definitely be back.
sambussa.author: ariana v.
sambussa.review: This place was so good. I got the veggie combo and sambussa. The two workers were so nice and willing to explain and make sure i got what i wanted. I will definitely be back.

excerpts: We also had the sambussa for an appetizer and that was delicious as well.
sambussa.author: Wilson W.
sambussa.review:
Fantastic food. The server recommended the veggie combo, the lamb tibs, and ground beef something. It was well presented on a huge platter with their sourdough flatbread, which is a mix between a pancake and a crepe, and you can wrap and dip it as you wish. 

The taste was delicious, the dipping sauces and the meat combined very well. We also had the sambussa for an appetizer and that was delicious as well. Everything is very fresh here. 

Finally, there are only 8 or so small tables (for 1-2 people) inside the restaurant, so either go early or order takeout!

excerpts: The first thing I had was the sambussa.
I live meat so ate the meat ones.
My partner ( carnivore that he is) loved the lentil sambussa.
It is a flavor party in your mouth!
The sauce , the meat, the flaky pastry !!!
So good!
I always burn my mouth because I can't wait for them to cool down
and they are made to order
so they come out piping hot!
I take my coworkers as often as I can because one the place is yummy
and two I would hate to loose this gem because people ate too scared to try something new.
I ordered the Kitfo and didn't quite tell folks that its essentially raw beef and they just loved it!
My usual order is chicken tibs , beef do wat, sambussa , and the salad and the vegetarian platter( I share with my coworkers)
I am going to try the lamb next
and I bet it's as good as the rest.
My only complaint is that I think they calm the spiciness of down for the wimpy American palates.
I will ask for really spicy tibs next time.
sambussa.author: PeachBrande B.
sambussa.review:
I love Ethiopian food. Where else can you eat with your hands, make a mess, and generally gorge yourself ? There are a lot of Ethiopian places around but not in my neck of the woods. I work in the Tenderloin and I am often left to walk far to get something to eat on my lunch. I waited with baited breath for this place to open. I would look at it on my way to work which is literally 2 minutes away. The first thing I had was the sambussa. I live meat so ate the meat ones. My partner ( carnivore that he is) loved the lentil sambussa. It is a flavor party in your mouth! The sauce , the meat, the flaky pastry !!! So good! I always burn my mouth because I can't wait for them to cool down and they are made to order so they come out piping hot! 
I take my coworkers as often as I can because one the place is yummy and two I would hate to loose this gem because people ate too scared to try something new. I ordered the Kitfo and didn't quite tell folks that its essentially raw beef and they just loved it! The chicken tibs are yummy and so is the beef tibs. Now the chickpea salad appetizer is a must get. It was fresh and delicious and we were fighting over the last bit. My usual order is chicken tibs , beef do wat, sambussa , and the salad and the vegetarian platter( I share with my coworkers)  I am going to try the lamb next and I bet it's as good as the rest. My only complaint is that I think they calm the spiciness of down for the wimpy American palates. I will ask for really spicy tibs next time. 
All in all the flavor is nice , the people who work there are very kind , and I could eat here everyday if budget would allow it! 

Mmmmmmm I just made myself hungry! I know where I'll be eating Monday for lunch

excerpts: The sambussa was my favorite item.
We also had the beef kitfo - medium rare, as well as one of the vegetarian sides.
Seating is limited, but it was late and we ordered take out.
And being only 2 blocks from our apartment, we will definitely be returning soon to try out more!
sambussa.author: Jennifer F.
sambussa.review: This was our first time trying out Ethiopian food. And we LOVED it! The sambussa was my favorite item. We also had the beef kitfo - medium rare, as well as one of the vegetarian sides. Seating is limited, but it was late and we ordered take out. And being only 2 blocks from our apartment, we will definitely be returning soon to try out more!

excerpts: The sambussa appetizers were a crisp start.
sambussa.author: Joe H.
sambussa.review: We came over from Houston to see the SF sites and ran across Tadu on our bus tour. A small, traditional restaurant with about 8 tables, it has family-style Ethiopian dining where the entrees are served on a big round piece of injera bread. We were treated to personal service by Elias, the owner, himself. We love Ethiopian flavors, and nothing disappointed here. The sambussa appetizers were a crisp start. The lamb and chicken tibs were delicious, and the beef wot dish was a great new flavor we hadn't tried yet. Elias brought us a couple of other flavors just to enhance our experience; a chick pea puree and another chicken dish I can't pronounce. All were fantastic. We finished off with baklava for dessert. We left my wife's yellow rose at the table, and Elias brought it all the way down the street to us himself. God bless you!

excerpts: Get the beef sambussa, beef tibs, and the vegetarian combo.
Generously feeds 2 people.
sambussa.author: Adam E.
sambussa.review: Excellent. Get the beef sambussa, beef tibs, and the vegetarian combo. Generously feeds 2 people.

excerpts: We had Lentil Sambussa (tasty straightforward snack and the accompanying red sauce was great) and Beef Tibs with Injera (simple ingredients and great mix of spices do the trick perfectly
and Injera is to die for).
Servings are generous, one appetizer and one entree easily fed two adults.
Highly recommended, don't get scared by a shabby neighbourhood.
sambussa.author: Grzegorz J.
sambussa.review: This place has a modest menu, but is genuine, clean and the food is great. We had Lentil Sambussa (tasty straightforward snack and the accompanying red sauce was great) and Beef Tibs with Injera (simple ingredients and great mix of spices do the trick perfectly and Injera is to die for). Servings are generous, one appetizer and one entree easily fed two adults. Highly recommended, don't get scared by a shabby neighbourhood.

excerpts: We started our lunch with the Sambussa/beef appetizer; followed with the Lamb Tibs and the Lamb Alicha Banatu.
Service is excellent, friendly, and helpful.
Food is excellent; prepared with care and delicious with distinctive flavors and textures.
I would be happy to indulge my appetite with every dish on this menu.
I will return for more of this wonderful cuisine.
sambussa.author: Geri S.
sambussa.review: We started our lunch with the Sambussa/beef appetizer; followed with the Lamb Tibs and the Lamb Alicha Banatu.  Service is excellent, friendly, and helpful.  Food is excellent; prepared with care and delicious with distinctive flavors and textures.  I would be happy to indulge my appetite with every dish on this menu.  I will return for more of this wonderful cuisine.

excerpts: To our surprise, he brought out complimentary sambussa to compensate for the wait.
It was a kind gesture and delicious too!
Within minutes, the fourth plate came out and we began digging in.
The meat was so well-seasoned and cooked that we all fell in love.
The salad and dressing that came with it gave it so much flavor and refreshed our palate.
In that moment, we knew we made the right choice coming here.
sambussa.author: Jenny N.
sambussa.review: Prior to Tadu, I have never had Ethiopian food before. After spontaneously looking for a place to eat lunch, my friends and I noticed this place we were eager to try it out. The place is small, but cozy (nice to escape the cold SF weather). The gentleman at the front was very welcoming and friendly. He helped us out by recommending tibs, so we ordered chicken, beef, and lamb tibs all with injera. The first three plates came out before 10 minutes and he noticed that the fourth hadn't come out yet. To our surprise, he brought out complimentary sambussa to compensate for the wait. It was a kind gesture and delicious too! Within minutes, the fourth plate came out and we began digging in. The meat was so well-seasoned and cooked that we all fell in love. The salad and dressing that came with it gave it so much flavor and refreshed our palate. In that moment, we knew we made the right choice coming here.

excerpts: We ordered the sambussa, the lamb tib as well as the veggie combo.
Yum.
I don't usually like lamb as most restaurants do not get rid of the "lamb smell".
They flavor the meat so well here.
The service is also impeccable.
They explained the menu as well as check in very regularly to make sure we are doing alright.
I said I wanted to try the telba drink.
The owner gave me a sample before confirming my order to make sure I really like the drink.
Similar to their food, the drink did not disappoint.
We will be back.
sambussa.author: ZW N.
sambussa.review: This is my first time eating Ethiopian food. I am impressed. The food is so flavorful. We ordered the sambussa, the lamb tib as well as the veggie combo. Yum. I don't usually like lamb as most restaurants do not get rid of the "lamb smell". They flavor the meat so well here. The service is also impeccable. They explained the menu as well as check in very regularly to make sure we are doing alright. I said I wanted to try the telba drink. The owner gave me a sample before confirming my order to make sure I really like the drink. Similar to their food, the drink did not disappoint. We will be back.

excerpts: I like the lamb tibs, timatim fitfit, buticha salad, and misir wot.
timatim fitfit.author: My N.
timatim fitfit.review: The food is really good.  I've only had takeout service -- its friendly and the food is always ready by the time I get there.  You can place the order online and pre-pay from their website so all you have to do is walk in and pick up the order, super easy and convenient.  I like the lamb tibs, timatim fitfit, buticha salad, and misir wot.

excerpts: Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen and sides of Azifa, buticha and salad.

In particular, the Alicha Tikil Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with onions, ginger, and tumeric) and Kik Alicha (chickpeas cooked with spicy tumeric, ginger, and garlic) stood out.
I was mesmerized by the flavors.
The Misir
Wot (split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, ginger, and garlic) was smoky and peppery.
I don't think the combo I had came with Azifa (lentils sauteed with onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds, and lemon).
The buticha (ground chickpeas, peppers, and onions) was delicious.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Lauren H.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
On a Sunday afternoon, I came here very hungry at a rather odd hour between lunch and dinner and ordered right away. Service was quick and friendly. My Vegetarian Combination came out in mere minutes. I stopped for a moment to take in the wonderful aromas and then proceeded to inhale the food so fast my stomach started to hurt a little.   

The combo came with Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen and sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. In particular, the Alicha Tikil Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with onions, ginger, and tumeric) and Kik Alicha (chickpeas cooked with spicy tumeric, ginger, and garlic) stood out. I was mesmerized by the flavors.  
 
The Misir Wot (split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, ginger, and garlic) was smoky and peppery. I don't think the combo I had came with Azifa (lentils sauteed with onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds, and lemon). The buticha (ground chickpeas, peppers, and onions) was delicious. Eating the collard greens (Gomen) made me feel extra healthy.  

I appreciated the hand wipe that was provided after the meal which seems to be customary at Ethiopian restaurants. And I love the Andes chocolates that came with the bill. Some of the customers were speaking to the staff in an Ethiopian language adding to the authenticity of this place. Don't let walking in the neighborhood deter you! It wasn't nearly so bad in broad daylight.

excerpts: The alicha tikil gomen seemed to have a better blend of spices adorning the veggies.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Adam B.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
A gem in the Tenderloin; a few seats and a menu full of Ethiopian treats.  The vegetarian combination is very filling and reasonably priced.  I kinda of wish there was a meat combo, but instead all the carnivore options were just the meat with injera.  Guess I'll have to come back with a friend next time to justify getting the veggie combo *and* a separate meat dish.

Beef Sambusa: The sambusa itself was very similar to a deep fried empanada.  I suppose many cultures have the concept of wrapping ground meat in dough and then heating it in oil.  However, the red sauce on the side was amazing!  Had a little spicy kick, but not overwhelming.  Full of so much flavor that it really brought these sambusas to the next level. 

Vegetarian Combination: Loved the variety of 6 different items on one plate.  My favorite was probably the misir wot since I love me some berbere.  The kik alicha was pretty tasty too since chickpeas are a nice hearty pairing to the spongy injera bread.  The gomen was a little bland, but mixing those collard greens with any of the mushier items solved that issue.  The alicha tikil gomen seemed to have a better blend of spices adorning the veggies.  The small amounts of buticha and azifa were a bit intense by themselves, but enhanced the other items when a dab was added.

excerpts:
I highly recommend the veggie combo which comes with:

- Gomen: collard greens
- Alicha tikil gomen: cabbage, potatoes, carrots
- Misir wot: split lentil (my favorite!)
alicha tikil gomen.author: Jay C.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
Ethiopian is incredibly vegan friendly and you can't get much better Ethiopian in the city than Tadu (for an upscale experience, check out Radio Africa Kitchen). All their veggie dishes are pretty much vegan so for those who sometimes second guess like me, this is a vegan SAFE place! And if in doubt, ask the incredibly friendly wait staff who are patient with first timers and veterans alike. I highly recommend the veggie combo which comes with:

- Gomen: collard greens
- Alicha tikil gomen: cabbage, potatoes, carrots
- Misir wot: split lentil (my favorite!)
- Kik alicha (chickpea)
- And sides azifa: lentils (ridiculously good), buticha: ground chickpeas, and salad
- With a basket of injera

This is a small place (4-5 tables) usually full of other Ethiopians, so come early to beat the rush.

excerpts: Also, our alicha tikil gomen ended up being almost entirely cabbage.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Lisa K.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
This is a nice little oasis in the tenderloin. I started with the excellent Ethiopian coffee, to which I added ridiculously heavy-seeming cream. We had the vegetarian combo platter and the chicken tibs, which we asked to be brought out together on a big plate with injera underneath & a bountiful basket of rolled injera alongside. There was *so* much food and I thought it was pretty delicious & made for wonderful leftovers.

The biggest difference I found between Tadu & other Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've had is that it tasted a bit "fresher" and less slow-cooked/stewed. I'm not sure if this was a time issue or a stylistic one. Honestly I prefer the long-cooked method where the flavors meld together more and everything softens up, but this was good too. I found it especially noticeable in the gomen (greens) and kik alicha. Also, our alicha tikil gomen ended up being almost entirely cabbage.

excerpts:
