**VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints.

In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Elliott D.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
TL;DR:

Quite decent in the realm of Ethiopian, though I'm puzzled by their lack of a proper Wot offerings.

THE DEETS:

***VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints. In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there. Unexpected but interesting.

***REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter. Served with a side of Ayib (cheese). Spicy & Hot. (served rare of course)

Nice & buttery, I approve. I like a little moo with my beef (raw or rare). They seem to serve as tiny bits rather than actual ground beef, which is an interesting & unexpected approach. 

***LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.

I've never really cared for tibs, which are kinda okay but just not as creamy, tender, or flavorful as wot. But they don't have any wot offerings, which is disappointing. 

***FIRFIR - LAMB ALICHA BANATU - Small pieces of injera tossed in Tadu's sauces of mild tumeric with lamb. Mild.

Quite nice. This dish highlights why Ethiopian leftovers are always better the second day--the injera gets soft, mushy, and even a bit more fermented, which sounds like it would be gross, but during this process everything becomes super-infused with flavor.

excerpts: After perusing the menu, the three of us decided to share the Vegetarian Combo, which includes the Kik Alicha (chickpeas), Misir Wot (spicy lentils), Gomen (collard greens), Alicha Tikil Gomen (carrots/potatoes/cabbage), Azifa (lentils), and salad.
The star of the combo was the Misir Wot, which had great flavor and a little bit of a kick to it.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Terence T.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
The combination of trying to find a restaurant in walking distance that was open midday on a Sunday and having not had Ethiopian food for ages led me to Tadu. As it's located in the Tenderloin, we walked past the numerous homeless people that are unfortunately so common there. 

After perusing the menu, the three of us decided to share the Vegetarian Combo, which includes the Kik Alicha (chickpeas), Misir Wot (spicy lentils), Gomen (collard greens), Alicha Tikil Gomen (carrots/potatoes/cabbage), Azifa (lentils), and salad. The star of the combo was the Misir Wot, which had great flavor and a little bit of a kick to it. The other items were pretty typical and not especially interesting (have yet to have them anywhere where I thought they were great).

In addition to the vegetables, we had the lamb tibs and beef tibs. The lamb had a nice, strong lamb flavor to it. To our dismay, the beef tibs were tasteless. In addition, the two dishes are prepared in exactly the same way, so the contrast in flavors (or lack thereof) was especially noticeable.

Plenty of injera for our meal (they asked if we wanted more, but we were already full). We certainly overordered as we had leftovers.

Overall, this is somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. I've decided on the lower rating due to proximity to the homeless--if you are walking around with a child, you feel a bit unsafe. I will say that when we were inside the restaurant, we had no concerns about safety.

excerpts: Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen with sides of Azifa, buticha and salad.
It's quite a feast on its own.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Saminda W.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
Everything was pretty epic, not a single complaint.  

We had the veggie combo and all the dishes were delish.  It comes with the Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen with sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. It's quite a feast on its own.  Highly recommend you go with this choice and get the best of all worlds.

I also had some of the Special Kifto (lean ground beef, onions and jalapeno sauteed with special spices and homemade butter) and it was great but not as amazing as the veggie dishes. 

Service was great, they are really friendly and fast.

excerpts: We ordered the Kik Alicha, Beef Tibs, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Minchin Wot.
Everything was excellent and well spiced.
alicha tikil gomen.author: Chris M.
alicha tikil gomen.review:
We stopped in on Sunday after reading reviews on Yelp for this place. We were in the mood for Ethiopian food and most of our usual places were not open until later in the day. What a wonderful find!

We ordered the Kik Alicha, Beef Tibs, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Minchin Wot. Everything was excellent and well spiced. The injera was especially good, not too sour, and service was spot on.

The veggies were fresh and flavorful. The Kik was not too mushy and had a good texture. Both meat dishes were excellent and not overly oily. We brought some of the Minchin home and will using that as a pasta sauce.

They've only been open two months and are working on getting a liquor license, but I highly recommend this place. 

We will be coming back for sure.

So happy to have a new Ethiopian place to enjoy!

excerpts: The shiro wot and mesir
wot were sooo flavorful.
When I asked which one he'd recommend, he told me the shiro wot and gave me a scoop of mesir wot on the side to try.
shiro wot.author: Emily C.
shiro wot.review:
Went here on a whim when I was here for a conference. The shiro wot and mesir wot were sooo flavorful. Very generous portions and gave more than enough of the delicious injera bread. 

Love these mom and pop shops, and this one certainly didn't disappoint. When I asked which one he'd recommend, he told me the shiro wot and gave me a scoop of mesir wot on the side to try. Loved this couple and wish their restaurant the best!! 

On a side note, I went by myself and got catcalled at least 5-6 times in the time that I walked the 0.2 miles from where I was. If you're with a family or it's after dark, I'd recommend grabbing a Lyft or Uber to get to the area.

excerpts: Misir Wot and Shiro Wot - both were to die for!
shiro wot.author: Omead A.
shiro wot.review:
My wife and I enjoyed a fantastic dinner with friends at Tadu! We started off with two orders of Sambussas, one veggie and one beef. Both options were delicious, and the slightly spicy dipping sauce was exquisite! 

For our main entree, we ordered two of the Vegan combos. It was a great call, as we were able to try a variety of all their different veggie meals. Our favorite of the bunch had to be  Misir Wot and Shiro Wot - both were to die for! For the nonvegans, we also ordered a plate of the medium rare  regular kitfo, which was equally amazing! 

Great service, friendly atmosphere, and we will definitely be coming back!

excerpts: My friends are both Vegetarian, so we ordered the Vegetarian Combination (lentils, cabbage, collard greens) with Shiro Wot (ground chickpeas that had a consistency of a thick, refried bean paste) to share.
Injera came separately in a basket.
The flavors were fantastic, and it was definitely a good idea to split it between the 3 of us!
We especially enjoyed the Shiro Wot and lentils.
shiro wot.author: Christine T.
shiro wot.review:
I went with two girl friends to Tadu last night and was extremely pleased. I walked over to Tadu from Union Square and didn't feel the most comfortable walking alone through the Tenderloin, so just take note of this if you decide to come by foot in the evening. 

It's a small place but was well-packed when we arrived. I asked for a table for three, and the girl working there quickly ran to the back to grab two chairs to join a table with a single chair. We started off with lentil sambussas (samosas), which came out super hot and fresh with BOMB spicy sauce! 

My friends are both Vegetarian, so we ordered the Vegetarian Combination (lentils, cabbage, collard greens) with Shiro Wot (ground chickpeas that had a consistency of a thick, refried bean paste) to share. Injera came separately in a basket. The flavors were fantastic, and it was definitely a good idea to split it between the 3 of us! We especially enjoyed the Shiro Wot and lentils. After we finished the huge platter, the girl brought us a small plate of baklava that was "on the house", which was such a pleasant surprise. 

The man running the show was super nice and definitely gave Tadu a warm, home-y vibe. Friendly service, great bang for your buck--I'll be back.

excerpts: I absolutely love the beef berebere banatu, and shiro wot.
shiro wot.author: Shereen A.
shiro wot.review:
Tadu freaking ROCKS!

Was really craving Ethiopian food and after not finding anything comparable to Seattle, I decided I didn't care and wanted to try this place (the five stars lured me in).

The first time we came here, it was an hour before closing to find that there were no seats and it was SUPER packed. There's only five tables, so plan accordingly. We waited and waited, and thankfully right before they closed they kindly seated us.

We started off with the vegetarian sambusas (ask for the hot sauce, it spicy and delish). The edges were perfectly crispy, we practically inhaled them.

Next up, the vegetarian combo, beef berebere banatu, firfir, lamb tibs, and shiro wot (so I know this is a lot of food, but leftovers are the best, so whatever).

Bf ate the ENTIRE veg combo by himself. Not only is it super flavorful, it's massive (one of those can't stop eating, it's so delicious), and you get enough injera to swaddle a newborn baby elephant in. 

They even brought us a bite each of baklava since we waited outside for an hour for a table. So nice (and so yum).

I absolutely love the beef berebere banatu, and shiro wot. We never come here and not order both of those. 

Also, they have gluten free injera (FROM Ethiopia!!), like no joke. Order this (+$3) and you'll leave without feeling fat, no matter how much you dig in. It's a bit more tart than the regular injera, but so so delicious, absolutely fluffy, and perfectly moist. I never skip it. I gladly take the the left overs home and make my own berebere firfirX (lentils, chicken, etc.) to enjoy for another day. 

The staff is always so helpful, very kind, and remembers you. 

Seriously addicted to this place.

excerpts: Side of Shiro Wot - YUM.
shiro wot.author: Jessica L.
shiro wot.review:
Delicious Ethiopian food! Went for the first time last night and it was fantastic. 

We ordered:
Lentil Sambusa - Little fried pocket of deliciousness. Very flavorful. Comes with a red spicy sauce that makes this appetizer special.
Vegetarian Combination- Lots of different sides. My favorite were the Misir Wot.
Minchet Abish Wot - Savory, spicy, really great with the injera.
Side of Shiro Wot - YUM. 

The restaurant is small and cozy. Casual vibe. The guy who waited on us, let us try the Shiro for free (and it was amazing). I highly suggest this restaurant if you like Ethiopian.

The only thing this restaurant is missing is a meat/veggie combo. Sometimes you just want a little of both :)

excerpts: Would highly recommend shiro wot and mushroom/brinjal gravy for injera.
shiro wot.author: Sukirti S.
shiro wot.review: Nice and tasty food. This is such a small Ethiopian place with a numerous options for vegetarians! Injera was soft with a light sour taste. Had been there with a small group and the place was tight with no room for air. Service was not commendable. If you are there only for the food then you would enjoy it! Would highly recommend shiro wot and mushroom/brinjal gravy for injera.

excerpts: Really loved the Misir Wot and Shiro Wot .
shiro wot.author: Pranav B.
shiro wot.review:
I had read a lot about this place on Yelp and have seen in consistently rated in the Top 10 SFO restaurants. This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and needless to say, I absolutely loved it. Ordered a Vegetarian combination and Chicken Tibs. Really loved the Misir Wot and Shiro Wot . The rest of the lentils and salads were alright. 

Cons: It is located in the Tenderloin area, which is a sketchy neighbourhood. Also, I wish the Injera were served hot.

Mentioned the cons to the owner and he took my review positively. Overall, anyone in SFO city should check out this place.

excerpts: My favorite of the vegetarian dishes is the Shiro Wot.
The Misir
Wot is a close second.
I like spicy food though.
shiro wot.author: Katy H.
shiro wot.review:
This place is out of control good. I've been here twice and both times it was heaven. One order of sambussas and one veggie combo will make a filling meal for two vegetarians. If you're really hungry, order two of the vegetarian dishes. You can have them served together on one big injera so you can share. 

My favorite of the vegetarian dishes is the Shiro Wot. The Misir Wot is a close second. I like spicy food though. If you don't, you might like the Kik Alicha Wot better. 

As a bonus - the owner is really welcoming and clearly excited about the food.

excerpts: If you don't, you might like the Kik Alicha Wot better.
kik alicha wot.author: Katy H.
kik alicha wot.review:
This place is out of control good. I've been here twice and both times it was heaven. One order of sambussas and one veggie combo will make a filling meal for two vegetarians. If you're really hungry, order two of the vegetarian dishes. You can have them served together on one big injera so you can share. 

My favorite of the vegetarian dishes is the Shiro Wot. The Misir Wot is a close second. I like spicy food though. If you don't, you might like the Kik Alicha Wot better. 

As a bonus - the owner is really welcoming and clearly excited about the food.

excerpts: As for the food, I had Regular Kitfo with a side order-size of Kik Alicha Wot.
My friend had the Vegetarian Combo.
Plenty of spongy injera to eat it all with.
Everything was so full of amazing flavors and spices, and we left full and satisfied.
The service was very attentive.
It was busy when we arrived around 2 pm on a Sunday (the place only has a handful of tables), but by the time we left it had emptied out.
I admit I've only had Ethiopian food a few times, and this was the first Ethiopian restaurant I've been in SF, but I see no need to go anywhere else the next time I get a craving.
I strongly recommend this place.
kik alicha wot.author: Patrick F.
kik alicha wot.review: The Tenderloin has its issues and may not be a place I go after dark, but finding amazing food from all over the world for cheap makes it worth exploring (at least in daylight). Tadu is a tiny place that you could easily miss due to minimal signage, but missing it would be a crime! The atmosphere is very "no frills," but bright and very clean, including the bathroom (which is often where places like this fall short when it comes to cleanliness). As for the food, I had Regular Kitfo with a side order-size of Kik Alicha Wot. My friend had the Vegetarian Combo. Plenty of spongy injera to eat it all with. Everything was so full of amazing flavors and spices, and we left full and satisfied. The service was very attentive. It was busy when we arrived around 2 pm on a Sunday (the place only has a handful of tables), but by the time we left it had emptied out. I admit I've only had Ethiopian food a few times, and this was the first Ethiopian restaurant I've been in SF, but I see no need to go anywhere else the next time I get a craving. I strongly recommend this place.

excerpts: Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen and sides of Azifa, buticha and salad.

In particular, the Alicha Tikil Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with onions, ginger, and tumeric) and Kik Alicha (chickpeas cooked with spicy tumeric, ginger, and garlic) stood out.
I was mesmerized by the flavors.
The Misir
Wot (split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, ginger, and garlic) was smoky and peppery.
I don't think the combo I had came with Azifa (lentils sauteed with onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds, and lemon).
The buticha (ground chickpeas, peppers, and onions) was delicious.
azifa.author: Lauren H.
azifa.review:
On a Sunday afternoon, I came here very hungry at a rather odd hour between lunch and dinner and ordered right away. Service was quick and friendly. My Vegetarian Combination came out in mere minutes. I stopped for a moment to take in the wonderful aromas and then proceeded to inhale the food so fast my stomach started to hurt a little.   

The combo came with Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen and sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. In particular, the Alicha Tikil Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with onions, ginger, and tumeric) and Kik Alicha (chickpeas cooked with spicy tumeric, ginger, and garlic) stood out. I was mesmerized by the flavors.  
 
The Misir Wot (split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, ginger, and garlic) was smoky and peppery. I don't think the combo I had came with Azifa (lentils sauteed with onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds, and lemon). The buticha (ground chickpeas, peppers, and onions) was delicious. Eating the collard greens (Gomen) made me feel extra healthy.  

I appreciated the hand wipe that was provided after the meal which seems to be customary at Ethiopian restaurants. And I love the Andes chocolates that came with the bill. Some of the customers were speaking to the staff in an Ethiopian language adding to the authenticity of this place. Don't let walking in the neighborhood deter you! It wasn't nearly so bad in broad daylight.

excerpts: The small amounts of buticha and azifa were a bit intense by themselves, but enhanced the other items when a dab was added.
azifa.author: Adam B.
azifa.review:
A gem in the Tenderloin; a few seats and a menu full of Ethiopian treats.  The vegetarian combination is very filling and reasonably priced.  I kinda of wish there was a meat combo, but instead all the carnivore options were just the meat with injera.  Guess I'll have to come back with a friend next time to justify getting the veggie combo *and* a separate meat dish.

Beef Sambusa: The sambusa itself was very similar to a deep fried empanada.  I suppose many cultures have the concept of wrapping ground meat in dough and then heating it in oil.  However, the red sauce on the side was amazing!  Had a little spicy kick, but not overwhelming.  Full of so much flavor that it really brought these sambusas to the next level. 

Vegetarian Combination: Loved the variety of 6 different items on one plate.  My favorite was probably the misir wot since I love me some berbere.  The kik alicha was pretty tasty too since chickpeas are a nice hearty pairing to the spongy injera bread.  The gomen was a little bland, but mixing those collard greens with any of the mushier items solved that issue.  The alicha tikil gomen seemed to have a better blend of spices adorning the veggies.  The small amounts of buticha and azifa were a bit intense by themselves, but enhanced the other items when a dab was added.

excerpts:
sides azifa: lentils (ridiculously good), buticha: ground chickpeas, and salad
-
azifa.author: Jay C.
azifa.review:
Ethiopian is incredibly vegan friendly and you can't get much better Ethiopian in the city than Tadu (for an upscale experience, check out Radio Africa Kitchen). All their veggie dishes are pretty much vegan so for those who sometimes second guess like me, this is a vegan SAFE place! And if in doubt, ask the incredibly friendly wait staff who are patient with first timers and veterans alike. I highly recommend the veggie combo which comes with:

- Gomen: collard greens
- Alicha tikil gomen: cabbage, potatoes, carrots
- Misir wot: split lentil (my favorite!)
- Kik alicha (chickpea)
- And sides azifa: lentils (ridiculously good), buticha: ground chickpeas, and salad
- With a basket of injera

This is a small place (4-5 tables) usually full of other Ethiopians, so come early to beat the rush.

excerpts: We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs.
This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera.
My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs.
SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite.
Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.
azifa.author: Crystal S.
azifa.review: Went here for an early dinner on a Saturday prior to watching a movie. We figured this would be a perfect place as one of our group is a Vegetarian. We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs. This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera. My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs. SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite. Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.

excerpts:
**VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints.

In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there.
azifa.author: Elliott D.
azifa.review:
TL;DR:

Quite decent in the realm of Ethiopian, though I'm puzzled by their lack of a proper Wot offerings.

THE DEETS:

***VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints. In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there. Unexpected but interesting.

***REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter. Served with a side of Ayib (cheese). Spicy & Hot. (served rare of course)

Nice & buttery, I approve. I like a little moo with my beef (raw or rare). They seem to serve as tiny bits rather than actual ground beef, which is an interesting & unexpected approach. 

***LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.

I've never really cared for tibs, which are kinda okay but just not as creamy, tender, or flavorful as wot. But they don't have any wot offerings, which is disappointing. 

***FIRFIR - LAMB ALICHA BANATU - Small pieces of injera tossed in Tadu's sauces of mild tumeric with lamb. Mild.

Quite nice. This dish highlights why Ethiopian leftovers are always better the second day--the injera gets soft, mushy, and even a bit more fermented, which sounds like it would be gross, but during this process everything becomes super-infused with flavor.

excerpts: After perusing the menu, the three of us decided to share the Vegetarian Combo, which includes the Kik Alicha (chickpeas), Misir Wot (spicy lentils), Gomen (collard greens), Alicha Tikil Gomen (carrots/potatoes/cabbage), Azifa (lentils), and salad.
The star of the combo was the Misir Wot, which had great flavor and a little bit of a kick to it.
azifa.author: Terence T.
azifa.review:
The combination of trying to find a restaurant in walking distance that was open midday on a Sunday and having not had Ethiopian food for ages led me to Tadu. As it's located in the Tenderloin, we walked past the numerous homeless people that are unfortunately so common there. 

After perusing the menu, the three of us decided to share the Vegetarian Combo, which includes the Kik Alicha (chickpeas), Misir Wot (spicy lentils), Gomen (collard greens), Alicha Tikil Gomen (carrots/potatoes/cabbage), Azifa (lentils), and salad. The star of the combo was the Misir Wot, which had great flavor and a little bit of a kick to it. The other items were pretty typical and not especially interesting (have yet to have them anywhere where I thought they were great).

In addition to the vegetables, we had the lamb tibs and beef tibs. The lamb had a nice, strong lamb flavor to it. To our dismay, the beef tibs were tasteless. In addition, the two dishes are prepared in exactly the same way, so the contrast in flavors (or lack thereof) was especially noticeable.

Plenty of injera for our meal (they asked if we wanted more, but we were already full). We certainly overordered as we had leftovers.

Overall, this is somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. I've decided on the lower rating due to proximity to the homeless--if you are walking around with a child, you feel a bit unsafe. I will say that when we were inside the restaurant, we had no concerns about safety.

excerpts: My favorites are: gomen, telba, azifa, tima tima fit fit, and misir
wot.
The telba drink is really tasty.
It's sweet from the honey.
I enjoy this drink because it's healthy and  full of omegas.
This is the best tima tima fit fit I've had.
The chunks of injera are thick and the seasoning are spicy and tangy.
This is the first place I ever had Ethiopian
and I'm happy I did
because now it's my favorite type of food!
I love all of the spices and love they put in their food!
azifa.author: Joe G.
azifa.review: Whenever I'm traveling to the city I'm sure to stop by this place! It's walking distance to union square. The waitresses and cooks are really sweet. I'm vegan so it's nice coming here and knowing they do not cook with butter/eggs. My favorites are: gomen, telba, azifa, tima tima fit fit, and misir wot. The telba drink is really tasty. It's sweet from the honey. I enjoy this drink because it's healthy and  full of omegas. This is the best tima tima fit fit I've had. The chunks of injera are thick and the seasoning are spicy and tangy. This is the first place I ever had Ethiopian and I'm happy I did because now it's my favorite type of food! I love all of the spices and love they put in their food!

excerpts: Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen with sides of Azifa, buticha and salad.
It's quite a feast on its own.
azifa.author: Saminda W.
azifa.review:
Everything was pretty epic, not a single complaint.  

We had the veggie combo and all the dishes were delish.  It comes with the Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen with sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. It's quite a feast on its own.  Highly recommend you go with this choice and get the best of all worlds.

I also had some of the Special Kifto (lean ground beef, onions and jalapeno sauteed with special spices and homemade butter) and it was great but not as amazing as the veggie dishes. 

Service was great, they are really friendly and fast.

excerpts: Each dish was excellent, the Kik Alicha and Azifa especially stood out.
azifa.author: Amanda S.
azifa.review:
Found Tadu by chance as I was walking home, stopped to chat to the friendly owner and came back for food an hour later. I'm so excited to have a good Ethipian restaurant in my neighborhood. 

I had the vegetarian combo, it came with the lightest and fluffiest injera I've tasted. Each dish was excellent, the Kik Alicha and Azifa especially stood out.

I'll definitely be back. Often.

excerpts: Incredible raw kifto and a medley of vegetarian sides (gomen, Wot, azifa, kik alicha) made for an excellent dinner.
The owner is friendly and will make good suggestions if you tell him what you like.
The service is swift and the kitchen is very clean.
What a gem in the tenderloin!!!
azifa.author: Nastja R.
azifa.review: The best I've had. Hands down. Incredible raw kifto and a medley of vegetarian sides (gomen, Wot, azifa, kik alicha) made for an excellent dinner. The owner is friendly and will make good suggestions if you tell him what you like. The service is swift and the kitchen is very clean. What a gem in the tenderloin!!!

excerpts: : Get the vegetable medley  (with eggplant  or mushroom)  and Vegetarian combo‼.
The injera bread is made with teff & millet (i think)
the vegetable medley.author: Athonia C.
the vegetable medley.review:
Tadu is great if you know what to order and what condiments to request. I really hope this location stays around for a while because they're so damn unique.  I'm also appreciative of restaurants who state which items are vegetarian & vegan right on the menu. The knowledgable staff here help further fine tune what you might order if you are the enlightened type who trys to avoid consuming animal products. 

They are awarded stars here as such: 

1. Ambiance: It's comfortable and they there's wonderful Ethiopian decorations
2. Food: the stews are all very flavorful. Their spicy hot powder, available by request, is just what you'd need to bring the heat up a notch
3. Tadu is Vegetarian & Vegan friendly. They know their ingredients so they can advise which dishes will suit those with self imposed dietary restrictions. 

I couldn't give Tadu five stars because, for me, the fifth is reserved for restaurants who offer vegan proteins (e.g. TVP, Gardein, Beyond Meat etc.). However, had 'Yelp!' offered reviewers a choice of several celestial bodies, I would have awarded Tadu four stars and one crab nebula! 

WHAT TO ORDER?: Get the vegetable medley  (with eggplant  or mushroom)  and Vegetarian combo‼. The injera bread is made with teff & millet (i think) so that's always cruelty free.

Maybe this is too much to ask but I think the problem with all Ethiopian restaurants is that they have yet to offer vegan mock meat proteins. Vegans are a loyal subset of the Ethiopian restaurants. Given the smaller selection of choices we have for restaurants they can expect a higher return visit rate from the vegetarian community. I wish they could work in bulk vegan food items as outlined in guide for restaurants who want to offer such things such as this one below: http://www.mercyforanimals.org/VRGFRNational.pdf

excerpts: I really loved the vegetable medley, which consisted of mushrooms with bell peppers and onions in Ethiopian spices.
I've never had a dish like that at an Ethiopian place before, and it was really tasty.
Highly recommended!
the vegetable medley.author: Jen T.
the vegetable medley.review:
The place was really small -- just seven little tables for two people each, with random extra chairs here and there to squeeze in a third. Prepare for a moderate wait, especially since there only appears to be one waiter. However, that waiter was very friendly and fairly attentive, given that he had seven tables to deal with. 

But the main thing is the food. SO GOOD. The injera is perfect, not too moist and not too dry, and the vegetarian combo was pretty perfect (and a great value at around $12!). I really loved the vegetable medley, which consisted of mushrooms with bell peppers and onions in Ethiopian spices. I've never had a dish like that at an Ethiopian place before, and it was really tasty. Highly recommended!

excerpts: My girlfriend and I shared the vegetarian combo and beef tibs.
I love when they serve the dish on top of a big piece of injera along with rolled up pieces of injera on the side.
beef tibs.author: Edward W.
beef tibs.review:
I've only tried Ethiopian food a handful of times, but I've loved it every time and this place was not any different. 

The amount of seating here is quite minimal, so we were lucky to snag a table for 4. My girlfriend and I shared the vegetarian combo and beef tibs. I love when they serve the dish on top of a big piece of injera along with rolled up pieces of injera on the side. It's fun to eat the food with your hands and the veggies and meat were all very flavorful. 

It was such a pleasure to eat here and I'm sure i'll be back.

excerpts: and we paired the veggie sampler with an order each of the chicken, lamb, and beef tibs - basically cubes of meat simmered in the house sauce.
All of this is served on Injera - a bread that looks like a pancake
but it's greyish-purpleish
and it was explained to me that it was made out of grain that has been imported from the homeland.
There's a sour taste to it
and I know it sounds weird
beef tibs.author: Ray R.
beef tibs.review:
Running out of lunch options at work, I turned to Yelp who had a philosophical question for me. Would I be willing to make my way through the jungle (The Tenderloin) to seek out treasure beyond my wildest dreams? I'm happy to report, this Safari was an adventure well worth the journey past the mumbling crackheads offering oratorial rewards in exchange for their next hit, feces of the dog and human kind littered throughout like pancakes at an IHOP buffet, and just the wretched smell of ..well you get the point.

The place is tiny. We had a group of 5 and it was a little tight sitting at one table but we made due. The menu is simple enough - there's lunch specials and there's the group share-family style entrees, which is what we did. We decided to do the vegetarian sampler which come in big dollops of various veggies - creamed chickpeas, some collard greens, lentils, etc. and we paired the veggie sampler with an order each of the chicken, lamb, and beef tibs - basically cubes of meat simmered in the house sauce. All of this is served on Injera - a bread that looks like a pancake but it's greyish-purpleish and it was explained to me that it was made out of grain that has been imported from the homeland. There's a sour taste to it and I know it sounds weird but it goes very well with the food.

You eat with your hands by scooping up food with Injera (there's also extra Injera served besides the one used as the "plate") or if you are weak, they can give you a spoon and fork. But that defeats the whole purpose of trying this type of food - it just does not taste the same unless you eat it how it's meant to be eaten. Food was delicious and service was great. I liked everything we had.

The only qualm I have was that I felt as if the portions were a bit small. For the price we paid, I expected a little more. We were 5 hungry, growing boys, and we all felt a little hungry after we devoured our meal. 

All in all, a great experience and will definitely come back!

PS - don't try to correct me in my reference to the bread. It's Injera. To call it "Injera Bread" would be like calling lumpia "Lumpia roll" or Chai "Chai Tea". Like Madam Miriam Defensor would say - it's a redundancy, student!

excerpts: I ordered Beef Tibs and my friends ordered Misir Wot and Mushroom veggie.
The Tibs was what you would expect in any good Ethiopian place.
But their vegetarian dishes were so yummy with their soft injeras!!
The Misir Wot was spicy, tangy, flavorful, awesome, tasty, lovely, gorgeous...
beef tibs.author: Ram R.
beef tibs.review:
I am a meat lover but this place converted me to a vegetarian for a brief 1-hour period!

I went with a couple of friends. I ordered Beef Tibs and my friends ordered Misir Wot and Mushroom veggie. The Tibs was what you would expect in any good Ethiopian place. But their vegetarian dishes were so yummy with their soft injeras!! The Misir Wot was spicy, tangy, flavorful, awesome, tasty, lovely, gorgeous... :D 

Portion sizes are large so please go with friends. They'll love it!

excerpts: In addition to the vegetables, we had the lamb tibs and beef tibs.
The lamb had a nice, strong lamb flavor to it.
To our dismay, the beef tibs were tasteless.

excerpts: I eat Ethiopian on a regular but the beef tibs was not flavored the way I'm use to for sure.
The Alicha was very greasy, and the salad with yogurt eek...what happened to oil and vinegar.
I guess they do it different in San Fran then back home.
Oh well $40 down the drain
even my spiced tea wasn't right.
Oh well to each their own.

beef tibs.review: The delivery was fantastic very fast super friendly....food not so much. I eat Ethiopian on a regular but the beef tibs was not flavored the way I'm use to for sure. The Alicha was very greasy, and the salad with yogurt eek...what happened to oil and vinegar. I guess they do it different in San Fran then back home. Oh well $40 down the drain even my spiced tea wasn't right.  Oh well to each their own.

excerpts: We went for the share patter vegetable combination plus the beef tibs, and this was plenty for two hungry diners.
No boring flavours here, each dish was delicious.
A great place to head with a vegetarian friend.
The interior is clean and the service is friendly.
I'd be here all the time if I lived in SF.
beef tibs.author: Laura D.
beef tibs.review: This place was great! It was my first Ethiopian food experience and I am hooked! I've been dreaming about the wholewheat sourdough flatbread ever since, mmmm so fluffy. We went for the share patter vegetable combination plus the beef tibs, and this was plenty for two hungry diners. No boring flavours here, each dish was delicious. A great place to head with a vegetarian friend. The interior is clean and the service is friendly. I'd be here all the time if I lived in SF.

excerpts: We ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs.
I liked both quite a lot, but preferred the rich flavour of the beef tibs.
beef tibs.author: Uli B.
beef tibs.review:
I am a big fan of Ethipoan food and this place didn't disappoint me at all. I'd read the reviews here on Yelp prior to my visit and since it was favorably reviewed by some of my trusted Yelp friends, I decided that I'd come here for dinner with a colleague one evening.

We ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs. I liked both quite a lot, but preferred the rich flavour of the beef tibs. 

Situated in the heart of the Tenderloin, I was expecting a run-down equipment but was actually surprised that the space was newly renovated and quite bright.

excerpts: We got the kitfo and the beef Tibs, and both were good, but the beef tibs were ESPECIALLY good...watch out, though, they're spicy; it'll kick your ass.
beef tibs.author: Chris S.
beef tibs.review:
Flavors: awesome. Deeper, more interesting, and I assume more authentic than the other Ethopian places I've been. Lots of good choices. We got the kitfo and the beef Tibs, and both were good, but the beef tibs were ESPECIALLY good...watch out, though, they're spicy; it'll kick your ass. I'm glad that the sever was ok with me getting up to serve myself several more waters. 

Seating: LIMITED. I wouldn't come here with more than a couple of people. Which kind of sucks, because it's a bit hard to do Ethopian takeout, AND Ethopian is more fun with more people....but they do takeout, and that would be the way to do it. Make sure to get extra Injera. 

Prices: Pretty good for ethopian, for sure! 

Location: Smack dab in a sketchy part of the tenderloin. Bummer.

Gastro the next day: Not so good. But I don't really care what my stomach says, I really like this place.

excerpts: Got the veggie combination plate with beef tibs and shared it with two other people.
It was my friends' first time trying Ethiopian, and I wanted them to come away with happy stomachs.
The food was absolutely delicious, and the server was friendly and helpful.
beef tibs.author: Tiffany S.
beef tibs.review:
Got the veggie combination plate with beef tibs and shared it with two other people. It was my friends' first time trying Ethiopian, and I wanted them to come away with happy stomachs. The food was absolutely delicious, and the server was friendly and helpful. Not being very familiar with the menu, he helped explain the menu and suggested foods we could share as a group.

The place is a little small, but didn't feel crowded. When we arrived (around 6:30 on a Friday evening), nearly all of the tables were full but we luckily had no wait. Would definitely love to go again next time I'm in the area.

excerpts: For our main course, we had an order of lamb tibs and another of beef tibs, served with injera.
This is essentially a platter of heavily spiced meat, served with vegetables and cheese.
Injera is the Ethiopian version of a crepe.
You get as much as you can eat, and you also pick up the meat with it, as there is no silverware.
beef tibs.author: Dan D.
beef tibs.review:
Wow this food is good!

My partner and I went there for a Sunday lunch. The restaurant wasn't busy at all, which was probably for the best since they only have like seven tables.

It's also located in a rough part of town. It's in the heart of the Tenderloin, so be prepared for all the sights (and smells) that entails. 

With that out of the way, the food definitely made it worth the trip! We started with beef sambussas, which were fantastic. The meat had a delightful combination of spices, and the dipping sauce they came with was also spicy and full of flavor.

For our main course, we had an order of lamb tibs and another of beef tibs, served with injera. This is essentially a platter of heavily spiced meat, served with vegetables and cheese. Injera is the Ethiopian version of a crepe. You get as much as you can eat, and you also pick up the meat with it, as there is no silverware. We both thought the lamb tasted better than the beef (each was cooked in different spices), but both were awesome. 

We finished with Ethiopian coffee. I'm not much of a coffee drinker, and I still thought it was quite good.

Overall, every single thing we ate was delicious. The prices were all super cheap, and we walked out of Tadu with our stomachs feeling thoroughly stuffed. I will definitely be back!

excerpts: We got the veggie combo, LENTIL SAMBUSSA (SOO GOOD) and beef tibs for 2 people.
It was wayy plenty of food.
And for a great price :D if you call like 15 mins early, they can try to hold you a table which would probably be worth the effort
cuz its a verryy cozy place, only like 5 or 6 tables and no space to wait for a table to free up inside
so you might have to wait outside in the grimey TL streets which is known to rob you of your appetite.
beef tibs.author: Sara C.
beef tibs.review: The food is delicious, super friendly staff & great service, and the portions were such that I had a full lunch off the leftovers! We got the veggie combo, LENTIL SAMBUSSA (SOO GOOD) and beef tibs for 2 people. It was wayy plenty of food. And for a great price :D if you call like 15 mins early, they can try to hold you a table which would probably be worth the effort cuz its a verryy cozy place, only like 5 or 6 tables and no space to wait for a table to free up inside so you might have to wait outside in the grimey TL streets which is known to rob you of your appetite.

excerpts: -I ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs.
Addicting & Wow.
Two word sums up the beef tibs.
Excellent flavors and spices for the beef tids.
beef tibs.author: P H.
beef tibs.review:
Decor: 4/5
-VERY limited seating
-has incense sticks placed near the tables on the steel beams

Service: 5/5
-very welcoming and homey, our orders were taken at the table and served to the table

Food: 5/5
-First time trying Ethiopian and I'm blown away at how delicious the dishes were.
-I ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs. Addicting & Wow. Two word sums up the beef tibs. Excellent flavors and spices for the beef tids. I didn't know exactly what the vegetarian combination consisted of however each side did not disappoint my adventurous taste buds
-The collard greens, lentils and chickpeas from the vegetarian dish were all great as well.

excerpts: We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination.
Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait
and everything was delicious!
If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special.
But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.
beef tibs.author: Jenny F.
beef tibs.review:
I'm definitely going to be frequenting this restaurant after my first visit tonight.

I've always been a huge fan of Ethiopian cuisine, with New Eritrea being one of my favorite SF spots. The only drawback about New Eritrea is that it's all the way in the Sunset, which isn't very conveniently located for me (but they're still worth the drive)!

But I digress. I was so glad the girlfriend found this spot on Yelp that was so close to where we work and on our way home. When we first walked it, it appears to be completely full, all tables occupied. The sweet owner asked us if we wanted to dine in and pulled out an extra table that fit perfectly in the little nook of space left in the room.

We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination. Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait and everything was delicious! If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special. But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.

If you're on the fence about this place, jump off already! There's a reason they have such high ratings. Great service & amazing food. Let the food speak for itself. :)

excerpts:
We had the beef sambussa to start, and the lamb and beef tibs with injera as entrees. 
The sambussa was a dumpling-like appetizer, with juicy, slightly spicy ground beef wrapped in a perfectly crunchy and flaky shell of dough, and accompanied with a orange dipping sauce which added a ton of seasoning without overpowering the taste of the wrapping or the beef.
beef tibs.author: Caleb W.
beef tibs.review:
I came here on a Monday evening around 8pm with a few friends. While seating is rather sparse, especially for groups larger than two, plenty of seats were available when we walked in.

We had the beef sambussa to start, and the lamb and beef tibs with injera as entrees. 
The sambussa was a dumpling-like appetizer, with juicy, slightly spicy ground beef wrapped in a perfectly crunchy and flaky shell of dough, and accompanied with a orange dipping sauce which added a ton of seasoning without overpowering the taste of the wrapping or the beef. 

The injera was just as it should be, soft and spongy, without being overpowering or too sour. I absolutely recommend the lamb tibs -- tender lamb cubes sautéed with the most delicious caramelized onions, and seasoned heavily with black pepper and not much else. While not readily apparently after the first few bites, the lamb tibs are actually low-key spicy, and will definitely warm you up after a while. 

It's not the best Ethiopian food I've ever had, but it's definitely up there.

excerpts: The beef Tibs has great flavor and is a safe bet for anyone who has never eaten Ethiopian food before.
beef tibs.author: Marc P.
beef tibs.review: This is very good Ethiopian food and the staff is very friendly and accommodating. The beef Tibs has great flavor and is a safe bet for anyone who has never eaten Ethiopian food before. The Sambussa appetizer with beef is also good.

excerpts: Then we ordered lamp and beef tibs.
For beginner you eat with your hands.
No utensils if you wanna
do it right.
Love the flavors and spices they use, bring back memories of my travel to Africa.
Interesting sponge bread made of teff flour (wheat) used to wrap the meat and veggies.
The pepper powder is super spicy!
Be careful a dash can set you on fire and make you go running for more water.
I would definitely come back and try more dishes.
The food is not something I eat everyday.
I'm glad that I found this new gem for Ethiopian cuisine.
beef tibs.author: Hua T.
beef tibs.review: Rainy Friday, decided to try other non typical food out there. Ethiopian food came to mind and found this new cosy place. Really liked the atmosphere here. Friendly staff and great service. It was a quiet night. They kept on coming to our table to check if we were happy with everything. Had ground beef sambussa for appetizers. Then we ordered lamp and beef tibs. For beginner you eat with your hands. No utensils if you wanna do it right. Love the flavors and spices they use, bring back memories of my travel to Africa. Interesting sponge bread made of teff flour (wheat) used to wrap the meat and veggies. The pepper powder is super spicy! Be careful a dash can set you on fire and make you go running for more water. I would definitely come back and try more dishes. The food is not something I eat everyday. I'm glad that I found this new gem for Ethiopian cuisine.

excerpts: We ordered the Kik Alicha, Beef Tibs, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Minchin Wot.
Everything was excellent and well spiced.
beef tibs.author: Chris M.
beef tibs.review:
We stopped in on Sunday after reading reviews on Yelp for this place. We were in the mood for Ethiopian food and most of our usual places were not open until later in the day. What a wonderful find!

We ordered the Kik Alicha, Beef Tibs, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Minchin Wot. Everything was excellent and well spiced. The injera was especially good, not too sour, and service was spot on.

The veggies were fresh and flavorful. The Kik was not too mushy and had a good texture. Both meat dishes were excellent and not overly oily. We brought some of the Minchin home and will using that as a pasta sauce.

They've only been open two months and are working on getting a liquor license, but I highly recommend this place. 

We will be coming back for sure.

So happy to have a new Ethiopian place to enjoy!

excerpts: The chicken tibs are yummy and so is the beef tibs.
Now the chickpea salad appetizer is a must get.
It was fresh and delicious and we were fighting over the last bit.
My usual order is chicken tibs , beef do wat, sambussa , and the salad and the vegetarian platter( I share with my coworkers)
I am going to try the lamb next
and I bet it's as good as the rest.
My only complaint is that I think they calm the spiciness of down for the wimpy American palates.
I will ask for really spicy tibs next time.
beef tibs.author: PeachBrande B.
beef tibs.review:
I love Ethiopian food. Where else can you eat with your hands, make a mess, and generally gorge yourself ? There are a lot of Ethiopian places around but not in my neck of the woods. I work in the Tenderloin and I am often left to walk far to get something to eat on my lunch. I waited with baited breath for this place to open. I would look at it on my way to work which is literally 2 minutes away. The first thing I had was the sambussa. I live meat so ate the meat ones. My partner ( carnivore that he is) loved the lentil sambussa. It is a flavor party in your mouth! The sauce , the meat, the flaky pastry !!! So good! I always burn my mouth because I can't wait for them to cool down and they are made to order so they come out piping hot! 
I take my coworkers as often as I can because one the place is yummy and two I would hate to loose this gem because people ate too scared to try something new. I ordered the Kitfo and didn't quite tell folks that its essentially raw beef and they just loved it! The chicken tibs are yummy and so is the beef tibs. Now the chickpea salad appetizer is a must get. It was fresh and delicious and we were fighting over the last bit. My usual order is chicken tibs , beef do wat, sambussa , and the salad and the vegetarian platter( I share with my coworkers)  I am going to try the lamb next and I bet it's as good as the rest. My only complaint is that I think they calm the spiciness of down for the wimpy American palates. I will ask for really spicy tibs next time. 
All in all the flavor is nice , the people who work there are very kind , and I could eat here everyday if budget would allow it! 

Mmmmmmm I just made myself hungry! I know where I'll be eating Monday for lunch

excerpts: We had the beef tibs and the vegetarian platter.
Their service was absolutely spectacular.
They make you feel like you're at home!
We'll definitely be back!
beef tibs.author: Juan M.
beef tibs.review: This place is great!  The food was simply delicious. We had the beef tibs and the vegetarian platter.  Their service was absolutely spectacular.  They make you feel like you're at home!  We'll definitely be back!

excerpts: I highly recommend the beef tibs, shiro wat, and the vegetarian  combo.
Thank you for a great foodie experience!
beef tibs.author: Ilia M.
beef tibs.review: The food and service are impeccable. You must come visit. They make you feel very special and the food is perfectly seasoned. I highly recommend the beef tibs, shiro wat, and the vegetarian  combo. Thank you for a great foodie experience!

excerpts: Get the beef sambussa, beef tibs, and the vegetarian combo.
Generously feeds 2 people.
beef tibs.author: Adam E.
beef tibs.review: Excellent. Get the beef sambussa, beef tibs, and the vegetarian combo. Generously feeds 2 people.

excerpts: We had Lentil Sambussa (tasty straightforward snack and the accompanying red sauce was great) and Beef Tibs with Injera (simple ingredients and great mix of spices do the trick perfectly
and Injera is to die for).
Servings are generous, one appetizer and one entree easily fed two adults.
Highly recommended, don't get scared by a shabby neighbourhood.
beef tibs.author: Grzegorz J.
beef tibs.review: This place has a modest menu, but is genuine, clean and the food is great. We had Lentil Sambussa (tasty straightforward snack and the accompanying red sauce was great) and Beef Tibs with Injera (simple ingredients and great mix of spices do the trick perfectly and Injera is to die for). Servings are generous, one appetizer and one entree easily fed two adults. Highly recommended, don't get scared by a shabby neighbourhood.

excerpts: The chicken tibs is pretty good
but I like dark than white.
chicken tibs.author: Christy V.
chicken tibs.review:
This place is pretty good.  My first time trying Ethiopian food. Service is good but a bit slow which its because they do get busy which I'm ok with. 4 star from me. 

Flaxseed drink with honey taste like blended peanut butter not to sweet: pretty interesting. The ground beef kitfo cooked medium rare is spicy and good. The chicken tibs is pretty good but I like dark than white. So it does cater for vegetarians and meat eaters. 

A lot of people usually get their veggie combo. Oh and the injera is like a sour dough pancake you use to wrap the food to eat with. You use your hand/fingers and injera to eat the food. 

The place is small so get there when they open or when rush hours are over. I see people usually order togo and from delivery company since the place is small. Tables I see is 4 or less but I'm sure you can squeeze the tables or chairs together for bigger parties if they aren't already filled. 

Fun experience, not everyday kind of food and pretty filling due to the injera. Definitely come again when there's parking. Parking is hard and lots of drugs,homeless and crazy people so just a heads up. Still worth to come by at lease once.

excerpts: Had the chicken tibs and boy was it delicious!
Full of flavor and they give you a side of injera to eat with as well!
The spice can be adjusted with the jalapenos on the side which was a nice touch.
chicken tibs.author: Alan C.
chicken tibs.review:
Coming here late in the evening can be dangerous since it's in the Tenderloin but trust me, the food is well worth the risk!

Had the chicken tibs and boy was it delicious! Full of flavor and they give you a side of injera to eat with as well! The spice can be adjusted with the jalapenos on the side which was a nice touch. Quick service, friendly and helpful staff, and overall great quality of food!

The only reason I gave this place 1 less star is the location. Not exactly the safest neighborhood but well worth the trouble.

excerpts: so we added the "Chicken Tibs" ($9.95).
We opted to have our chicken juicy and they didn't hold back on that
, it was really tasty.
You can see the tomatoes, and jalapeños within the sauces.
Also, the spice level was medium and it does have a hint of pepper and lime taste.
chicken tibs.author: Jon B.
chicken tibs.review:
Tadu is a few blocks from our hotel and it was a good place for casual Ethiopian meals. I was looking forward to it especially, that I seldom get this type of cuisine that consists of vegetables and meats blended in special spices. 

When looking at their menu it took us awhile to figure out what's best. We had to ask if some of their items are portioned enough for three. Thankfully, their menu has a brief description for each item, which most we're not familiar with. But, in the end we left satisfied and what we ordered was mighty tasty. 

We went for the "Vegetarian Combination" ($11.95). Bedded on the bottom is the slightly spongey textured pancake, it tastes like sour bread. Then on the top is the split pea stew, spicy lentils, the tikil gomen its cabbage, potatoes, carrots and right down the middle of the plate is a salad. The vegetarian part alone may sound simple but, it was definitely full of flavor. 

I couldn't live without the meat so we added the "Chicken Tibs" ($9.95). We opted to have our chicken juicy and they didn't hold back on that, it was really tasty. You can see the tomatoes, and jalapeños within the sauces. Also, the spice level was medium and it does have a hint of pepper and lime taste. All I can say the tibs was stewed to perfection. 

Friendly service here, and I notice our server was one the cooks, nice multitasking from her. To dine inside it's a little tight in space when all tables are occupied, but hey  you can't complain about the cool mom and pop restaurant experience in downtown San Francisco. 

Located in the Tenderloin District, let Tadu spice up your lunch and dinner time.

excerpts: I decided to get the Chicken Tibs ($9.95) which is chicken sauteed with Tadu's special sauces, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos and berbere using the on-line ordering app on Yelp.
I got decent sized container having 3 sections, the largest one of which was filled with the Chicken Tibs, while the other two had some salad and green leafy vegetables.
What I liked was they had not tossed the injera on top of the food making it soggy, something that other Ethiopian restaurants are notorious for, but instead had packaged it separately.
Like most Ethiopian restaurants in NorCal the injera lacked the intense sour taste that is typical of injera from restaurants in SoCal.
The chicken tibs were excellent.
They were juicy and had a nice spicy kick.
Even the green leafy vegetables were extremely good.
Overall this turned out to be a very enjoyable meal.
chicken tibs.author: Ahmad J.
chicken tibs.review:
I decided to try Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen for dinner a couple of days ago as it had good ratings on Yelp. While going through its menu I was surprised that it did not have a meat combo (chicken, lamb and beef stew) that I generally get in any new Ethiopian restaurant that I try, as it gives you an opportunity to try different dishes from the restaurant in one go. I decided to get the Chicken Tibs ($9.95) which is chicken sauteed with Tadu's special sauces, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos and berbere using the on-line ordering app on Yelp.

A very painful part of this entire experience was reaching Tadu as it is in the heart of the hood (Tenderloin). While walking from FiDi you will cross a couple of homeless colonies spread out on the pavement and have to shoo off at-least a couple of determined panhandlers before you reach the restaurant. The good news is that my order was ready as soon as I reached and I was on my way back via a slightly longer route back that avoided the worst parts of the hood.

I got decent sized container having 3 sections, the largest one of which was filled with the Chicken Tibs, while the other two had some salad and green leafy vegetables. What I liked was they had not tossed the injera on top of the food making it soggy, something that other Ethiopian restaurants are notorious for, but instead had packaged it separately. Like most Ethiopian restaurants in NorCal the injera lacked the intense sour taste that is typical of injera from restaurants in SoCal. The chicken tibs were excellent. They were juicy and had a nice spicy kick. Even the green leafy vegetables were extremely good. Overall this turned out to be a very enjoyable meal. My only complaint was that this came with only one injera bread, which left me wanting a lot more.

Price wise this particular dish was pretty cheap for Ethiopian restaurant standards. Other items like the beef and lamb tibs were around the $15 mark. If you add another couple of bucks for the second injera you will end up close to the price point of other Ethiopian restaurants, so it's a little bit of smart price management here so as not to price them out of the hood. I'm confident that Tadu is one of the better Ethiopian restaurants that I've been to, even without having had a chance to sample a lot of their dishes at once. Well, it's all the more reason to come back and try them one at a time.

excerpts: We also had chicken tibs and the veggie combo.
As is not too uncommon, the meats were spicy while the veggies were more on the bland side, including the misir wat.
Unfortunately, there is neither wine nor beer available, so we had to do with water.
Overall, if in the area, this place is a great option.
chicken tibs.author: Nobbi L.
chicken tibs.review:
Last weekend we were in SF, and I had to get my Ethiopian fix. As we did not want to go to the East Bay and were staying Downtown, I decided to try out Tadu. As others have noted, it is located in the heart of the Tenderloin which is not for the faint of heart. But then we folks who love unusual cuisines don't get freaked out by bunches of homeless, some of whom you have to step over.

The food was good. The kitfo was prepared raw as we had ordered it. They even brought us some mitmita. We also had chicken tibs and the veggie combo. As is not too uncommon, the meats were spicy while the veggies were more on the bland side, including the misir wat. Unfortunately, there is neither wine nor beer available, so we had to do with water. Overall, if in the area, this place is a great option.

excerpts: We got 2 veggie combos and two sides of chicken tibs and one side of miser wot.
chicken tibs.author: Arthita G.
chicken tibs.review:
We went to Tadu for dinner after watching sunset from battery spencer park. We found valet parking in a nearby garage for about 15 bucks. Street parking is available too but it's a bit challenging to find a spot. Also the neighborhood looks a little unsafe. 

Tadu is a small place and there's around 6-8 tables. We were lucky to find a spot as soon as we walked in. It's a little cramped in there but the we really enjoyed the food. We got 2 veggie combos and two sides of chicken tibs and one side of miser wot. We also tried the Ethiopian coffee and it was so good! The staff were really nice. We had a very satisfying meal.

excerpts: Had the chicken tibs and they were delicious!

They don't sell beer but you're allowed to bring in beer from the outside (liquor store on Jones st) 
Friendly staff.
chicken tibs.author: Joe R.
chicken tibs.review:
Had the chicken tibs and they were delicious! They don't sell beer but you're allowed to bring in beer from the outside (liquor store on Jones st) 
Friendly staff.

excerpts: We got the vegetable combination plate, lentil sambussa, and chicken tibs
and they were all superb.
The chicken tibs was definitely a favorite of ours!
chicken tibs.author: Jacqui C.
chicken tibs.review:
I am absolutely excited to have found this place! The food is authentic with the usual traditional dishes, but they've also made some modern variations which I must come back to try.

The place itself is a small restaurant with an intimate setting of a family-run business. The staff are quick, friendly, and welcoming.

We got the vegetable combination plate, lentil sambussa, and chicken tibs and they were all superb. The chicken tibs was definitely a favorite of ours!

excerpts: We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs.
This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera.
My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs.
SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite.
Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.
chicken tibs.author: Crystal S.
chicken tibs.review: Went here for an early dinner on a Saturday prior to watching a movie. We figured this would be a perfect place as one of our group is a Vegetarian. We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs. This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera. My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs. SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite. Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.

excerpts: We had the vegetarian combo platter and the chicken tibs, which we asked to be brought out together on a big plate with injera underneath & a bountiful basket of rolled injera alongside.
There was
*so
* much food
chicken tibs.author: Lisa K.
chicken tibs.review:
This is a nice little oasis in the tenderloin. I started with the excellent Ethiopian coffee, to which I added ridiculously heavy-seeming cream. We had the vegetarian combo platter and the chicken tibs, which we asked to be brought out together on a big plate with injera underneath & a bountiful basket of rolled injera alongside. There was *so* much food and I thought it was pretty delicious & made for wonderful leftovers.

The biggest difference I found between Tadu & other Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've had is that it tasted a bit "fresher" and less slow-cooked/stewed. I'm not sure if this was a time issue or a stylistic one. Honestly I prefer the long-cooked method where the flavors meld together more and everything softens up, but this was good too. I found it especially noticeable in the gomen (greens) and kik alicha. Also, our alicha tikil gomen ended up being almost entirely cabbage.

excerpts: I ordered the chicken tibs and my friend had the veggie plate and it was served together on the same giant plate.
I also got the ground beef sambussas.
The sambussas were fried perfectly with a sweet dipping sauce.
chicken tibs.author: Lisa X.
chicken tibs.review:
Five stars for the authentic eating experience, service, and amazing food. I ordered the chicken tibs and my friend had the veggie plate and it was served together on the same giant plate. I also got the ground beef sambussas.  The sambussas were fried perfectly with a sweet dipping sauce. The chicken had so much flavor from the spices, peppers and onions. 

Tadu is deep into the tenderloin. My friend and I had to dodge piles of poo and she gagged the entire way from the urine soaked sidewalk. It was worth the trip, though!

excerpts: I ordered chicken tibs.
The entrees come with unlimited injera bread and a cabbage side.
The food was really amazing for both of us
and we sure shall be here again.
Keep it going guys!
chicken tibs.author: Neil S.
chicken tibs.review:
Great food, great service!
We came in here on a week night. Since my wife is a vegetarian, she ordered Misir Wot. I ordered chicken tibs. The entrees come with unlimited injera bread and a cabbage side. 
The food was really amazing for both of us and we sure shall be here again. Keep it going guys!

excerpts: We ordered the sambussas (both veggie and beef), which were very good, along with the vegetarian combination plate and the chicken tibs.
I liked that everything was presented on a large injera, so that all of the juices could soak in.
The food was very tasty, although not noteworthy.
The ambiance (or lack thereof) of the space made it less of an enjoyable experience.
Plus, given the small space and lack of music, you could overhear all of the conversations around us.
I'm sure they are running a clean kitchen
but the space just felt tired and a bit rundown; I think it really needs a complete interior renovation.
I think if we eat here again, it will be take out rather than sit down.
chicken tibs.author: Regina L.
chicken tibs.review:
My husband and I love Ethiopian food, so we were very excited to learn about Tadu. We came relatively early on a Saturday evening and there was a pretty long line already. We were hoping that the line would move quickly, but given how small their space is, it took longer than the time quoted. Normally I wouldn't mind but the restaurant is in a BAD area; during our wait we saw a drug deal occur two doors down, and we were constantly yelled at or solicited by passerbys. When we finally sat down, I realized how small their actual kitchen was and worried that we might be waiting quite some time for our food. Thankfully orders were placed quickly and food came out relatively regularly and quickly. 

We ordered the sambussas (both veggie and beef), which were very good, along with the vegetarian combination plate and the chicken tibs. I liked that everything was presented on a large injera, so that all of the juices could soak in. The food was very tasty, although not noteworthy. The ambiance (or lack thereof) of the space made it less of an enjoyable experience.  Plus, given the small space and lack of music, you could overhear all of the conversations around us. I'm sure they are running a clean kitchen but the space just felt tired and a bit rundown; I think it really needs a complete interior renovation. I think if we eat here again, it will be take out rather than sit down.

excerpts: We ordered the lamb and chicken tibs and the veggie sampler.
All of it was amazing.
It had been forever since I had had Ethiopian, but this was definitely some of the better dishes I've had.
The lamb and chicken was super tender and simmered in some amazing sauces - deep and rich with spices on the lamb.
My favorite veggie were the collard greens, they were tangy and delish, and not overcooked and wimpy like greens can tend to get.
chicken tibs.author: Rory J.
chicken tibs.review:
So I probably should have read the review a little closer when I went here - I was definitely under the impression that it was a sit-down, full on restaurant. It's more like a fast casual model with amazing food. Something I'd never experience with Ethiopian before - I usually prepare my self for a 2+ hour experience when doing Ethiopian. 

Small tables, limited menu, no booze (pretty sure). But super friendly people that were more than happy to provide some recommendations for us. 

We ordered the lamb and chicken tibs and the veggie sampler. All of it was amazing. It had been forever since I had had Ethiopian, but this was definitely some of the better dishes I've had. The lamb and chicken was super tender and simmered in some amazing sauces - deep and rich with spices on the lamb. My favorite veggie were the collard greens, they were tangy and delish, and not overcooked and wimpy like greens can tend to get.

excerpts: Our really nice server recommended that we split the lamb and chicken tibs and veggie platter between three people.
He was really patient about explaining the various dishes and that the injera (Ethiopian sourdough bread with the consistency of a spongy crepe) was unlimited!
To eat the meal, you rip the bread and use it to pick up various cooked meats and vegetables.
It's a really social experience among friends, since everyone is reaching into and eating from the same communal platter.
There was a wide variety of spices, textures, and flavors featured on the platter.
Everything tasted pretty amazing, and we were very satisfied by the end of the meal.
chicken tibs.author: Brittany C.
chicken tibs.review:
Tadu is in the heart of the Tenderloin, so don't be surprised by the neighboring sights (and smells). But hey, the Tenderloin is also where you can get fantastic food of all kinds without spending a ton of money, and Tadu is no exception to this.

Once you find the restaurant and walk in, you'll notice that there isn't much in the way of decor (or seating). But don't be deceived by the sketchy surroundings and unassuming decor, the food is great and the staff are so friendly!

Our really nice server recommended that we split the lamb and chicken tibs and veggie platter between three people. He was really patient about explaining the various dishes and that the injera (Ethiopian sourdough bread with the consistency of a spongy crepe) was unlimited! To eat the meal, you rip the bread and use it to pick up various cooked meats and vegetables. It's a really social experience among friends, since everyone is reaching into and eating from the same communal platter. There was a wide variety of spices, textures, and flavors featured on the platter. Everything tasted pretty amazing, and we were very satisfied by the end of the meal. We were even more satisfied to discover that this very filling and enjoyable dinner cost us less than $15 each!

I probably never would have found this place if my friend hadn't insisted on "Ethiopian food" for dinner, but I'm glad he did, because the Yelp reviews don't lie -- this place is a hole-in-the-wall treasure!

excerpts: My picky 5 yr old ate a ton of chicken tibs and
chicken tibs.author: Nhieu w.
chicken tibs.review: My girls told me I had to give them five stars! My picky 5 yr old ate a ton of chicken tibs and my 7 yr old love the special kitfo.

excerpts: The chicken tibs here is amazing and would totally recommend ordering it with the veggie combo .
chicken tibs.author: Anand S.
chicken tibs.review: The best Ethiopian food I have had in the US. The chicken tibs here is amazing and would totally recommend ordering it with the veggie combo .

excerpts: The veggie combo and chicken tibs tasted so fresh and full of flavor.
The staff was friendly.
The prices were reasonable.
chicken tibs.author: Tim B.
chicken tibs.review:
Oakland and Berkeley have long bested San Francisco when it comes to quantity and quality of Ethiopian/Eritrean food, but with the recent opening of Tadu, the scales may finally be tipping. This was the best Ethiopian meal I've had in SF. 

The veggie combo and chicken tibs tasted so fresh and full of flavor. The staff was friendly. The prices were reasonable. And with its high ceilings, vibrant paint and exposed steel beams, the small seating area felt relaxed and unimposing.

Ask for the not-so-spicy "spicy sauce," a traditional housemade awaze sauce that complements the flavors if you need a little something extra.

excerpts: Got the veggie combo and the chicken tibs and ate it all.
It was on the spicy side
so I guess my punk status when it comes to spice has been solidified.
What happened to me?
Anyhow the hub almost ate a big old slice of jalapeño from the tibs bc he thought it was a bell pepper.
I saved his life before he bit into it like a good wife.
It was plenty of food including he basket of injera that accompanied it.
We both resolved to try the one Ethiopian restaurant in Honolulu again even though we were disappointed
he first time.
Bc tadu reminded us how much we looooooove this cuisine.
We decided even more than North Indian food.
But since we soft now we ubered it there and back.
(Were we ever not soft?)
I think since even ny was so safe before we left we just can handle any non gentrified areas anymore.
Punks.
That's us.
chicken tibs.author: Jannet L.
chicken tibs.review: I've definitely gotten soft living in Honolulu enough so that I was intimidated by the neighborhood and a little uneasy when we arrived at the restaurant and had to wait outside for a table. Only three people running he restaurant and they were hustling. No one to really man the front of the place but since he place is tiny you can see the entire restaurant and kitchen from the front. Anyhow service is fast and friendly and food comes out quick. So we got a table pretty quickly.  But no one taking names. You just wait until a table opens up and seat yourself. The place is small and bare bones but clean and bright. Somehow seems more legit than the other Ethiopian place we were considering which serves brunch and burgers etc. but maybe that's regular Ethiopian fare too? Anyhow the food was worth waiting and delicious and I miss Ethiopian food very much. Despite being busy the service was friendly and warm and food came out quick hot and delicious. Got the veggie combo and the chicken tibs and ate it all. It was on the spicy side so I guess my punk status when it comes to spice has been solidified. What happened to me? Anyhow the hub almost ate a big old slice of jalapeño from the tibs bc he thought it was a bell pepper. I saved his life before he bit into it like a good wife. It was plenty of food including he basket of injera that accompanied it. We both resolved to try the one Ethiopian restaurant in Honolulu again even though we were disappointed he first time. Bc tadu reminded us how much we looooooove this cuisine. We decided even more than North Indian food. But since we soft now we ubered it there and back. (Were we ever not soft?) I think since even ny was so safe before we left we just can handle any non gentrified areas anymore. Punks. That's us.

excerpts: I got the chicken tibs and it did not disappoint!
The meal came with injera, chicken, salad, lentils, and more injera on the side.
chicken tibs.author: Aimee Z.
chicken tibs.review:
I got the chicken tibs and it did not disappoint! The meal came with injera, chicken, salad, lentils, and more injera on the side. Ethiopian food is made to eat with your hands, but alas I resorted to using a fork. 

Service was really nice and fairly quick. The portion size was quite generous (not to mention you can always eat a lot of injera). For people not familiar with Ethiopian food, it's actually surprisingly similar to Indian food in taste. Injera is a spongy bread like side that's soft in texture. 

The price was also great- $9.95 for a delicious, filling meal! =]

excerpts: We had Chicken tibs, Veggie combo with Injeras..
The chicken was sooo good!
I can still taste it, a must must have!
chicken tibs.author: Nupur K.
chicken tibs.review:
Great food, warm staff, super cheap!
