We had Chicken tibs, Veggie combo with Injeras.. The chicken was sooo good! I can still taste it, a must must have! They also carry Ethiopian coffee - highly recommended! I may sound crazy but I also highly appreciate them giving wet wipes post food, with all that finger licking chicken and spicy lentil I needed that! 

Why 4/5 then? coz I've had better yellow lentil and cabbage.

excerpts:
We ordered the vegetarian combination (great way to sample all of the vegetarian dishes instead of ordering just one), the chicken tibs, and the beef firfir. 

Got the chicken tibs as "spicy" as well but it definitely didn't have nearly as much kick as the beef firfir.
On wait times - came here on a Saturday night near closing time (8:40 pm) and they let us in
chicken tibs.author: Sylvia L.
chicken tibs.review:
Servings here are generous. We ordered the vegetarian combination (great way to sample all of the vegetarian dishes instead of ordering just one), the chicken tibs, and the beef firfir. 

Tips:
If you like spicy - go with the Firfir (beef, not the lamb - they said they can't make the lamb as spicy). Got the chicken tibs as "spicy" as well but it definitely didn't have nearly as much kick as the beef firfir.
On wait times - came here on a Saturday night near closing time (8:40 pm) and they let us in (there was even a waiting line); pretty sure they kept letting people in around 9pm and maybe 10 minutes after.

All in all - the food was good but it wasn't mindblowingly better than Moya (I actually thought it was on par) so I think I'll stick with ordering from Moya and then eating at the City Beer Store (they let you bring food in) so that I can have delicious Ethiopian with delicious beer :).

excerpts: The veggie combo and chicken tibs were plenty of food for two guys who just rode 18 miles on bike and ran another 4 miles.
Highly recommend the drink, "telba"--roasted then ground flax seeds in water and sweetened with honey.
chicken tibs.author: Christopher W.
chicken tibs.review:
I rarely give 5 star reviews on a first visit, but felt compelled to do so for Tadu. Right off the bat we were greeted and offered a seat. Throughout the visit there were friendly vibes all around.

The veggie combo and chicken tibs were plenty of food for two guys who just rode 18 miles on bike and ran another 4 miles. Highly recommend the drink, "telba"--roasted then ground flax seeds in water and sweetened with honey. Very refreshing.

Really hope that Tadu thrives in the neighborhood. I managed to get a couple looking through the window to come in after I gave them the "two thumbs up" gesture! Will be back with friends.

excerpts: Had the chicken tibs with injera and the ritko sandwich.
The ayub cheese will change your life.
chicken tibs.author: Alyson S.
chicken tibs.review:
So freaaaaaaking delicious. I've only just started trying Ethiopian food, and let me just say, if you haven't tried it you're missing out. Had the chicken tibs with injera and the ritko sandwich. The ayub cheese will change your life. Don't forget to finish off with some Ethiopian coffee (seriously, the best coffee, and starting to be come my absolute favorite).

Great service and great food. Will be back again!

excerpts: Ordered a Vegetarian combination and Chicken Tibs.
chicken tibs.author: Pranav B.
chicken tibs.review:
I had read a lot about this place on Yelp and have seen in consistently rated in the Top 10 SFO restaurants. This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and needless to say, I absolutely loved it. Ordered a Vegetarian combination and Chicken Tibs. Really loved the Misir Wot and Shiro Wot . The rest of the lentils and salads were alright. 

Cons: It is located in the Tenderloin area, which is a sketchy neighbourhood. Also, I wish the Injera were served hot.

Mentioned the cons to the owner and he took my review positively. Overall, anyone in SFO city should check out this place.

excerpts: Loved the sambusas and beef and chicken tibs.
Everything tasted super fresh and was visually appealing, which can be difficult with lentils and such.
Very nice owner and staff as well.
chicken tibs.author: Rowena L.
chicken tibs.review: Super delicious Ethiopian food. Loved the sambusas and beef and chicken tibs. Everything tasted super fresh and was visually appealing, which can be difficult with lentils and such. Very nice owner and staff as well.

excerpts: we ordered veg combo wand chicken tibs...
I liked the chicken tibs more.
my buddy was vegetarian ...
he had the veg combo and was little bit bland .. if it was spicy would have been much better
chicken tibs.author: Pavan N.
chicken tibs.review: Ethiopian food.. Im trying for the first time. Me and my buddy went to the place. Nice service. Not a big dine in...neighbourhood wasnt great... but the food was good.. we ordered veg combo wand chicken tibs... I liked the chicken tibs more. my buddy was vegetarian ... he had the veg combo and was little bit bland .. if it was spicy would have been much better

excerpts: Try the chicken tibs!
chicken tibs.author: Rohit B.
chicken tibs.review:
Been here twice for Ethiopian in the last week and the food is awesome! Try the chicken tibs! Customer service is pretty good - the first time I was there, they even served complimentary dessert! 

The prices are very reasonable and both times we had some leftovers. Take them in a box even if you don't need them - instead give them to one of the homeless folks on the street outside.

excerpts: So the first time I got food from Tadu, I gave him a taste of the perfectly spiced misir from my veggie combo and of the chicken tibs, and he was a convert.
The food is always ready quickly, and the person at the counter is as friendly as can be.
I finish work at 10 and find myself craving these dishes all week, so
the only way this could be better is if there were delivery and later hours.
Then I could have it everyday.
chicken tibs.author: Heather H.
chicken tibs.review:
Love! I am thrilled to have an Ethiopian restaurant closer to home. Traditionally, my partner and I would pickup takeout from different restaurants when I would get Ethiopian food, because he thought he didn't like it (which I could never understand). So the first time I got food from Tadu, I gave him a taste of the perfectly spiced misir from my veggie combo and of the chicken tibs, and he was a convert. 
The food is always ready quickly, and the person at the counter is as friendly as can be.  I finish work at 10 and find myself craving these dishes all week, so the only way this could be better is if there were delivery and later hours. Then I could have it everyday.

excerpts: Shared the vegetarian combo and chicken tibs all on the same plate with two other people.
All delicious!
chicken tibs.author: Nandita V.
chicken tibs.review: Great food. Shared the vegetarian combo and chicken tibs all on the same plate with two other people. All delicious!

excerpts: The chicken tibs are yummy and so is the beef tibs.
Now the chickpea salad appetizer is a must get.
It was fresh and delicious and we were fighting over the last bit.
My usual order is chicken tibs , beef do wat, sambussa , and the salad and the vegetarian platter( I share with my coworkers)
I am going to try the lamb next
and I bet it's as good as the rest.
My only complaint is that I think they calm the spiciness of down for the wimpy American palates.
I will ask for really spicy tibs next time.
chicken tibs.author: PeachBrande B.
chicken tibs.review:
I love Ethiopian food. Where else can you eat with your hands, make a mess, and generally gorge yourself ? There are a lot of Ethiopian places around but not in my neck of the woods. I work in the Tenderloin and I am often left to walk far to get something to eat on my lunch. I waited with baited breath for this place to open. I would look at it on my way to work which is literally 2 minutes away. The first thing I had was the sambussa. I live meat so ate the meat ones. My partner ( carnivore that he is) loved the lentil sambussa. It is a flavor party in your mouth! The sauce , the meat, the flaky pastry !!! So good! I always burn my mouth because I can't wait for them to cool down and they are made to order so they come out piping hot! 
I take my coworkers as often as I can because one the place is yummy and two I would hate to loose this gem because people ate too scared to try something new. I ordered the Kitfo and didn't quite tell folks that its essentially raw beef and they just loved it! The chicken tibs are yummy and so is the beef tibs. Now the chickpea salad appetizer is a must get. It was fresh and delicious and we were fighting over the last bit. My usual order is chicken tibs , beef do wat, sambussa , and the salad and the vegetarian platter( I share with my coworkers)  I am going to try the lamb next and I bet it's as good as the rest. My only complaint is that I think they calm the spiciness of down for the wimpy American palates. I will ask for really spicy tibs next time. 
All in all the flavor is nice , the people who work there are very kind , and I could eat here everyday if budget would allow it! 

Mmmmmmm I just made myself hungry! I know where I'll be eating Monday for lunch

excerpts: We enjoyed a vegetable combination plate and chicken tibs.
Generous portions and very tasty.
We took Uber afterward as we are not from this area and weren't sure about the safety of the location.
chicken tibs.author: L M.
chicken tibs.review: A cozy nicely decorated location in Tenderloin. The staff was very kind and helpful. We enjoyed a vegetable combination plate and chicken tibs. Generous portions and very tasty. We took Uber afterward as we are not from this area and weren't sure about the safety of the location.

excerpts: My 12 year old daughter also loved it, particularly the chicken tibs!
We will be back for sure.
chicken tibs.author: Sy D.
chicken tibs.review: Super fresh food by lovely people. They were warm and generous from the moment we sat down. The food is balanced so well, and full of flavor. My 12 year old daughter also loved it, particularly the chicken tibs! We will be back for sure.

excerpts: The lamb and chicken tibs were delicious, and the beef wot dish was a great new flavor we hadn't tried yet.
Elias brought us a couple of other flavors just to enhance our experience; a chick pea puree and another chicken dish I can't pronounce.
All were fantastic.
We finished off with baklava for dessert.
We left my wife's yellow rose at the table, and Elias brought it all the way down the street to us himself.
God bless you!
chicken tibs.author: Joe H.
chicken tibs.review: We came over from Houston to see the SF sites and ran across Tadu on our bus tour. A small, traditional restaurant with about 8 tables, it has family-style Ethiopian dining where the entrees are served on a big round piece of injera bread. We were treated to personal service by Elias, the owner, himself. We love Ethiopian flavors, and nothing disappointed here. The sambussa appetizers were a crisp start. The lamb and chicken tibs were delicious, and the beef wot dish was a great new flavor we hadn't tried yet. Elias brought us a couple of other flavors just to enhance our experience; a chick pea puree and another chicken dish I can't pronounce. All were fantastic. We finished off with baklava for dessert. We left my wife's yellow rose at the table, and Elias brought it all the way down the street to us himself. God bless you!

excerpts: We loved the chicken tibs, it was seriously amazing!
The owner was very nice.
This is a fabulous restaurant and you must definitely go there for the super food!
chicken tibs.author: Tashi W.
chicken tibs.review: Great food! Devoured 2 baskets of injera and 2 plates of stuffing! We loved the chicken tibs, it was seriously amazing! The owner was very nice. This is a fabulous restaurant and you must definitely go there for the super food!

excerpts: Will definitely come back, as I'd like to try the lamb tibs and the vegetarian combination next
lamb tibs.author: Kevin P.
lamb tibs.review:
Food was very good - I ordered the special kitfo, medium rare, which was served with some injera bread
Staff were extremely friendly
Will definitely come back, as I'd like to try the lamb tibs and the vegetarian combination next

excerpts: Other items like the beef and lamb tibs were around the $15 mark.

If you add another couple of bucks for the second injera you will end up close to the price point of other Ethiopian restaurants, so it's a little bit of smart price management here so as not to price them out of the hood.
I'm confident that Tadu is one of the better Ethiopian restaurants that I've been to, even without having had a chance to sample a lot of their dishes at once.
Well, it's all the more reason to come back and try them one at a time.
lamb tibs.author: Ahmad J.
lamb tibs.review:
I decided to try Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen for dinner a couple of days ago as it had good ratings on Yelp. While going through its menu I was surprised that it did not have a meat combo (chicken, lamb and beef stew) that I generally get in any new Ethiopian restaurant that I try, as it gives you an opportunity to try different dishes from the restaurant in one go. I decided to get the Chicken Tibs ($9.95) which is chicken sauteed with Tadu's special sauces, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos and berbere using the on-line ordering app on Yelp.

A very painful part of this entire experience was reaching Tadu as it is in the heart of the hood (Tenderloin). While walking from FiDi you will cross a couple of homeless colonies spread out on the pavement and have to shoo off at-least a couple of determined panhandlers before you reach the restaurant. The good news is that my order was ready as soon as I reached and I was on my way back via a slightly longer route back that avoided the worst parts of the hood.

I got decent sized container having 3 sections, the largest one of which was filled with the Chicken Tibs, while the other two had some salad and green leafy vegetables. What I liked was they had not tossed the injera on top of the food making it soggy, something that other Ethiopian restaurants are notorious for, but instead had packaged it separately. Like most Ethiopian restaurants in NorCal the injera lacked the intense sour taste that is typical of injera from restaurants in SoCal. The chicken tibs were excellent. They were juicy and had a nice spicy kick. Even the green leafy vegetables were extremely good. Overall this turned out to be a very enjoyable meal. My only complaint was that this came with only one injera bread, which left me wanting a lot more.

Price wise this particular dish was pretty cheap for Ethiopian restaurant standards. Other items like the beef and lamb tibs were around the $15 mark. If you add another couple of bucks for the second injera you will end up close to the price point of other Ethiopian restaurants, so it's a little bit of smart price management here so as not to price them out of the hood. I'm confident that Tadu is one of the better Ethiopian restaurants that I've been to, even without having had a chance to sample a lot of their dishes at once. Well, it's all the more reason to come back and try them one at a time.

excerpts: Lamb tibs - Bomb.com
...order it, don't look back, and just put it in your mouth.
lamb tibs.author: Jen W.
lamb tibs.review:
Such a hidden, hole in the wall...that every local person who loves ethiopian food knows about!  Haha.  I don't exactly know what authentic ethiopian food is but I eat it enough to know exactly what I like.  Tadu is up there with the best of them.  It's located right smack in the middle of the TL...the beautiful scent of urine just a few steps away.  Don't even think about that and just go in to experience some deliciousness.

Two must haves:  

Special kitfo - typically eaten rare but we went with medium rare.  This is Tadu's most beloved dish and what they're known for.  It's pretty much ground beef with jalapeños and seasoning.  Don't ask me what seasoning cause I have absolutely no idea!

Lamb tibs - Bomb.com...order it, don't look back, and just put it in your mouth.  Mmhmm...

Don't forget the injera.  If you need more, you can always ask but they give you plenty.  

The place is super small so you might have to wait for a table.  It appeared that most peeps ordered togo.  Super affordable prices.  Friendly peeps.

excerpts:
Lamb tibs: spicy sautéed lamb and lamb ribs with bellpeppers onions and jalapeños that came with a lentil sauce, cabbage/ carrot turmeric sauce, of course about a pound of injera and this delightful herbed micro ricotta (ayub) and berbere 13.95$, 

veggie medley with bellpeppers, onions and mushrooms 9.95$ spicy and complemented the protein

ground beef sambussas 4$ for 3, similar to a wonton or jamaican meat patty with meat; with a side of delicious spicy sauce that had Turmeric
lamb tibs.author: Megan K.
lamb tibs.review:
Mmmm! Hearty spicy Ethiopian made with love :) 
S
Light lunch turned into a feast. I only ordered 3 items for the two of us. 

Lamb tibs: spicy sautéed lamb and lamb ribs with bellpeppers onions and jalapeños that came with a lentil sauce, cabbage/ carrot turmeric sauce, of course about a pound of injera and this delightful herbed micro ricotta (ayub) and berbere 13.95$, 

veggie medley with bellpeppers, onions and mushrooms 9.95$ spicy and complemented the protein

ground beef sambussas 4$ for 3, similar to a wonton or jamaican meat patty with meat; with a side of delicious spicy sauce that had Turmeric and I think harissa. Definitely ordering again! 

Delish! 
We also had Ethiopian coffee which was extremely strong, like a slow drip black americano. Crack!

And the kelba, (cant wait to try at home to incorporate into smoothies) a rich yet refreshing slightly sweet blend of flaxseeds and honey.

Service was extremely friendly and warm and I believe the owner was our server. They know how to run a business. Bravo!

excerpts: Our go-to main course is the Vegetarian combination and lamb tibs.
Veg combo comes with lentils, wat, collard greens and cabbage served on a big-ass injera.
And more rolled up slices of injera are served in a basket to keep you going.
3 different kinds of wats are served which have a lil kick to it.
I can eat just the lentils with injera all day long.
Also try their Ethiopian tea with honey.
lamb tibs.author: Sujeesha V.
lamb tibs.review:
My all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco!

This is a cute little hole-in-the-wall kinda place with colorful Ethiopian vibes. This place is located in super shady Tenderloin area of SF. So, uber. Uber. UBER (or Lyft, whatever). Crew is just Wonderful and they invite us in with a Big smile that is sooo contagious. They are very attentive and agnostic to your needs.

Our favorite appetizer here is the Fitfit and close second is Beef sambussa. Fitfit has this surprising tanginess to it that just wakes up your taste buds preparing your tongue for the awesomeness that is yet to be served in the name of main course.

Our go-to main course is the Vegetarian combination and lamb tibs. Veg combo comes with lentils, wat, collard greens and cabbage served on a big-ass injera. And more rolled up slices of injera are served in a basket to keep you going. 3 different kinds of wats are served which have a lil kick to it. I can eat just the lentils with injera all day long. Also try their Ethiopian tea with honey. Perfect compliment to the flavor profile going on in your mouth.

The spicy hot powder that is served as a side IS. THE. BOMB. Just sprinkle a lil bit on your injera before diving into the dips and you can thank me later!

Fun fact: just gotta check mark on the receipt to tip, which makes tipping a no-brainer. Ain't that awesome? :D

My Ethiopian friend vouches for this place and so do I. Try it out. You wont regret it.

excerpts: For two people, a Veggie Combo Platter plus Lamb Tibs was more than enough.
In fact we were stuffed silly but a good kind of full since the food was so delicious!
The veggie platter came with yellow & red lentils as well as collard greens.
My favorites were the lamb tibs & yellow lentils.
I love the experience of eating Ethiopian food because it's very colorful & the spongy injera is the perfect way to scoop up bite sizes of deliciousness.
lamb tibs.author: Ruby C.
lamb tibs.review:
I've had this spot bookmarked for the longest time since I love Ethiopian food -- glad I finally had a chance to try it!

Nice small family run restaurant with impeccable service. They checked on us multiple times to see how the food was & if we needed anything. Like all the Ethiopian restaurants I've been to (& it's honestly quite a few!), there's a sink outside the restroom since it's customary to eat with your hands. Look mom, no utensils! 

We started off with the Beef Sambussa appetizer which was perfectly crispy & very flavorful -- a must order! If you're not quite sure what to order, the veggie combo platter is a good place to start & to that depending on how hungry you are, you can add some protein dishes. For two people, a Veggie Combo Platter plus Lamb Tibs was more than enough. In fact we were stuffed silly but a good kind of full since the food was so delicious! The veggie platter came with yellow & red lentils as well as collard greens. My favorites were the lamb tibs & yellow lentils. I love the experience of eating Ethiopian food because it's very colorful & the spongy injera is the perfect way to scoop up bite sizes of deliciousness. They must've recognized my friend who is a regular since they gave us complimentary dessert.

Perfect for smaller parties. It's a small spot so if you come with a party larger than 4 you might have some difficulty finding a large enough table. They deliver via Eat24. 

Tadu, thanks for the wonderful food & great service. Looking forward to the next visit!

excerpts: We ordered the beef sambussa, veggie combo and lamb tibs.
Sambussa were flavorful and perfectly crisp.
The lamb tibs were cooked perfectly!
The njera here is really light:airy and not too sour.
lamb tibs.author: Semuteh F.
lamb tibs.review:
Excellent food and service! We had a great experience at Tadu from the moment we walked in. The space is small but we got a table for two immediately at 8:15 on a Saturday night. We ordered the beef sambussa, veggie combo and lamb tibs. Sambussa were flavorful and perfectly crisp. They also came with a really good dipping sauce (next time I'll ask them to keep that at the table for the meal--it's a great condiment).

Veggie combo and lamb were perfect. I liked the lentil wat and cabbage/potato the best. We weren't crazy about the salad in the middle. The lamb tibs were cooked perfectly! The njera here is really light:airy and not too sour. It was the perfect accompaniment!

For about $40 including tip, this is now one of our favorite places in the nabe.

excerpts: We got the veggie platter and the lamb tibs.
Super delicious.
Love the Ethiopian bread that's soaked with the lamb sauce.
lamb tibs.author: Rebecca C.
lamb tibs.review:
Love this little hole in the wall with super authentic Ethiopian food. My Ethiopian friend highly recommended this place. Also another added benefit: no corkage for wine served! We got the veggie platter and the lamb tibs. Super delicious. Love the Ethiopian bread that's soaked with the lamb sauce. Get the moderate spice to have a bit kick in the food. 

Service is great. Fantastic for a laid back night and we will be back!

excerpts: We tried: the lamb tibs (great quality lamb, though I did feel it was a little too salty), the michet abish wot

(I hadn't had that *specific* wot before, so I can't compare it exactly, but it was one of the best ground beef-based Ethiopian dishes I've had, plus I'm always happier when Ethiopian dishes come with ayib, which, theirs was some of the best in that respect too), and the veggie combo, which was also great.
lamb tibs.author: Adam F.
lamb tibs.review:
Was here for dinner last night, after getting to see Hamilton (bragbragbrag). First off, yes, the reviews mentioning the unsavoriness of the neighborhood have a bit of a point. I really thought they were exaggerating - it's SF, not Compton, right? - but yeah... it's only 4 blocks from Orpheum Theater, but during that 4 block walk, my wife was catcalled by two different homeless people. 

Worth it, though - we have had a lot of Ethiopian food, in a lot of cities, and this is up there. It's not at all fancy, but the food is excellent. We tried: the lamb tibs (great quality lamb, though I did feel it was a little too salty), the michet abish wot (I hadn't had that *specific* wot before, so I can't compare it exactly, but it was one of the best ground beef-based Ethiopian dishes I've had, plus I'm always happier when Ethiopian dishes come with ayib, which, theirs was some of the best in that respect too), and the veggie combo, which was also great. 3 dishes for 4 people pretty much filled us up (though my mom doesn't eat that much, or we probably would've wanted one more). 

I want to specifically call out their injera, which I think was the tastiest, most flavorful injera I'd ever had (maybe whatever's in the SF water that makes their sourdough so good?) I also want to call out how fast we got our food after we ordered - normally I expect Ethiopian restaurants to run a bit slowly, but we got our food in like a few minutes, despite how fresh it clearly was. We also asked what "telba" was (I haven't seen that before), and were given free samples of it (which was good, as it was totally not what I was expecting, and I would not have enjoyed it - tasty enough, but way too thick to be particularly refreshing), and when my wife ordered a baklava for dessert, instead they gave us one for free. My mom also said the coffee was excellent (I'm not remotely an expert on coffee, so I can't corroborate, but she is, so I trust her.) 

Highly recommended. Though yeah, don't come here with a group larger than 4 (even that was a little bit of a stretch), and maybe don't walk here by yourself after dark.

excerpts: The lamb tibs are to die for and so is the special kitfo--rare of course!
Any-who, I've had everything on the menu and you truly cannot go wrong.
The vegetarian options are sooo good, you don't even realize you're missing out on eating meat.
What better way to support locality, diversity, culture and FOOD in sf.
lamb tibs.author: Angela N.
lamb tibs.review:
Fantastic family run Ethiopian food. I've been here every month with my boyfriend for two years and can't stop. Sometime twice a month if we're feeling it. Been to several other places in sf and the east bay and nothing compares. The folks here are endearing and so friendly. Super fast in food prep. I always bring new folks here, because it's the best food in my opinion around. Heart, soul, culture, spice and love. The lamb tibs are to die for and so is the special kitfo--rare of course! Any-who, I've had everything on the menu and you truly cannot go wrong. The vegetarian options are sooo good, you don't even realize you're missing out on eating meat. What better way to support locality, diversity, culture and FOOD in sf. Be ready to eat with your hands!

Hands down to these guys. Small kitchen and staff, but fantastic service and food. Never longer than 30mins.

excerpts: We ordered the Veggies Combo and the Lamb Tibs - which is SUPER spicy, but tasty.
The neighborhood is a bit dirty since it's downtown SF, but thumbs up to the restaurant.
It's pretty small, but the staff makes up for it.
Baklava for dessert also really tasty!
They do deliveries
lamb tibs.author: Bruna D.
lamb tibs.review:
That's the third Ethiopian restaurant I've been to in SF, and by far the best one! Prices are reasonable, perfect amount of food (we had a bit leftovers). We ordered the Veggies Combo and the Lamb Tibs - which is SUPER spicy, but tasty. The neighborhood is a bit dirty since it's downtown SF, but thumbs up to the restaurant. It's pretty small, but the staff makes up for it. Baklava for dessert also really tasty!
They do deliveries

excerpts: The food here is incredible, and I'm starting to crave the Lamb Tibs and House Salad as I'm sitting here and writing this review.
The Lamb Tibs were incredible.
Very fresh, flavorful, and filling.
I especially loved the house salad.
It sounds simple, but the dressing is so so addicting.
Personally I could not finish this plate alone, but then again I have a tiny appetite.
I'll be back very soon and very often!
lamb tibs.author: Stefanie C.
lamb tibs.review:
The next time someone comes to visit San Francisco and asks me where to eat, this will be at the top of my list of recommendations!! I have not had Ethiopian food in years, and Tadu reminded me of everything I was missing out on. The food here is incredible, and I'm starting to crave the Lamb Tibs and House Salad as I'm sitting here and writing this review. 

I came here at around 6:30 PM on a Friday evening. That or earlier is probably the best time to show up, because there are only a handful number of tables in this restaurant, and by the time I left with my friends, there were tons of people waiting outside. On that note, come with 2 to 4 people per table. This is not designed for large groups.

The Lamb Tibs were incredible. Very fresh, flavorful, and filling. I especially loved the house salad. It sounds simple, but the dressing is so so addicting. Personally I could not finish this plate alone, but then again I have a tiny appetite. I'll be back very soon and very often!

excerpts: I ordered beef sambussa for an appetizer and the vegetable combo with lamb tibs for my entree, which could have served 2-3 people.
Wish I could have brought my leftovers back home with me
but unfortunately I had to head straight to the airport afterwards for a flight.
The beef sambussa came with a spicy sauce and was piping hot and delicious.
It was a bit on the greasy side, but extremely yummy.
The vegetable combo and lamb tibs was presented on an unfurled piece of injera, which is a spongey sort of flatbread.
The first thing I thought of when I looked at it was my slight case of "trypophobia
" (don't look it up on Google if you're uncomfortable with images of clustered, small holes)...but the subtle taste and texture was amazing.
There was also a side of extra rolled up injera for you to eat the wat (Ethiopian stew that has a similar consistency to hummus).
I personally LOVED the types of wat I got -
they were so flavorful and some of them definitely had a kick to them.
The lamb tibs were also quite yummy
lamb tibs.author: Katherine Z.
lamb tibs.review:
My first time trying Ethiopian food and Tadu did not disappoint! I ordered beef sambussa for an appetizer and the vegetable combo with lamb tibs for my entree, which could have served 2-3 people. Wish I could have brought my leftovers back home with me but unfortunately I had to head straight to the airport afterwards for a flight. The beef sambussa came with a spicy sauce and was piping hot and delicious. It was a bit on the greasy side, but extremely yummy. The vegetable combo and lamb tibs was presented on an unfurled piece of injera, which is a spongey sort of flatbread. The first thing I thought of when I looked at it was my slight case of "trypophobia" (don't look it up on Google if you're uncomfortable with images of clustered, small holes)...but the subtle taste and texture was amazing. There was also a side of extra rolled up injera for you to eat the wat (Ethiopian stew that has a similar consistency to hummus). I personally LOVED the types of wat I got - they were so flavorful and some of them definitely had a kick to them.  The lamb tibs were also quite yummy and I loved the smokiness to them. 

Ambience-wise, the place is quite colorful and cute. It's very small and probably only seats less than 20 people. The food comes out very quickly. One slight detraction to the restaurant is its location in Tenderloin, a neighborhood that slightly gives me the heebie-jeebies as a young woman by myself. As I did not feel comfortable walking in the area, I simply Ubered to and from the restaurant - no big deal. The food definitely makes this place worth it! And the service was awesome. Check it out!

excerpts: Lamb Tibs.
Grilled tidbits with onions and spices.
This was really good having a nice seared flavor.
lamb tibs.author: Edwin L.
lamb tibs.review:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and fortunately it was very good.  If not, I would have been turned off to Ethiopian cuisine.  The restaurant was a bit in the shady area of San Francisco but well worth the trip. It was dotted with more of the homeless and indignant rather than gangs so I didn't feel unsafe when I went in the late afternoon daylight hours.

For the restaurant itself; small cafe style with about 6 small tables.  Clean, well kept, homey, and comfortable, nothing fancy.  It looked like about 60% of the business was take out.  Since this was my first experience with Ethiopian food, I didn't have a basis to compare the food with but I can tell you everything was fresh, flavorful, excellently prepared and unexpectedly well presented for a small cafe restaurant in the Tenderloin district. I would describe the food as tasty comfort food that you could easily develop a craving for.  Portions didn't look much when I first got it, me being a "healthy" eater but it was more than enough to fill me up.  I think the Injera bread has a lot to do with it.

A family run business and I really appreciate the friendly, caring atmosphere where customers are made to feel as a guest in their "home", a lost art with most business nowadays. 

My wife and I had the Sambussa.. Tasty with a mild spicy sauce on the side. Nicely packed, so you actually can taste the stuffing. Lamb Tibs.  Grilled tidbits with onions and spices.  This was really good having a nice seared flavor.   Vegetarian combination.  Great way to try all the different Ethiopian prepared veggies.  Each has it unique flavor, some mild, while others are a bit more spicy.  I like the spicy Misir Wot the best.  I had a small cup of Ethiopian coffee which the owner gave me for free to try We also got a complementary Baklava and Spiced tea (they forgot to give us our Spice tea during our order) (a typical example of how customers are treated as a valued and appreciated "guest").  Boy the Baklava was good too, being not overly sweet having a flaky pastry.

All and all, excellent experience and tasty food at a reasonable price.  I have now developed a comfort food craving for Ethiopian cuisine and for this establishment.  Thank you Tadu!!!

excerpts: We order the vegetable combo with lamb tibs and it was sooo good and flavorful!
I remember really liking the potatoes and the fresh greens in the veggie combo, which went perfectly well with the spicy lamb tibs.
The veggie combo + lamb tib was A LOT of food for two people
and I think the portion could've fed 3-4 people.
lamb tibs.author: Leilani Y.
lamb tibs.review:
My second time trying Ethiopian food and it did not disappoint! I like this place more than Enssaro, where I first tried Ethiopian food in Oakland. 

This place is pretty small only 5-6 tables but it's very neat and has modern decor. It's also family ran :) a little boy served us our water. 

I really like the injera here because it wasn't too sour. We order the vegetable combo with lamb tibs and it was sooo good and flavorful! 
Warning: the lamb tib is pretty spicy!! 

I remember really liking the potatoes and the fresh greens in the veggie combo, which went perfectly well with the spicy lamb tibs. The veggie combo + lamb tib was A LOT of food for two people and I think the portion could've fed 3-4 people. However, my bf and I didn't know how to order smaller portions. 

I was a little iffy using my hands to eat but they're super cleaver for having a sink outside of the bathroom. 

All in all, this place is a must try!

excerpts: LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.
lamb tibs.author: Elliott D.
lamb tibs.review:
TL;DR:

Quite decent in the realm of Ethiopian, though I'm puzzled by their lack of a proper Wot offerings.

THE DEETS:

***VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints. In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there. Unexpected but interesting.

***REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter. Served with a side of Ayib (cheese). Spicy & Hot. (served rare of course)

Nice & buttery, I approve. I like a little moo with my beef (raw or rare). They seem to serve as tiny bits rather than actual ground beef, which is an interesting & unexpected approach. 

***LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.

I've never really cared for tibs, which are kinda okay but just not as creamy, tender, or flavorful as wot. But they don't have any wot offerings, which is disappointing. 

***FIRFIR - LAMB ALICHA BANATU - Small pieces of injera tossed in Tadu's sauces of mild tumeric with lamb. Mild.

Quite nice. This dish highlights why Ethiopian leftovers are always better the second day--the injera gets soft, mushy, and even a bit more fermented, which sounds like it would be gross, but during this process everything becomes super-infused with flavor.

excerpts: In addition to the vegetables, we had the lamb tibs and beef tibs.
The lamb had a nice, strong lamb flavor to it.
To our dismay, the beef tibs were tasteless.
lamb tibs.author: Terence T.
lamb tibs.review:
The combination of trying to find a restaurant in walking distance that was open midday on a Sunday and having not had Ethiopian food for ages led me to Tadu. As it's located in the Tenderloin, we walked past the numerous homeless people that are unfortunately so common there. 

After perusing the menu, the three of us decided to share the Vegetarian Combo, which includes the Kik Alicha (chickpeas), Misir Wot (spicy lentils), Gomen (collard greens), Alicha Tikil Gomen (carrots/potatoes/cabbage), Azifa (lentils), and salad. The star of the combo was the Misir Wot, which had great flavor and a little bit of a kick to it. The other items were pretty typical and not especially interesting (have yet to have them anywhere where I thought they were great).

In addition to the vegetables, we had the lamb tibs and beef tibs. The lamb had a nice, strong lamb flavor to it. To our dismay, the beef tibs were tasteless. In addition, the two dishes are prepared in exactly the same way, so the contrast in flavors (or lack thereof) was especially noticeable.

Plenty of injera for our meal (they asked if we wanted more, but we were already full). We certainly overordered as we had leftovers.

Overall, this is somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. I've decided on the lower rating due to proximity to the homeless--if you are walking around with a child, you feel a bit unsafe. I will say that when we were inside the restaurant, we had no concerns about safety.

excerpts: I'd recommend the SAMBUSSAS as a starter and LAMB TIBS as an entree.
And you can't go wrong with the VEGETARIAN COMBO, which will give you sampling of almost all the veggie entrees.
The food overall was pretty tasty

A little bit of spice and so much flavor

LAMB TIBS ($14) - 4/5
[sautéed in spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, berbere]
Juicy and delicious!
lamb tibs.author: Jessie L.
lamb tibs.review:
TLDR: flavorful Ethiopian food, large portions, very reasonable prices; definitely recommend for a different dining experience

I've seen Tadu listed as one of the "Best of Yelp" Restaurants for many weeks now (maybe since its opening?). I've yet to see a place maintain a 5-star rating for so long and with 100+ reviews, so of course it made my bookmarks list. Honestly, if fellow Yelper Ben K. hadn't suggested it for dinner, I don't know if I would've ever made it here since I don't like to frequent the TL.

The restaurant is a small hole-in-the wall with maybe 5-6 tables and probably has the capacity for only 15ish people. In contrast to the surrounding TL, the inside is pretty nice and clean. The place wasn't busy yet at around 6pm on a Friday, but it filled up pretty easily and there were people waiting by the time we left.

Anyone unfamiliar with Ethiopian food (like me) might be a little lost with the menu, not because there are too many options, but because everything sounds more or less the same. The menu has a few appetizers and several veggie and meat entrees, which all come with injera, a spongy sourdough crepe. I'd recommend the SAMBUSSAS as a starter and LAMB TIBS as an entree. And you can't go wrong with the VEGETARIAN COMBO, which will give you sampling of almost all the veggie entrees. The food overall was pretty tasty and I really enjoyed anything cooked with berbere (some sort of chili/spice).

For anyone who hasn't had Ethiopian food, there are no utensils (unless asked for). You basically break off pieces of injera and use it to pick up the meat/veggies or dip it in the more hummus-like veggie dishes.

Entrees range from $10-15 and portion sizes are big and filling, especially with the unlimited injera. One entree can easily feed you for 2 meals, so it's definitely worth the price. Being the fatass that I am sometimes though, I ended up eating much more than I should have..

Service is pretty good here. Our server (who I think may have been the owner) checked in on us a few times to ask how the food was and to see if we needed more injera or water.

===========

SAMBUSSA ($4) - 5/5
Comes with 3. Kind of like samosas, but the dough is thinner, airier, flakier and crispier, and the inside is filled with ground beef or lentils. We got the ground beef, which was amazing! A little bit of spice and so much flavor

LAMB TIBS ($14) - 4/5
[sautéed in spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, berbere]
Juicy and delicious! The jalapeños and berbere give it a good kick, but more heat would've been even better. The dish was on the greasy side for me but tasted so good that the greasiness couldn't stop me from eating more of it

VEGETARIAN COMBINATION ($12) - 4/5
We ordered the vegetarian banatu/firfir, but I'm pretty sure they gave us the veggie combo now that I'm looking back at my picture. The vegetarian firfir is supposed to be vegetables and pieces of injera in berbere but we definitely did not get that on our plate. The veggie combo didn't disappoint though and was a really good sampler of many of their veggie entrees

     -MISIR WOT - 4.5/5
     [split lentil sauce made w/ berbere, onions, ginger, garlic]
     Orange/red and similar in texture to a thick tomato sauce. A little bit spicy from the berbere, which I loved. Definitely one of my favorite veggie options
     
     -ALICHA TIKIL GOMEN - 4.5/5
     [cabbage, potatoes & carrots]
     Another favorite from the combo. Not as flavorful as the misir wot but I like that it actually has veggies in it

     -GOMEN - 3.5/5
     [collard greens]
     A little bitter but still pretty good

     -KIK ALICHA WOT - 3/5
     [chickpea cooked w/ spicy tumeric, ginger & garlic]
     Yellow and a little thicker than hummus in texture. Not bad but didn't impress me

     -BUTICHA - 3/5
     [ground chickpeas, peppers & onions]
     Reminded me of a potato salad in taste and mashed potatoes in texture. I actually liked the flavor but it felt pretty rich and heavy so I could only eat a few bites

     -AZIFA - 3/5
     [lentils sauteed w/ onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds & lemon]
     Served cold. Also kind of rich/heavy

VEGGIE MEDLEY ($10) - 4/5
[mushrooms stir fried w/ peppers, jalapeno & berbere]
Solid. Not super special and pretty greasy, but very flavorful

KITFO ($13.50) - 3.5/5
Flavorful lean ground beef, cooked to a nice medium rare. I liked it a lot at first but wasn't really a fan of the half raw ground texture after a bit

INJERA (complimentary)
The entrees are served on a giant piece of injera. I've only had Ethiopian once before and didn't like the injera much because of the acidity, but was pleased with the injera here. Theirs was soft, spongy and tasted like sourdough without being too acidic. I don't really like sourdough in general so I wouldn't eat the injera on its own, but it works well with the entrees and soaks up the juices of the lamb very well

excerpts: Next up, the vegetarian combo, beef berebere banatu, firfir, lamb tibs, and shiro
wot
lamb tibs.author: Shereen A.
lamb tibs.review:
Tadu freaking ROCKS!

Was really craving Ethiopian food and after not finding anything comparable to Seattle, I decided I didn't care and wanted to try this place (the five stars lured me in).

The first time we came here, it was an hour before closing to find that there were no seats and it was SUPER packed. There's only five tables, so plan accordingly. We waited and waited, and thankfully right before they closed they kindly seated us.

We started off with the vegetarian sambusas (ask for the hot sauce, it spicy and delish). The edges were perfectly crispy, we practically inhaled them.

Next up, the vegetarian combo, beef berebere banatu, firfir, lamb tibs, and shiro wot (so I know this is a lot of food, but leftovers are the best, so whatever).

Bf ate the ENTIRE veg combo by himself. Not only is it super flavorful, it's massive (one of those can't stop eating, it's so delicious), and you get enough injera to swaddle a newborn baby elephant in. 

They even brought us a bite each of baklava since we waited outside for an hour for a table. So nice (and so yum).

I absolutely love the beef berebere banatu, and shiro wot. We never come here and not order both of those. 

Also, they have gluten free injera (FROM Ethiopia!!), like no joke. Order this (+$3) and you'll leave without feeling fat, no matter how much you dig in. It's a bit more tart than the regular injera, but so so delicious, absolutely fluffy, and perfectly moist. I never skip it. I gladly take the the left overs home and make my own berebere firfirX (lentils, chicken, etc.) to enjoy for another day. 

The staff is always so helpful, very kind, and remembers you. 

Seriously addicted to this place.

excerpts: Get the lamb tibs...
ok yes Ethiopian food is always full of flavors, but this spot really makes it apparent.
I literally closed my eyes with every bite.
They give you great portions and its literally cooked fresh a few feet away from where you're dining.
I mean come on,
what else do you want?
The kitfo was great too..
I should've order rare and not medium but still delicious!
The injera was a plenty and delicious as well.
The prices are good especially for being in San Francisco and you get more than enough food.
I wish they had some honey wine, but that's ok
it's hardly a complaint, merely a wish.
We will definitely be back.
lamb tibs.author: Guisela L.
lamb tibs.review: I'm a fan! Get the lamb tibs...ok yes Ethiopian food is always full of flavors, but this spot really makes it apparent. I literally closed my eyes with every bite. They give you great portions and its literally cooked fresh a few feet away from where you're dining. I mean come on, what else do you want? The kitfo was great too..I should've order rare and not medium but still delicious! The injera was a plenty and delicious as well. The prices are good especially for being in San Francisco and you get more than enough food. I wish they had some honey wine, but that's ok it's hardly a complaint, merely a wish. We will definitely be back.

excerpts: I highly recommend the lamb tibs.
It's made fresh to order and is absolutely delicious.
The onions are perfectly caramelized and the seasoning of spices and salt is perfect.
lamb tibs.author: Sherry L.
lamb tibs.review:
I love Ethiopian food but a good place is hard to find. My friend and I were seriously craving some the other afternoon, but the one in the Mission doesn't open until dinnertime. So we found Tadu in the TL, which has 5 stars. And it really lived up to its rating! There are only a few tables inside so when its busy, I can see why there would be a wait. There aren't that many items on the menu, but everything on it is delicious.

I highly recommend the lamb tibs. It's made fresh to order and is absolutely delicious. The onions are perfectly caramelized and the seasoning of spices and salt is perfect. So yummy!

We ordered the full size of the Alicha but they accidentally gave us the veggie combo, which is fine. The veggie combo was great. We loved the cabbage, lentils, and chickpeas. I also liked the salad a lot too. The collard greens were good too.

We also ordered the Beef Sambussa as an appetizer. There were only 3 but the filling was spicy and yummy.

Next time, I really want to try the eggplant (which they didn't have a half size of) and some of the other meat dishes. The pictures look awesome!

excerpts: At the recommendation of our server, we chose the Lamb Tibs in addition to the Vegetarian Combo.
The Lambs Tibs were juicy, but could have used some more seasoning.
In the veg combo, I enjoyed the Misir Wot (red lentils with Berbere spice) the most.
I also liked the buticha, which the server compared to hummus.
lamb tibs.author: Adrienne H.
lamb tibs.review:
I've only had Ethiopian in San Jose (Zeni), and Tadu wasn't quite at that level, but it still hit the spot. Bonus points for curing a terrible case of post crappy $40 hotel breakfast buffet hangry-ness.

We got the Sambussa starter which came with three pieces of fried flakey dough stuffed with ground beef and onions. Tadu's version is extra crispy, the filling is seasoned well, and the tomato dipping sauce was fantastic.

At the recommendation of our server, we chose the Lamb Tibs in addition to the Vegetarian Combo. The Lambs Tibs were juicy, but could have used some more seasoning. In the veg combo, I enjoyed the Misir Wot (red lentils with Berbere spice) the most. I also liked the buticha, which the server compared to hummus. It was made from chickpeas but much thicker than hummus, and reminded me of potato salad.

The Injera bread was not as sour or fluffy as I prefer, but that didn't stop me from eating an entire basket anyway. Injera is my weakness. There's something about the act of scooping up food with bread that I absolutely enjoy. Service was attentive and kind as well. Tadu is worth braving the sketch area for!

excerpts: We ordered the veggie combo with lamb tibs.
The gomen was a little bit too salty, but the lentils and cabbage were delicious.
This meal was of great value, especially in SF.
I would definitely recommend this place if you are in Tenderloin.
It is little seating so probably not a good place for parties of 4 or more.
lamb tibs.author: Shu T.
lamb tibs.review: I came here to introduce Ethiopian food to my roommate and it is by far one of the best Ethiopian places in the Bay area. We ordered the veggie combo with lamb tibs. The gomen was a little bit too salty, but the lentils and cabbage were delicious. This meal was of great value, especially in SF. I would definitely recommend this place if you are in Tenderloin. It is little seating so probably not a good place for parties of 4 or more.

Rib Tibs (they were out!)
