lamb tibs.review: Three of us ate here last night - 5 stars all around - awesome customer service, delish food and an overall relaxed vibe. They don't serve any alcohol, but it's BYOB - which we learned after the fact. Ordered a ton of food including the chicken, beef and lamb tibs all of which were solid - the chicken was the spiciest of the lot w/o question. Also got the gluten free injera as we were told that is the traditional method of preparation i.e with teff flour only versus any wheat flour added. Also ordered a couple of veggie dishes including one of the lentil based items - I don't recall as I didn't eat much of the veggies on the plate. It's straight up family style to share, eat with your hands and have a good time. The place probably doesn't seat more than 15-20 people at a time but we were fortunate to have a 3 seater spot available for us when we walked in. I'd def. recommend Tadu to anyone interested in going beyond the boring and mundane foods we eat day to day!

excerpts: For the nonvegans, we also ordered a plate of the medium rare  regular kitfo, which was equally amazing!
regular kitfo.author: Omead A.
regular kitfo.review:
My wife and I enjoyed a fantastic dinner with friends at Tadu! We started off with two orders of Sambussas, one veggie and one beef. Both options were delicious, and the slightly spicy dipping sauce was exquisite! 

For our main entree, we ordered two of the Vegan combos. It was a great call, as we were able to try a variety of all their different veggie meals. Our favorite of the bunch had to be  Misir Wot and Shiro Wot - both were to die for! For the nonvegans, we also ordered a plate of the medium rare  regular kitfo, which was equally amazing! 

Great service, friendly atmosphere, and we will definitely be coming back!

excerpts: **REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter.
Served with a side of Ayib (cheese).
Spicy & Hot.
regular kitfo.author: Elliott D.
regular kitfo.review:
TL;DR:

Quite decent in the realm of Ethiopian, though I'm puzzled by their lack of a proper Wot offerings.

THE DEETS:

***VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints. In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there. Unexpected but interesting.

***REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter. Served with a side of Ayib (cheese). Spicy & Hot. (served rare of course)

Nice & buttery, I approve. I like a little moo with my beef (raw or rare). They seem to serve as tiny bits rather than actual ground beef, which is an interesting & unexpected approach. 

***LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.

I've never really cared for tibs, which are kinda okay but just not as creamy, tender, or flavorful as wot. But they don't have any wot offerings, which is disappointing. 

***FIRFIR - LAMB ALICHA BANATU - Small pieces of injera tossed in Tadu's sauces of mild tumeric with lamb. Mild.

Quite nice. This dish highlights why Ethiopian leftovers are always better the second day--the injera gets soft, mushy, and even a bit more fermented, which sounds like it would be gross, but during this process everything becomes super-infused with flavor.

excerpts: Ordered ribs goden, veggie combo, regular kitfo and vegetarian banatu.
The owner was so incredibly nice, greeted us so warnly and even offered us a complimentary traditional Ethiopian tea.
I have had a lot of Ethiopian food in the bay area, but his place is the most authentic, fresh and delicious.
I can't wait to come back the again!!!!
regular kitfo.author: Emnet W.
regular kitfo.review: Best Ethiopian food in town hands down! Ordered ribs goden, veggie combo, regular kitfo and vegetarian banatu. The owner was so incredibly nice, greeted us so warnly and even offered us a complimentary traditional Ethiopian tea. I have had a lot of Ethiopian food in the bay area, but his place is the most authentic, fresh and delicious. I can't wait to come back the again!!!!

excerpts: As for the food, I had Regular Kitfo with a side order-size of Kik Alicha Wot.
My friend had the Vegetarian Combo.
Plenty of spongy injera to eat it all with.
Everything was so full of amazing flavors and spices, and we left full and satisfied.
The service was very attentive.
It was busy when we arrived around 2 pm on a Sunday (the place only has a handful of tables), but by the time we left it had emptied out.
I admit I've only had Ethiopian food a few times, and this was the first Ethiopian restaurant I've been in SF, but I see no need to go anywhere else the next time I get a craving.
I strongly recommend this place.
regular kitfo.author: Patrick F.
regular kitfo.review: The Tenderloin has its issues and may not be a place I go after dark, but finding amazing food from all over the world for cheap makes it worth exploring (at least in daylight). Tadu is a tiny place that you could easily miss due to minimal signage, but missing it would be a crime! The atmosphere is very "no frills," but bright and very clean, including the bathroom (which is often where places like this fall short when it comes to cleanliness). As for the food, I had Regular Kitfo with a side order-size of Kik Alicha Wot. My friend had the Vegetarian Combo. Plenty of spongy injera to eat it all with. Everything was so full of amazing flavors and spices, and we left full and satisfied. The service was very attentive. It was busy when we arrived around 2 pm on a Sunday (the place only has a handful of tables), but by the time we left it had emptied out. I admit I've only had Ethiopian food a few times, and this was the first Ethiopian restaurant I've been in SF, but I see no need to go anywhere else the next time I get a craving. I strongly recommend this place.

excerpts:
I ordered the special kitfo, medium rare, which was served with some injera bread
Staff were extremely friendly
special kitfo.author: Kevin P.
special kitfo.review:
Food was very good - I ordered the special kitfo, medium rare, which was served with some injera bread
Staff were extremely friendly
Will definitely come back, as I'd like to try the lamb tibs and the vegetarian combination next

excerpts:
try their "Kitfo" or "Special Kitfo" (since the owner is a Gurage Man) and the dish is originated from his tribe.

for real Afficionado, you don't get them in SF Bay Area.
special kitfo.author: Rudy H.
special kitfo.review:
Thank You Elias!

I've been living in DC (the largest Ethiopian Community outside of Ethiopia) for the past 17 years and had my more than fair share of my exposure of the Ethiopian Cuisine.
from the popular one like "Doro Wat" to the Raw Hanging Meat that the Ethiopians serves at their weddings "Kuert / Tere Sega" or "Milas Ena Senber" I know it all.
I had a very nice conversation with Elias the owner about some of the Restaurants and some of the unusual menus that the Ethiopian Restaurants serves in Washington DC / VA / MD area.
this place is good for those who are curious about Ethiopian Food and for the first timers.

try their "Kitfo" or "Special Kitfo" (since the owner is a Gurage Man) and the dish is originated from his tribe.

for real Afficionado, you don't get them in SF Bay Area.
you must come to Washington DC (U st) or VA (Skyline / George Mason Dr / Columbia Pike).

excerpts:
Two must haves:  

Special kitfo - typically eaten rare
special kitfo.author: Jen W.
special kitfo.review:
Such a hidden, hole in the wall...that every local person who loves ethiopian food knows about!  Haha.  I don't exactly know what authentic ethiopian food is but I eat it enough to know exactly what I like.  Tadu is up there with the best of them.  It's located right smack in the middle of the TL...the beautiful scent of urine just a few steps away.  Don't even think about that and just go in to experience some deliciousness.

Two must haves:  

Special kitfo - typically eaten rare but we went with medium rare.  This is Tadu's most beloved dish and what they're known for.  It's pretty much ground beef with jalapeños and seasoning.  Don't ask me what seasoning cause I have absolutely no idea!

Lamb tibs - Bomb.com...order it, don't look back, and just put it in your mouth.  Mmhmm...

Don't forget the injera.  If you need more, you can always ask but they give you plenty.  

The place is super small so you might have to wait for a table.  It appeared that most peeps ordered togo.  Super affordable prices.  Friendly peeps.

excerpts: We ordered the special kitfo with the vegetarian combo.
Girl friend doesn't like raw meat
so we ordered the kitfo well done.
special kitfo.author: Jeff P.
special kitfo.review:
We ordered the special kitfo with the vegetarian combo. Girl friend doesn't like raw meat so we ordered the kitfo well done. Loved that it was still juicy. 

When we asked for the bill we got a complimentary baklava. Which was unexpected and delicious. 

Best Ethiopian food we have ever had. We will definitely be back.

excerpts: The lamb tibs are to die for and so is the special kitfo--rare of course!
Any-who, I've had everything on the menu and you truly cannot go wrong.
The vegetarian options are sooo good, you don't even realize you're missing out on eating meat.
What better way to support locality, diversity, culture and FOOD in sf.
special kitfo.author: Angela N.
special kitfo.review:
Fantastic family run Ethiopian food. I've been here every month with my boyfriend for two years and can't stop. Sometime twice a month if we're feeling it. Been to several other places in sf and the east bay and nothing compares. The folks here are endearing and so friendly. Super fast in food prep. I always bring new folks here, because it's the best food in my opinion around. Heart, soul, culture, spice and love. The lamb tibs are to die for and so is the special kitfo--rare of course! Any-who, I've had everything on the menu and you truly cannot go wrong. The vegetarian options are sooo good, you don't even realize you're missing out on eating meat. What better way to support locality, diversity, culture and FOOD in sf. Be ready to eat with your hands!

Hands down to these guys. Small kitchen and staff, but fantastic service and food. Never longer than 30mins.

excerpts: We ordered the veggie platter with the special kitfo (lamb).
The food was delicious.
The injera was very fresh and had a great texture (could realty taste the sourdough)!
Only thing missing would be an alcohol menu :) delicious and very filling!
Worth the trek to the tenderloin.
special kitfo.author: Yin H.
special kitfo.review: Delicious food, excellent value, good service. After a day in Sonoma we found this place on yelp and decided to stop by. Though we arrived just a few minutes before closing, the staff was still very accommodating and welcomed us. We ordered the veggie platter with the special kitfo (lamb). The food was delicious. The injera was very fresh and had a great texture (could realty taste the sourdough)! Only thing missing would be an alcohol menu :) delicious and very filling! Worth the trek to the tenderloin.

excerpts: The flavor is out of this world, the injera is legit, the special kitfo's got some special spice, the service is great.
I just wish the place were bigger!
Now that word has gotten out about Tadu, there's always a line out the door and not nearly enough tables for all the demand.
special kitfo.author: Marco C.
special kitfo.review: This is by far the best Ethiopian food I've ever had, and I've tried a fair bit. The flavor is out of this world, the injera is legit, the special kitfo's got some special spice, the service is great. I just wish the place were bigger! Now that word has gotten out about Tadu, there's always a line out the door and not nearly enough tables for all the demand.

excerpts: my 7 yr old love the special kitfo.
special kitfo.author: Nhieu w.
special kitfo.review: My girls told me I had to give them five stars! My picky 5 yr old ate a ton of chicken tibs and my 7 yr old love the special kitfo.

excerpts: I had the special kitfo and peas.
Wow, the kitfo was so flavorful.
The recipes sits well above many other places I've been.
The peas were lightly flavored and their creaminess matched the kitfo well.
special kitfo.author: Dave S.
special kitfo.review:
Went here after a Giants game. So glad I did. Walking there takes you along some shady zones but it's worth the venture. 
The place is small. One 4 top and five 2 person tables. The menu is pretty basic, which I think makes sense for a smaller place. I had the special kitfo and peas. Wow, the kitfo was so flavorful. The recipes sits well above many other places I've been. The peas were lightly flavored and their creaminess matched the kitfo well.

excerpts: I got Vegan Combo + Special Kitfo, Lamb and Beef Libs, and Sambussa.
This meal was enough for four to five people.
By the way, Injera has a little sour.
Overall, five stars food.
special kitfo.author: Charles Z.
special kitfo.review: A bit crowded restaurant but it's acceptable. Food is great. I got Vegan Combo + Special Kitfo, Lamb and Beef Libs, and Sambussa. This meal was enough for four to five people. By the way, Injera has a little sour. Overall, five stars food.

excerpts: We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination.
Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait
and everything was delicious!
If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special.
But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.
special kitfo.author: Jenny F.
special kitfo.review:
I'm definitely going to be frequenting this restaurant after my first visit tonight.

I've always been a huge fan of Ethiopian cuisine, with New Eritrea being one of my favorite SF spots. The only drawback about New Eritrea is that it's all the way in the Sunset, which isn't very conveniently located for me (but they're still worth the drive)!

But I digress. I was so glad the girlfriend found this spot on Yelp that was so close to where we work and on our way home. When we first walked it, it appears to be completely full, all tables occupied. The sweet owner asked us if we wanted to dine in and pulled out an extra table that fit perfectly in the little nook of space left in the room.

We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination. Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait and everything was delicious! If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special. But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.

If you're on the fence about this place, jump off already! There's a reason they have such high ratings. Great service & amazing food. Let the food speak for itself. :)

excerpts: We had the special kitfo and lamb tibs.
I had come with high hopes after reading a lot of good things about Tadu, and it far exceeded my expectations.
special kitfo.author: Erin B.
special kitfo.review:
Whoooooaaaaaaa. This? Was the best meal I've had in a long time. We had the special kitfo and lamb tibs. I had come with high hopes after reading a lot of good things about Tadu, and it far exceeded my expectations. We finished the meal with baklava which was also excellent. 

The staff is also really, really nice. I hope these guys succeed and stick around a long time.

excerpts: We ordered the lamb tibs, the special kitfo, and the veggie special.
The lamb and the kitfo were great, but the veggies were off the chart delicious.
The injeera was perfect.
Slightly sour, light, and spongy.
The service was perfect.
Our waiter was helpful, attentive, friendly, and let us know that we could buy honey wine from across the street at Red Sea Grocery to have with our dinner.
Highly recommended.
We will be back!
special kitfo.author: Da Wei S.
special kitfo.review: A solid 5-star experience. The best Ethiopian food that I've ever had. We ordered the lamb tibs, the special kitfo, and the veggie special. The lamb and the kitfo were great, but the veggies were off the chart delicious. The injeera was perfect. Slightly sour, light, and spongy. The service was perfect. Our waiter was helpful, attentive, friendly, and let us know that we could buy honey wine from across the street at Red Sea Grocery to have with our dinner. Highly recommended. We will be back!

excerpts: For dinner I had the lamb tibs, one friend had the special kitfo and my other friend has the vegetarian combination.
We all thought it was absolutely delicious.
Then for dessert we had the baklava.
Probably the best that I have ever had.
Will definitely go back.
Thank you Tadu!
special kitfo.author: Brianna M.
special kitfo.review: Best food Ethiopian food I have ever had. Went tonight with two of my friends. The waiter was extremely helpful and so very nice. For an appetizer we had the lentil sambussa which was so moist and delicious. For dinner I had the lamb tibs, one friend had the special kitfo and my other friend has the vegetarian combination. We all thought it was absolutely delicious. Then for dessert we had the baklava. Probably the best that I have ever had. Will definitely go back. Thank you Tadu!

excerpts: The lamb tibs and special kitfo were quickly and thoroughly enjoyed by my omnivorous companions.
They report high levels of spiciness.
special kitfo.author: Ruby S.
special kitfo.review:
The restaurant is very small, but you can bring your own bottle, which is better because you get exactly what you want for cheaper.
The vegetarian platter has seven dishes, providing a good selection of dishes. It was all delicious. Hard to say what was best as I was too busy eating to be discerning as to which was best.
The lamb tibs and special kitfo were quickly and thoroughly enjoyed by my omnivorous companions. They report high levels of spiciness.

excerpts: My fav dishes are the Michet Abish Wot, and the Special Kitfo.
The baklava is also fresh and tasty!
special kitfo.author: Nick D.
special kitfo.review: This is easily one of the best Ethiopian restaurants in the bay. My fav dishes are the Michet Abish Wot, and the Special Kitfo. The baklava is also fresh and tasty!

excerpts: If you're up for an adventure, try the special kitfo (rare).
Very good!
special kitfo.author: Joseph E.
special kitfo.review: Delicious and truly authentic meal. Spent 3 months in Ethiopia earlier this year and the food was comparable to the best local restaurants in Addis Ababa. If you're up for an adventure, try the special kitfo (rare). Very good!

excerpts: The Special Kitfo is about the closest thing to food heaven for me.
The staff is extremely friendly and the restaurant always seems spotless.
The only downside is location.
This is about as TL as it gets.
Someone handed out a bag of crack right next to me while I was waiting next to my car.
This doesn't bother me much
but I'd be hesitant to go at night.
I'm hoping they'll offer delivery service in the near future.
I wouldn't even mind a $5 delivery fee if they want to join with Postmates or similar.
special kitfo.author: Bucky P.
special kitfo.review: The Special Kitfo is about the closest thing to food heaven for me.  The staff is extremely friendly and the restaurant always seems spotless.  The only downside is location.  This is about as TL as it gets.  Someone handed out a bag of crack right next to me while I was waiting next to my car.  This doesn't bother me much but I'd be hesitant to go at night.  I'm hoping they'll offer delivery service in the near future.  I wouldn't even mind a $5 delivery fee if they want to join with Postmates or similar.

excerpts: The special kitfo is delicious.
Prices are a touch high given the neighborhood.
special kitfo.author: Ethan C.
special kitfo.review: Probably 2nd best Ethiopian in SF (behind the one on Valencia), with the added benefit of being fast, having super nice staff, and being 300 yards from my door.   The special kitfo is delicious.   Prices are a touch high given the neighborhood.

excerpts: I ordered the Special Kitfo (beef tartar) and also took away the Veggie Combo.
As a bug fan of Ethiopian food, I was very impressed with the taste of the dishes.
The service was extremely nice and attentive.
special kitfo.author: Don C.
special kitfo.review:
I thoroughly enjoyed my first visit to Tadu last evening. I ordered the Special Kitfo (beef tartar) and also took away the Veggie Combo. As a bug fan of Ethiopian food, I was very impressed with the taste of the dishes. The service was extremely nice and attentive. I'm very glad that I longer have to head over to Oakland for good Ethiopian food and can get it right here in the city!

Can't wait to get back to sample more if the menu!

excerpts: My Vegetarian Combination came out in mere minutes.
vegetarian combination.author: Lauren H.
vegetarian combination.review:
On a Sunday afternoon, I came here very hungry at a rather odd hour between lunch and dinner and ordered right away. Service was quick and friendly. My Vegetarian Combination came out in mere minutes. I stopped for a moment to take in the wonderful aromas and then proceeded to inhale the food so fast my stomach started to hurt a little.   

The combo came with Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen and sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. In particular, the Alicha Tikil Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with onions, ginger, and tumeric) and Kik Alicha (chickpeas cooked with spicy tumeric, ginger, and garlic) stood out. I was mesmerized by the flavors.  
 
The Misir Wot (split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, ginger, and garlic) was smoky and peppery. I don't think the combo I had came with Azifa (lentils sauteed with onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds, and lemon). The buticha (ground chickpeas, peppers, and onions) was delicious. Eating the collard greens (Gomen) made me feel extra healthy.  

I appreciated the hand wipe that was provided after the meal which seems to be customary at Ethiopian restaurants. And I love the Andes chocolates that came with the bill. Some of the customers were speaking to the staff in an Ethiopian language adding to the authenticity of this place. Don't let walking in the neighborhood deter you! It wasn't nearly so bad in broad daylight.

excerpts: We went for the "Vegetarian Combination" ($11.95).
Bedded on the bottom is the slightly spongey textured pancake, it tastes like sour bread.
Then on the top is the split pea stew, spicy lentils, the tikil gomen its cabbage, potatoes, carrots and right down the middle of the plate is a salad.
vegetarian combination.author: Jon B.
vegetarian combination.review:
Tadu is a few blocks from our hotel and it was a good place for casual Ethiopian meals. I was looking forward to it especially, that I seldom get this type of cuisine that consists of vegetables and meats blended in special spices. 

When looking at their menu it took us awhile to figure out what's best. We had to ask if some of their items are portioned enough for three. Thankfully, their menu has a brief description for each item, which most we're not familiar with. But, in the end we left satisfied and what we ordered was mighty tasty. 

We went for the "Vegetarian Combination" ($11.95). Bedded on the bottom is the slightly spongey textured pancake, it tastes like sour bread. Then on the top is the split pea stew, spicy lentils, the tikil gomen its cabbage, potatoes, carrots and right down the middle of the plate is a salad. The vegetarian part alone may sound simple but, it was definitely full of flavor. 

I couldn't live without the meat so we added the "Chicken Tibs" ($9.95). We opted to have our chicken juicy and they didn't hold back on that, it was really tasty. You can see the tomatoes, and jalapeños within the sauces. Also, the spice level was medium and it does have a hint of pepper and lime taste. All I can say the tibs was stewed to perfection. 

Friendly service here, and I notice our server was one the cooks, nice multitasking from her. To dine inside it's a little tight in space when all tables are occupied, but hey  you can't complain about the cool mom and pop restaurant experience in downtown San Francisco. 

Located in the Tenderloin District, let Tadu spice up your lunch and dinner time.

excerpts: so I ordered the vegetarian combination.
I was also intrigued by their speciality, kifto, spicy raw beef.
Yep, as if eating Ethiopian food in bed wasn't weird enough, I added raw beef to the mix.
Living life on the edge, I tell ya.
vegetarian combination.author: Cassie P.
vegetarian combination.review:
Never have I ever ate Ethiopian food in bed... Until now! 

After a long week of work and travel, I was dead tired but it was Friday night and I was in San Francisco. Gotta live it up, right?! Well, on this particular night, "living it up" turned into ordering takeaway Ethiopian food with Yelp food delivery and cozying up in bed. Yes, I ate this messy, fragrant food in the comfort of my hotel room. Quite a different experience than I'm used to, but one for the books.

Now, don't think things didn't get a little crazy. Sure, I wasn't dancing at a club, but my heart rate was jumpin' as I briskly walked through the Tenderloin to find Tadu. I considered turning around and calling an Uber a couple minutes into my journey. Even in the daylight, I probably wouldn't walk through here again by myself. Even if it is 0.3 miles away.

My food was ready when I arrived. When it comes to Ethiopian food, the veggie options are usually my favorite so I ordered the vegetarian combination. I was also intrigued by their speciality, kifto, spicy raw beef. Yep, as if eating Ethiopian food in bed wasn't weird enough, I added raw beef to the mix. Living life on the edge, I tell ya. To cap it all off, I got a big bag of injera to sop it up. 

All in all, it was pretty darn good! I had never tried kifto before but am a fan of steak tartare which is somewhat similar. I could only have a couple of bites and there's no way I could ever finish a whole platter on my own because it's just too rich (and raw?). Loved the spice and overall flavor though. I basically ordered two entrees for myself and only finished about a third of the food before I was stuffed to the brim. It was all super hearty portions and a great price.

The restaurant itself is very small and casual. I would definitely venture here if I was craving Ethiopian (as I so often do). There's so much more I want to try!

excerpts: Will definitely come back, as I'd like to try the lamb tibs and the vegetarian combination next
vegetarian combination.author: Kevin P.
vegetarian combination.review:
Food was very good - I ordered the special kitfo, medium rare, which was served with some injera bread
Staff were extremely friendly
Will definitely come back, as I'd like to try the lamb tibs and the vegetarian combination next

excerpts: The vegetarian combination is very filling and reasonably priced.
I kinda of wish there was a meat combo, but instead all the carnivore options were just the meat with injera.
Guess
Vegetarian Combination:
Loved the variety of 6 different items on one plate.
My favorite was probably the misir wot since I love me some berbere.
The kik alicha was pretty tasty too since chickpeas are a nice hearty pairing to the spongy injera bread.
The gomen was a little bland, but mixing those collard greens with any of the mushier items solved that issue.
vegetarian combination.author: Adam B.
vegetarian combination.review:
A gem in the Tenderloin; a few seats and a menu full of Ethiopian treats.  The vegetarian combination is very filling and reasonably priced.  I kinda of wish there was a meat combo, but instead all the carnivore options were just the meat with injera.  Guess I'll have to come back with a friend next time to justify getting the veggie combo *and* a separate meat dish.

Beef Sambusa: The sambusa itself was very similar to a deep fried empanada.  I suppose many cultures have the concept of wrapping ground meat in dough and then heating it in oil.  However, the red sauce on the side was amazing!  Had a little spicy kick, but not overwhelming.  Full of so much flavor that it really brought these sambusas to the next level. 

Vegetarian Combination: Loved the variety of 6 different items on one plate.  My favorite was probably the misir wot since I love me some berbere.  The kik alicha was pretty tasty too since chickpeas are a nice hearty pairing to the spongy injera bread.  The gomen was a little bland, but mixing those collard greens with any of the mushier items solved that issue.  The alicha tikil gomen seemed to have a better blend of spices adorning the veggies.  The small amounts of buticha and azifa were a bit intense by themselves, but enhanced the other items when a dab was added.

excerpts: My friend and I had the vegetarian combination platter which is good for sharing between two people.
The flax seed and honey drink (Telba?) is delicious.
A great find and the waitstaff is the sweetest.
Recommended!
vegetarian combination.author: Nancy B.
vegetarian combination.review:
Excellent and super affordable food. The vegetarian and the vegan options are clearly marked on the menu and they are plenty! 
It is a small place which makes it very cozy and you can see what's going on and by the kitchen as they cook and serve the dishes.
My friend and I had the vegetarian combination platter which is good for sharing between two people. 
The flax seed and honey drink (Telba?) is delicious.
A great find and the waitstaff is the sweetest. Recommended!

excerpts: Our go-to main course is the Vegetarian combination and lamb tibs.
Veg combo comes with lentils, wat, collard greens and cabbage served on a big-ass injera.
And more rolled up slices of injera are served in a basket to keep you going.
3 different kinds of wats are served which have a lil kick to it.
I can eat just the lentils with injera all day long.
Also try their Ethiopian tea with honey.
vegetarian combination.author: Sujeesha V.
vegetarian combination.review:
My all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco!

This is a cute little hole-in-the-wall kinda place with colorful Ethiopian vibes. This place is located in super shady Tenderloin area of SF. So, uber. Uber. UBER (or Lyft, whatever). Crew is just Wonderful and they invite us in with a Big smile that is sooo contagious. They are very attentive and agnostic to your needs.

Our favorite appetizer here is the Fitfit and close second is Beef sambussa. Fitfit has this surprising tanginess to it that just wakes up your taste buds preparing your tongue for the awesomeness that is yet to be served in the name of main course.

Our go-to main course is the Vegetarian combination and lamb tibs. Veg combo comes with lentils, wat, collard greens and cabbage served on a big-ass injera. And more rolled up slices of injera are served in a basket to keep you going. 3 different kinds of wats are served which have a lil kick to it. I can eat just the lentils with injera all day long. Also try their Ethiopian tea with honey. Perfect compliment to the flavor profile going on in your mouth.

The spicy hot powder that is served as a side IS. THE. BOMB. Just sprinkle a lil bit on your injera before diving into the dips and you can thank me later!

Fun fact: just gotta check mark on the receipt to tip, which makes tipping a no-brainer. Ain't that awesome? :D

My Ethiopian friend vouches for this place and so do I. Try it out. You wont regret it.

excerpts: We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs.
This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera.
My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs.
SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite.
Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.
vegetarian combination.author: Crystal S.
vegetarian combination.review: Went here for an early dinner on a Saturday prior to watching a movie. We figured this would be a perfect place as one of our group is a Vegetarian. We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs. This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera. My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs. SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite. Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.

excerpts: My friends are both Vegetarian, so we ordered the Vegetarian Combination (lentils, cabbage, collard greens) with Shiro Wot (ground chickpeas that had a consistency of a thick, refried bean paste) to share.
Injera came separately in a basket.
The flavors were fantastic, and it was definitely a good idea to split it between the 3 of us!
We especially enjoyed the Shiro Wot and lentils.
vegetarian combination.author: Christine T.
vegetarian combination.review:
I went with two girl friends to Tadu last night and was extremely pleased. I walked over to Tadu from Union Square and didn't feel the most comfortable walking alone through the Tenderloin, so just take note of this if you decide to come by foot in the evening. 

It's a small place but was well-packed when we arrived. I asked for a table for three, and the girl working there quickly ran to the back to grab two chairs to join a table with a single chair. We started off with lentil sambussas (samosas), which came out super hot and fresh with BOMB spicy sauce! 

My friends are both Vegetarian, so we ordered the Vegetarian Combination (lentils, cabbage, collard greens) with Shiro Wot (ground chickpeas that had a consistency of a thick, refried bean paste) to share. Injera came separately in a basket. The flavors were fantastic, and it was definitely a good idea to split it between the 3 of us! We especially enjoyed the Shiro Wot and lentils. After we finished the huge platter, the girl brought us a small plate of baklava that was "on the house", which was such a pleasant surprise. 

The man running the show was super nice and definitely gave Tadu a warm, home-y vibe. Friendly service, great bang for your buck--I'll be back.

excerpts: Vegetarian combination.
Great way to try all the different Ethiopian prepared veggies.
Each has it unique flavor, some mild, while others are a bit more spicy.
I like the spicy Misir
Wot the best.
vegetarian combination.author: Edwin L.
vegetarian combination.review:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and fortunately it was very good.  If not, I would have been turned off to Ethiopian cuisine.  The restaurant was a bit in the shady area of San Francisco but well worth the trip. It was dotted with more of the homeless and indignant rather than gangs so I didn't feel unsafe when I went in the late afternoon daylight hours.

For the restaurant itself; small cafe style with about 6 small tables.  Clean, well kept, homey, and comfortable, nothing fancy.  It looked like about 60% of the business was take out.  Since this was my first experience with Ethiopian food, I didn't have a basis to compare the food with but I can tell you everything was fresh, flavorful, excellently prepared and unexpectedly well presented for a small cafe restaurant in the Tenderloin district. I would describe the food as tasty comfort food that you could easily develop a craving for.  Portions didn't look much when I first got it, me being a "healthy" eater but it was more than enough to fill me up.  I think the Injera bread has a lot to do with it.

A family run business and I really appreciate the friendly, caring atmosphere where customers are made to feel as a guest in their "home", a lost art with most business nowadays. 

My wife and I had the Sambussa.. Tasty with a mild spicy sauce on the side. Nicely packed, so you actually can taste the stuffing. Lamb Tibs.  Grilled tidbits with onions and spices.  This was really good having a nice seared flavor.   Vegetarian combination.  Great way to try all the different Ethiopian prepared veggies.  Each has it unique flavor, some mild, while others are a bit more spicy.  I like the spicy Misir Wot the best.  I had a small cup of Ethiopian coffee which the owner gave me for free to try We also got a complementary Baklava and Spiced tea (they forgot to give us our Spice tea during our order) (a typical example of how customers are treated as a valued and appreciated "guest").  Boy the Baklava was good too, being not overly sweet having a flaky pastry.

All and all, excellent experience and tasty food at a reasonable price.  I have now developed a comfort food craving for Ethiopian cuisine and for this establishment.  Thank you Tadu!!!

excerpts:
**VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints.

In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there.
vegetarian combination.author: Elliott D.
vegetarian combination.review:
TL;DR:

Quite decent in the realm of Ethiopian, though I'm puzzled by their lack of a proper Wot offerings.

THE DEETS:

***VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints. In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there. Unexpected but interesting.

***REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter. Served with a side of Ayib (cheese). Spicy & Hot. (served rare of course)

Nice & buttery, I approve. I like a little moo with my beef (raw or rare). They seem to serve as tiny bits rather than actual ground beef, which is an interesting & unexpected approach. 

***LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.

I've never really cared for tibs, which are kinda okay but just not as creamy, tender, or flavorful as wot. But they don't have any wot offerings, which is disappointing. 

***FIRFIR - LAMB ALICHA BANATU - Small pieces of injera tossed in Tadu's sauces of mild tumeric with lamb. Mild.

Quite nice. This dish highlights why Ethiopian leftovers are always better the second day--the injera gets soft, mushy, and even a bit more fermented, which sounds like it would be gross, but during this process everything becomes super-infused with flavor.

excerpts: I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea.
Amazing food and very affordable.
vegetarian combination.author: Astrohfiziks A.
vegetarian combination.review:
Very very delicious. I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea. Amazing food and very affordable. My belly was very happy!

The only drawback was that my friend, when paying, didn't receive his card back. Understandable, as it was a crowded day. He realized it once we'd left the restaurant, and noted that when he went back to receive it, the staff did not apologize for the inconvenience it caused him. 

I agree with other reviewers that the service can be odd (we asked other diners who had ordered if we could have their menu after waiting for a bit and not receiving on) and that the neighborhood isn't the best. Despite these small things, I definitely plan to go back.

excerpts: VEGETARIAN COMBINATION ($12)
We ordered the vegetarian banatu/firfir, but I'm pretty sure they gave us the veggie combo now that I'm looking back at my picture.
The vegetarian firfir is supposed to be vegetables and pieces of injera in berbere
but we definitely did not get that on our plate.
vegetarian combination.author: Jessie L.
vegetarian combination.review:
TLDR: flavorful Ethiopian food, large portions, very reasonable prices; definitely recommend for a different dining experience

I've seen Tadu listed as one of the "Best of Yelp" Restaurants for many weeks now (maybe since its opening?). I've yet to see a place maintain a 5-star rating for so long and with 100+ reviews, so of course it made my bookmarks list. Honestly, if fellow Yelper Ben K. hadn't suggested it for dinner, I don't know if I would've ever made it here since I don't like to frequent the TL.

The restaurant is a small hole-in-the wall with maybe 5-6 tables and probably has the capacity for only 15ish people. In contrast to the surrounding TL, the inside is pretty nice and clean. The place wasn't busy yet at around 6pm on a Friday, but it filled up pretty easily and there were people waiting by the time we left.

Anyone unfamiliar with Ethiopian food (like me) might be a little lost with the menu, not because there are too many options, but because everything sounds more or less the same. The menu has a few appetizers and several veggie and meat entrees, which all come with injera, a spongy sourdough crepe. I'd recommend the SAMBUSSAS as a starter and LAMB TIBS as an entree. And you can't go wrong with the VEGETARIAN COMBO, which will give you sampling of almost all the veggie entrees. The food overall was pretty tasty and I really enjoyed anything cooked with berbere (some sort of chili/spice).

For anyone who hasn't had Ethiopian food, there are no utensils (unless asked for). You basically break off pieces of injera and use it to pick up the meat/veggies or dip it in the more hummus-like veggie dishes.

Entrees range from $10-15 and portion sizes are big and filling, especially with the unlimited injera. One entree can easily feed you for 2 meals, so it's definitely worth the price. Being the fatass that I am sometimes though, I ended up eating much more than I should have..

Service is pretty good here. Our server (who I think may have been the owner) checked in on us a few times to ask how the food was and to see if we needed more injera or water.

===========

SAMBUSSA ($4) - 5/5
Comes with 3. Kind of like samosas, but the dough is thinner, airier, flakier and crispier, and the inside is filled with ground beef or lentils. We got the ground beef, which was amazing! A little bit of spice and so much flavor

LAMB TIBS ($14) - 4/5
[sautéed in spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, berbere]
Juicy and delicious! The jalapeños and berbere give it a good kick, but more heat would've been even better. The dish was on the greasy side for me but tasted so good that the greasiness couldn't stop me from eating more of it

VEGETARIAN COMBINATION ($12) - 4/5
We ordered the vegetarian banatu/firfir, but I'm pretty sure they gave us the veggie combo now that I'm looking back at my picture. The vegetarian firfir is supposed to be vegetables and pieces of injera in berbere but we definitely did not get that on our plate. The veggie combo didn't disappoint though and was a really good sampler of many of their veggie entrees

     -MISIR WOT - 4.5/5
     [split lentil sauce made w/ berbere, onions, ginger, garlic]
     Orange/red and similar in texture to a thick tomato sauce. A little bit spicy from the berbere, which I loved. Definitely one of my favorite veggie options
     
     -ALICHA TIKIL GOMEN - 4.5/5
     [cabbage, potatoes & carrots]
     Another favorite from the combo. Not as flavorful as the misir wot but I like that it actually has veggies in it

     -GOMEN - 3.5/5
     [collard greens]
     A little bitter but still pretty good

     -KIK ALICHA WOT - 3/5
     [chickpea cooked w/ spicy tumeric, ginger & garlic]
     Yellow and a little thicker than hummus in texture. Not bad but didn't impress me

     -BUTICHA - 3/5
     [ground chickpeas, peppers & onions]
     Reminded me of a potato salad in taste and mashed potatoes in texture. I actually liked the flavor but it felt pretty rich and heavy so I could only eat a few bites

     -AZIFA - 3/5
     [lentils sauteed w/ onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds & lemon]
     Served cold. Also kind of rich/heavy

VEGGIE MEDLEY ($10) - 4/5
[mushrooms stir fried w/ peppers, jalapeno & berbere]
Solid. Not super special and pretty greasy, but very flavorful

KITFO ($13.50) - 3.5/5
Flavorful lean ground beef, cooked to a nice medium rare. I liked it a lot at first but wasn't really a fan of the half raw ground texture after a bit

INJERA (complimentary)
The entrees are served on a giant piece of injera. I've only had Ethiopian once before and didn't like the injera much because of the acidity, but was pleased with the injera here. Theirs was soft, spongy and tasted like sourdough without being too acidic. I don't really like sourdough in general so I wouldn't eat the injera on its own, but it works well with the entrees and soaks up the juices of the lamb very well

excerpts: We ordered the sambussas (both veggie and beef), which were very good, along with the vegetarian combination plate and the chicken tibs.
I liked that everything was presented on a large injera, so that all of the juices could soak in.
The food was very tasty, although not noteworthy.
The ambiance (or lack thereof) of the space made it less of an enjoyable experience.
Plus, given the small space and lack of music, you could overhear all of the conversations around us.
I'm sure they are running a clean kitchen
but the space just felt tired and a bit rundown; I think it really needs a complete interior renovation.
I think if we eat here again, it will be take out rather than sit down.
vegetarian combination.author: Regina L.
vegetarian combination.review:
My husband and I love Ethiopian food, so we were very excited to learn about Tadu. We came relatively early on a Saturday evening and there was a pretty long line already. We were hoping that the line would move quickly, but given how small their space is, it took longer than the time quoted. Normally I wouldn't mind but the restaurant is in a BAD area; during our wait we saw a drug deal occur two doors down, and we were constantly yelled at or solicited by passerbys. When we finally sat down, I realized how small their actual kitchen was and worried that we might be waiting quite some time for our food. Thankfully orders were placed quickly and food came out relatively regularly and quickly. 

We ordered the sambussas (both veggie and beef), which were very good, along with the vegetarian combination plate and the chicken tibs. I liked that everything was presented on a large injera, so that all of the juices could soak in. The food was very tasty, although not noteworthy. The ambiance (or lack thereof) of the space made it less of an enjoyable experience.  Plus, given the small space and lack of music, you could overhear all of the conversations around us. I'm sure they are running a clean kitchen but the space just felt tired and a bit rundown; I think it really needs a complete interior renovation. I think if we eat here again, it will be take out rather than sit down.

excerpts: We ordered a vegetarian combination along with the lamb tibs and the beef kitfo.
vegetarian combination.author: Jason G.
vegetarian combination.review:
Stopped by here for lunch this weekend before seeing a show at the Orpheum.

This is a small restaurant, with a clean, modern industrial look inside, with bold colors and nice art on the walls.

Friendly, helpful service, so even if you have no experience with Ethiopian food you should feel confident that you'll know what you're getting.

Great food. Bold flavors, both for the meats and the vegetables. The lamb tibs were my personal favorite - outstanding.

We had a table of four, and of course were looking for variety. We ordered a vegetarian combination along with the lamb tibs and the beef kitfo. That was plenty of food for the four of us. 

If you're in this area, you need to go support this restaurant.

excerpts: I enjoyed the vegetarian combination and chicken tubs immensely.
There wasn't a single item that I did not enjoy.
vegetarian combination.author: Rowen D.
vegetarian combination.review:
I enjoyed the vegetarian combination and chicken tubs immensely. There wasn't a single item that I did not enjoy. It was flavorful and perfect for two people. 

It's super small but friendly and endearing

excerpts:
I didn't know exactly what the vegetarian combination consisted of however each side did not disappoint my adventurous taste buds
-The collard greens, lentils and chickpeas from the vegetarian dish were all great as well.
vegetarian combination.author: P H.
vegetarian combination.review:
Decor: 4/5
-VERY limited seating
-has incense sticks placed near the tables on the steel beams

Service: 5/5
-very welcoming and homey, our orders were taken at the table and served to the table

Food: 5/5
-First time trying Ethiopian and I'm blown away at how delicious the dishes were.
-I ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs. Addicting & Wow. Two word sums up the beef tibs. Excellent flavors and spices for the beef tids. I didn't know exactly what the vegetarian combination consisted of however each side did not disappoint my adventurous taste buds
-The collard greens, lentils and chickpeas from the vegetarian dish were all great as well.

excerpts:
We ordered the vegetarian combination (great way to sample all of the vegetarian dishes instead of ordering just one), the chicken tibs, and the beef firfir. 

Got the chicken tibs as "spicy" as well but it definitely didn't have nearly as much kick as the beef firfir.
On wait times - came here on a Saturday night near closing time (8:40 pm) and they let us in
vegetarian combination.author: Sylvia L.
vegetarian combination.review:
Servings here are generous. We ordered the vegetarian combination (great way to sample all of the vegetarian dishes instead of ordering just one), the chicken tibs, and the beef firfir. 

Tips:
If you like spicy - go with the Firfir (beef, not the lamb - they said they can't make the lamb as spicy). Got the chicken tibs as "spicy" as well but it definitely didn't have nearly as much kick as the beef firfir.
On wait times - came here on a Saturday night near closing time (8:40 pm) and they let us in (there was even a waiting line); pretty sure they kept letting people in around 9pm and maybe 10 minutes after.

All in all - the food was good but it wasn't mindblowingly better than Moya (I actually thought it was on par) so I think I'll stick with ordering from Moya and then eating at the City Beer Store (they let you bring food in) so that I can have delicious Ethiopian with delicious beer :).

excerpts: We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination.
Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait
and everything was delicious!
If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special.
But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.
vegetarian combination.author: Jenny F.
vegetarian combination.review:
I'm definitely going to be frequenting this restaurant after my first visit tonight.

I've always been a huge fan of Ethiopian cuisine, with New Eritrea being one of my favorite SF spots. The only drawback about New Eritrea is that it's all the way in the Sunset, which isn't very conveniently located for me (but they're still worth the drive)!

But I digress. I was so glad the girlfriend found this spot on Yelp that was so close to where we work and on our way home. When we first walked it, it appears to be completely full, all tables occupied. The sweet owner asked us if we wanted to dine in and pulled out an extra table that fit perfectly in the little nook of space left in the room.

We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination. Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait and everything was delicious! If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special. But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.

If you're on the fence about this place, jump off already! There's a reason they have such high ratings. Great service & amazing food. Let the food speak for itself. :)

excerpts: Ordered a Vegetarian combination and Chicken Tibs.
vegetarian combination.author: Pranav B.
vegetarian combination.review:
I had read a lot about this place on Yelp and have seen in consistently rated in the Top 10 SFO restaurants. This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and needless to say, I absolutely loved it. Ordered a Vegetarian combination and Chicken Tibs. Really loved the Misir Wot and Shiro Wot . The rest of the lentils and salads were alright. 

Cons: It is located in the Tenderloin area, which is a sketchy neighbourhood. Also, I wish the Injera were served hot.

Mentioned the cons to the owner and he took my review positively. Overall, anyone in SFO city should check out this place.

excerpts: On my first visit, my order, the vegetarian combination, consists of about 7 different vegetarian dishes that they offer, so one gets a true sample of their menu.
And, this dish just blew me away!
There was such a variety of flavors, one more amazing than the next!
vegetarian combination.author: Yvette F.
vegetarian combination.review:
I have been here twice this week for takeout, and sketchy neighborhood be damned, I'll be back for more!  

On my first visit, my order, the vegetarian combination, consists of about 7 different vegetarian dishes that they offer, so one gets a true sample of their menu.  And, this dish just blew me away!  There was such a variety of flavors, one more amazing than the next!  On my next visit, I ordered the lamb tibs, lamb ribs and meat pieces with onions that are cooked firm, slightly chewy and fully flavored. When I asked to have a vegetable stew (wot) that I had enjoyed so much with the lamb, instead of having me order it as a separate side, the kind woman who was helping me suggested that she would just include it on my lamb dish for an extra $1!!  That was just the perfect amount for me and I really appreciated her accommodating my wish.  So, what more can I add?!!  Go and try it!

excerpts: For dinner I had the lamb tibs, one friend had the special kitfo and my other friend has the vegetarian combination.
We all thought it was absolutely delicious.
Then for dessert we had the baklava.
Probably the best that I have ever had.
Will definitely go back.
Thank you Tadu!
vegetarian combination.author: Brianna M.
vegetarian combination.review: Best food Ethiopian food I have ever had. Went tonight with two of my friends. The waiter was extremely helpful and so very nice. For an appetizer we had the lentil sambussa which was so moist and delicious. For dinner I had the lamb tibs, one friend had the special kitfo and my other friend has the vegetarian combination. We all thought it was absolutely delicious. Then for dessert we had the baklava. Probably the best that I have ever had. Will definitely go back. Thank you Tadu!

excerpts: Now, on to the food:  We had the vegetarian combination and the lamb tib.
Both were just incredible.
There's not much more to say.
vegetarian combination.author: Justin H.
vegetarian combination.review:
OK, let's get this out of the way first: This is very possibly the best cup of coffee in San Francisco.  Dude at the counter (very dark skinned man with a huge smile) is a painter and uses coffee to paint.  He makes each cup by hand and it's seriously the perfect cup.

Now, on to the food:  We had the vegetarian combination and the lamb tib.  Both were just incredible.  There's not much more to say.

excerpts: I had the vegetarian combination.
Would not hesitate to go back.
vegetarian combination.author: Kevin B.
vegetarian combination.review: Really good food, great service, and not to pricey. I had the vegetarian combination. Would not hesitate to go back.

excerpts: We've tried the tibs, the kitfo, the vegetarian combo, and the minchet abish wot.
By far our favorites that we keep coming back for are the vegetarian combo and minchet abish wot.
So.
Freaking.
minchet abish wot.author: Joanne Y.
minchet abish wot.review:
One of my favorite cuisines and best of all this is only a few blocks from our place. We've tried the tibs, the kitfo, the vegetarian combo, and the minchet abish wot. By far our favorites that we keep coming back for are the vegetarian combo and minchet abish wot. So. Freaking. Good.

Occasionally I'll go through Ethiopian food withdrawal and I'll need to binge-eat this stuff. Actually, who am I kidding? Every time I get food from here I binge eat. It's hard to know exactly when to stop, and when I've reached that stopping point I know it's already too late... injera (sourdough-like sponge bread) EXPANDS in your stomach! My favorite thing to do is to come here after a good long bike ride or exercise, to be famished, and then stuff myself to the brim with a deliciously savory and filling meal here. Always so satisfying. Once I came here two days in a row. Yeah, it's that good.

Sharing is probably one of my favorite aspects of Ethiopian food. Everyone becomes very intimate with each other as you share food using your hands from a shared plate. Of course, that's not required if eating with your hands sounds icky, but it's part of the interactive experience of the meal!

TIP: Seating is pretty tight here, so I'd say come with no more than a group of four!

excerpts: Minchet Abish Wot - Savory, spicy, really great with the injera.
minchet abish wot.author: Jessica L.
minchet abish wot.review:
Delicious Ethiopian food! Went for the first time last night and it was fantastic. 

We ordered:
Lentil Sambusa - Little fried pocket of deliciousness. Very flavorful. Comes with a red spicy sauce that makes this appetizer special.
Vegetarian Combination- Lots of different sides. My favorite were the Misir Wot.
Minchet Abish Wot - Savory, spicy, really great with the injera.
Side of Shiro Wot - YUM. 

The restaurant is small and cozy. Casual vibe. The guy who waited on us, let us try the Shiro for free (and it was amazing). I highly suggest this restaurant if you like Ethiopian.

The only thing this restaurant is missing is a meat/veggie combo. Sometimes you just want a little of both :)

excerpts: The Minchet Abish Wot (that the man recommended) was really bad - and not like any Ethiopian food I have had.
A large portion of dry, overcooked ground beef - like the dry ground beef in a bad fast-food taco.
The lentils were hard and undercooked/undersoaked.
The two hispanic ladies in the kitchen don't know how to make Ethiopian food, and it seems they aren't good cooks in general.
Ethiopian aside, it was just bad food, cooked poorly.
The flavors were off and the food wasn't prepared well.
minchet abish wot.author: Ruth C.
minchet abish wot.review: The Minchet Abish Wot (that the man recommended) was really bad - and not like any Ethiopian food I have had. A large portion of dry, overcooked ground beef - like the dry ground beef in a bad fast-food taco. The lentils were hard and undercooked/undersoaked. The two hispanic ladies in the kitchen don't know how to make Ethiopian food, and it seems they aren't good cooks in general. Ethiopian aside, it was just bad food, cooked poorly. The flavors were off and the food wasn't prepared well.

excerpts: I love the vegetarian combo, lamb tibs and Minchet Abish Wot.
Minchet Abish
Wot is a comfort food for me....
minchet abish wot.author: Mohi M.
minchet abish wot.review: Best Ethiopian food I have ever had. I love Ethiopian dishes and Tadu Kitchen hits the spot. Their dishes are very authentic and they offer injera from Ethiopia for extra fee. I recommend it. If you are not familiar if this cuisine, ask the owner to help you. I love the vegetarian combo, lamb tibs and Minchet Abish Wot. Minchet Abish Wot is a comfort food for me....

excerpts: We ordered Sambussa (deep-fried pastry stuffed with lentils) for our appetizer; Kitfo (ground beef sautéed with spices) and Gomen Besega (collard greens cooked with lamb).
gomen besega.author: Michelle P.
gomen besega.review:
Exploring the Tenderloin...post Color Purple at The Orpheum.  The spices wafting through the door convinced me and my son...we had picked a winner! 

We ordered Sambussa (deep-fried pastry stuffed with lentils) for our appetizer; Kitfo (ground beef sautéed with spices) and Gomen Besega (collard greens cooked with lamb). 

We ate family style and pinching our food with the Injera (bread similar to a crepe).  My only regret is that I didn't bring my other 2 sons so we could try more dishes.

excerpts:
The dishes I had were amazing:

gomen besega - collard greens with lamb.
gomen besega.author: Bucky M.
gomen besega.review:
Delicious Ethiopian food. They have tables, chairs, silverware (some Ethiopian places are a little too authentic and don't have those things).

The dishes I had were amazing:

gomen besega - collard greens with lamb.

lamb alicha banatu firfir - mild turmeric.

excerpts: For my entree, I decided on the $12.50 Gomen Besega, a house specialty that takes a huge round of injera, the spongy native bread of Ethiopia, and then covers it with cooked collard greens mixed with bits of minced lamb, garlic and onion.
gomen besega.author: Ed U.
gomen besega.review:
Another treasure hunt led me to this compact Ethiopian spot deep in the 'Loin. Again a waft of positive Yelp reviews gave me the courage to gird my loins after dark and find my way to Ellis between Leavenworth and Jones where this cafe resides. Even though it was just past 8PM by the time I arrived, it was nearly full up with diners who didn't look like they were going anywhere soon. Luckily by the time I ordered at the counter, the front table opened up. I asked the woman at the register what she recommended since I was unfamiliar with everything on the menu except kitfo and injera (photo: http://bit.ly/1Dt2tGn). Kitfo is a bit like Hamburger Helper, Ethiopian style, which is not a bad thing but probably more meat-heavy than I had in mind for an entree.

In the meantime, who wouldn't want to start with an Ethiopian empanada called Sambussa, where you get three large, deep-fried turnover-like creations filled with lentil beans, onions and peppers? A trio for $4 struck me as a good deal, and it was, especially with a huge ramekin of a light marinara-like tomato sauce for dipping (photo: http://bit.ly/1EST1vN). For my entree, I decided on the $12.50 Gomen Besega, a house specialty that takes a huge round of injera, the spongy native bread of Ethiopia, and then covers it with cooked collard greens mixed with bits of minced lamb, garlic and onion. There was a thicker version of the tomato sauce on the side, which I think mixed in mashed lentil beans, as well as a fresh salad (photo: http://bit.ly/1ESSTfG).

On top of this generous portion came a basket of rolled injera which they served like bottomless mimosas (photo: http://bit.ly/1FwgaE4). By the time I depleted half of it, more injera came out as if it somehow multiplied in the kitchen. No matter since I happen to be a fan, and this one had a less vinegary taste than I've had at other Ethiopian spots. I was full by the time I was halfway through my entree, so I asked for a box which they happily provided. The owner came by to see if I enjoyed the food, and he shared with me his story about being a cabbie who dreamed of opening a place where he could serve his grandmother's recipes. Mission accomplished as the food has a very home-style flavor to it that tempers the exotic aspects of the cuisine. I plan to come back in the daytime when I can more freely walk there.

FOOD - 4 stars...home-style Ethiopian with the most flavorful injera in town (sorry Moya!)
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a bit tight in space but the interior is brightly lit and clean
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quite friendly and accommodating
TOTAL - 4 stars...if you're in the mood for Ethiopian, this is no Tenderloin trap

excerpts: Kitfo special and gomen besega are my jam and they definitely delivered here!
The spices and ghee were so indulgent against the tender meat and stewed greens.
And who doesn't love the primitive nature of eating sans
utensils?
gomen besega.author: Katie O.
gomen besega.review:
Kitfo special and gomen besega are my jam and they definitely delivered here! The spices and ghee were so indulgent against the tender meat and stewed greens. And who doesn't love the primitive nature of eating sans utensils? Very interactive.

One recommendation is to go raw with the kitfo--its like steak tartare but a million times better sopped up with tart injere. 

So glad to find another good ethiopian place a hop and skip away from home.

excerpts: The Gomen Besega was just what I was seeking.
The quinoa bread was superb and very tasty!
Accompanied by a fresh salad, a culinary adventure indeed!
Take out or eat in!
Whichever, take time to talk to the proprietors!
Friendly, intelligent, kind folks with a flare for art!
gomen besega.author: Michael B.
gomen besega.review: Tadu is an up and coming gem!  The Gomen Besega was just what I was seeking.  The quinoa bread was superb and very tasty! Accompanied by a fresh salad, a culinary adventure indeed!  Take out or eat in!  Whichever, take time to talk to the proprietors! Friendly, intelligent, kind folks with a flare for art!
